column2: These are palmy days for the housing and home-finance market. Record housing starts, a massive flow of new deposits to mortgage lenders and the prospect of fat profits for just about everybody are the theme this year.
NEW DELHI, May 6 -- A controversy over limiting land holdings is rocking India and, in some states, threatening a split in the ruling Congress party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

Awards were presented last night to two alumni and a member of the graduating class of 1972 by the Association of the Alumni of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons at its annual dinner at the Pierre Hotel.

Four well-known lawyers, including two prosecutors, agreed last week that the great power of the American prosecutor presents a grave potential for abuse. However, they failed to agree on what steps, if any, should be taken to reduce this potential.

When I was in the first grade, our teacher took us all one spring day to a tiny pond in the woods a few miles from the school, which was in eastern Massachusetts. It was hardly a pond, actually no more than a leaf-choked, marshy depression among the hardwoods.

AN elderly man leading his donkey and cart came down to the quay as our cruiser lay docked at Carnadoe Waters, one of the many lakes along Ireland's River Shannon. He went about filling a barrel of drinking water to take home. Yes, people do drink the Shannon's water.

How did a University of Maryland professor of English, whose field is the 18th century and whose Columbia Ph.D. dissertation was written on the composer Handel, come to devote 20 years of his life to the transcription, arranging and interweaving (plus copious introductory and biographical amplification) of the thousands of documents from a 19th-century Southern family that make up "The Children of Pride"?
OTTAWA, May 6 -- Ottawa immigration officials say they have discovered an underground route that was to be followed by possibly "thousands" of Cuban exiles hoping to enter the United States.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland -- In the open-hearth foundry of the Beirut Steel Works -- Poland's second largest steel mill -- large blackboards list the daily output of pig iron and the amount of money earned by each crew. The greater the output, the higher the wages.

DIEPPE, France -- There are two ways to get a reputation as a good French cook. One is to prop "Larousse Gastronomique" against the mixer and "Paris Bistro Cooking" behind the cutting board and follow them with slavish care; the other is to go to France and learn.

An unusual collection of photographs, manuscripts and other memorabilia entitled "Where Have All the Orphans Gone?" gives a glimpse of austerity and regimentation facing a disowned child before the turn of the century -- if he was lucky enough to get into a large orphanage.

IT'S almost impossible for today's television-disoriented youngsters to imagine the impact radio had in the thirties and forties, the golden age of the spoken word. There we'd sit, the whole family, huddled around the faceless squawk box in the living room, the glow of the amber dial shining on names like Stromberg-Carlson, Atwater Kent and Superheterodyne.
NEW BRUNSWICK -- The Eagleton Center for the American Woman and Politics here will bring 50 women politicians together this month to see what can be done about ending male domination of politics.

There was no inkling of impending doom. There had been a severe earthquake a day or two earlier and a great scar on a mountainside far up the wild valley showed that a landslide had occurred. But for the 20,000 inhabitants of Khait, a town in the Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic near the Afghanistan border, quakes are so common that little heed was paid.

CASTLE gates have been opening all over the British Isles in recent years, and one of the latest to display the "Do-Come-In" sign is owned by Northern Ireland's Lord Raymond O'Neill. He is different from some of his tourist-minded counterparts in that he is hardly poor and he has arranged for visitors to view his estate in a private train.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 6 -- The Rusty Callow Memorial rowing regatta on Lake Quinsigamond was won today by the United States Caost Guard Academy varsity crew. Leading the entire distance, the undefeated cadets finished four lengths ahead of the defending regatta chompion, Trinity College.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 6 -- Buffalo State University won the lightweight championship eight-oared shell event of the ninth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate rowing championship today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon Olympic rowing course.
TALLADEGA, Ala., May 6 -- Qualifying was completed this afternoon for tomorrow's running of the Winston 500, the 11th race of the Season on the Grand National stock-car circuit.

. . . castle crawling in the Ould Sod, don't expect to be hobnobbing with the natives when you sit down to dinner. It is more likely that you will be surrounded by Americans, even though some of them may be named Kelley and O'Keefe. Knappogue, Bunratty and Dungaire Castles hold their banquet and entertainment programs twice nightly (6 and 9 P.M.).

BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 6 -- Ed Williams, a 23-year-old junior from Bermuda, shattered meet records in the long and triple jumps to lead C. W. Post College to the team title in the 20th annual Collegiate Track Conference championship today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Way 6 -- Walking more or less on two legs and seeming a bit tired from too much sun or too much something, the homeward-bound spectators on one side of the fence barely noticed the splendid animal on the other side, by the barn.

Books that attempt to establish their significance before the story has even started make some readers (this one) a little wary of what is to follow. In this novel, the author first thanks a foundation that no longer exists.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 -- Recycling of castaway bottles, cans and papers so far is failing to make much headway around the country despite the efforts of thousands of ecology-minded people who are hauling the waste products to collection points for re-use.

More than 100 amateur wrestlers from this area, hoping to earn berths on the summer Olympic team, begin their quest next weekend in the Metropolitan Olympic Trial Meet outdoors at Cantiague Park in Hicksville, L.I.

Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, vowed yesterday to take "what ever additional steps are necessary" to clear Lewisohn Hall of the black and Latin students and "outsiders" who have held it for 12 days.
HONG KONG, May 6 -- An acute shortage of teachers with knowledge of the language is a major problem in the new drive in China to teach English in the nation's schools, starting with primary grades.

Rumania, which unsuccessfully challenged the United States for Davis Cup tennis supremacy last year, clinched a first-round European Zone victory over Switzerland yesterday when Ilie Nastase and Ion Tiriac combined for a 6-0, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1 doubles triumph over Matthias Werren and Freddy Blatter.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- Chris Speier's two-run homer and four-hit pitching by Sam McDowell carried the San Francisco Giants to a 3-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

THE relation in which artistic ideas stand to the pressures of revolutionary politics is too often assumed -- almost always for political rather than artistic reasons -- to be a simple one. Despite a mountain of evidence to the contrary, the belief persists that art, if it is sufficiently "advanced" esthetically, will naturally ally itself with the ideology of revolution.
LIME ROCK, Conn., May 6 -- George Follmer of Arcadia, Calif., who is playing cross-country commuter this weekend, led from start to finish today and won the 200-mile Schaefer Trans-Am in a Javelin.

John M. Schiff's Droll Role, the outsider in an eight-horse field, outlasted Rokeby's Farewell Party in a tense duel down the stretch at Aqueduct yesterday to capture the $83,475 Grey Lag Handicap by a nose.

A national political convention involves complicated logistics in housing, feeding and transporting thousands of delegates and visitors as well as serving the special communication needs of newspapers and television. For these mundane reasons, it is always a help all around for both parties to convene in the same city and to choose one which -- like Miami Beach -- has ample facilities and experience.

There is a strong sense, in C. P. Snow's novels, of circles overlapping, of year inextricably linking up with year, of old places trodden over with fresh footprint. The "Strangers and Brothers" sequence hovers back and forth in setting and time, so that even such a novel as "The Masters," which covers events in only one year, costs its backward glances, and itself foreshadows its successors.
COLUMBIA, S. C., May 6 -- In the latest development in a controversy involving the African Methodist Episcopal Church, Bishop William F. Ball Sr. has denied "any mishandling of funds."

EAST MEADOW, L. I. May 6 -- Within minutes after the Nassau County Police Department opened its miniature "safety town" here this week to teach young school children traffic safety, there was a "four-car accident" on one of its 10-foot-wide macadam roads.
WE WERE having a conversation about "Conversation" the other day with Francis Ford Coppola. "Conversation" is the title of an original thriller, and Coppola is its author.
NEWARK -- Essex County College, one of the newest community colleges in the state, has established an educational exchange agreement with a Soviet educational institution.

The political and gastronomic borders between France and Switzerland were confused in the article on Geneva (Travel section, March 5). The author stated correctly that Switzerland is not for gourmets, but gour mets do not consider Geneva a part of Switzerland.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- The Kansas City Royals reached Baltimore pitching for seven runs in the first two innings tonight, scored a 9-1 victory and knocked the Orioles out of first place in the American League Eastern Division.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 6 (UPI) -- The defending champion Mrs. Beth Barry of Mobile Ala., defeated Mrs. Wanda Hendrix of Tyler, Tex., 10 and 8, in 36 holes of match play today to capture the Women's Southern golf championship.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday endorsed a bill passed by the Legislature authorizing creation of an 11 - member state commission that could revise New York City's Charter.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6 -- A 48-hour strike by 8,000 workers at the Chuquicamata copper mine, Chile's largest, ended today after the Government made concessions on bonuses, work regulations and promotions.
ST. LOUIS, May 6 -- A 320-acre plot of Kansas prairie land given in 1848 by the Potawatomi Indians to Jesuit missionaries has been paid back with interest.

When I was growing up I was very politically aware and ambitious. I knew just what I was going to be.

HARTFORD, May 6 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, the Connecticut Democrat who last week declared his support for Senator George McGovern as his party's candidate for the Presidency, was himself challenged this week by the McGovern organization in Hartford for his seat at the state nominating convention in June.

The Children's Community Workshop, a tuition-free "community school" organized by parents on the upper West Side as an alternative to public school education, is seeking affiliation with the public school system on an autonomous basis in an effort to survive a financial crisis that forced it to suspend operations last Monday.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 6 -- Three young revolutionaries were hanged here early today.

This is in reference to the article that appeared in the April 23 boating section regarding enforcement of New York State's antipollution laws. Navigation Law Section 33C, which prohibits the discharge of raw sewage from boats, is very much in force.
DETROIT, May 6 -- The Government is withholding too much money from the paycheck of Norbert Gazarek, an auto worker, but he doesn't care.

ROME -- Italian voters will find six or seven different hammer-and-sickle symbols on their ballots when they go to the polls today and tomorrow to elect a new Parliament. But there is little chance of Italy's drifting further to the left as a result of the election. The big and ominous question is over the strength of Italian neo-Fascism.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 7 -- The South Vietnamese Government announced last night that it had decided to evacuate all civilians from Kontum city, in the Central Highlands, south to Pleiku by road.
LITTLE FERRY -- "Sokol" is a familiar word in this small north Jersey borough, but its meaning falls victim to the generation gap.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Felix G. Rohatyn, who made controversial contacts with the White House and Justice Department concerning an antitrust settlement for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, is the sole trustee for the personal forune of Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson.

I was drawing some mice the other afternoon to illustrate a children's book I'm working on, and they were giving me trouble. I couldn't decide how to dress Mrs. Mouse and her daughter Edwina. So I went downstairs to see if a cup of coffee would help.

The National Broadcasting Company took the lion's share of a group of Emmy Awards presented by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences at twin ceremonies last night and yesterday afternoon here and in Los Angeles.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 6 -- Senator George McGovern made a strong statewide showing in precinct caucuses last night and appeared to have swamped Democratic party regulars in the fight for convention delegates from Oklahoma City and Tulsa.

WASHINGTON -- The events that battered the once-mighty United Mine Workers of America last week were described by some in the Bible Belt Appalachian coalfields as acts of a God "exceeding wroth." But that explanation left out the shade of Jock Yablonski -- by week's end, his vengeance seemed almost complete.

Wright Mills and . . . .

As the environmental backlash gains momentum it becomes fashionable to see the controversies in vaious shades of gray, instead of in sharply-defined black and white. After all, ecological concern must be fitted into the economic framework, we are told, Conservationists, though admittedly "well-intentioned," are also often "ill-advised" or "emotional," while the polluter (like the sportsman who gets his kicks from ambushing an elephant or a tiger) deeply cares about that which he destroys.

I am annoyed to see the youth air fares in existence again this summer. That the Government continues to condone "Let's Go to Europe" instead of "See U.S.A." is incomprehensible. Middle - aged Americans, who are compelled to pay full fare, have already traveled throughout the U.S.; today, however, we are raising a generation of young people who are more familiar with the Colosseum than the Grand Canyon.

THE delight in encountering the Edith Sitwell-William Walton "Facade" for the first time is not something easily forgotten. For this writer, it happened before World War II, when he was played the original recordings by Miss Sitwell and Constant Lambert.
MOSCOW, May 6 -- A sociological survey of Soviet working women made public here shows that those with professional skills appear to make the best mothers and the most efficient housewives.
AFLAO, Ghana, May 3 -- People in this eastern border town find it hard to believe that Kwame Nkrumah, the man who symbolized African independence, is dead.

THE Museum of Non-Objective Painting was always a bit pseudovoluptuous, what with ankle-deep wall-to-wall carpeting, overstuffed divans, enormous tailor-made silver or gold frames on paintings installed only inches from the floor, soft piped music (preferably Bach) plus a faint suggestion of scented air.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 6 -- The Commodity Credit Corporation of the United States Department of Agriculture and the Korea Silo Company, a private concern, signed here yesterday an agreement to jointly build and operate a $6.6-million grain-storage facility in the port of Inchon, west of Seoul.
TOKYO -- A 62-year-old real estate man in northeatsern Japan had the largest income in the country last year, a startling $12.6-million, and paid tax on most of it at a 14 per cent rate.

LONDON -- The more the Vietnamese front disintegrates the more President Nixon's Asian policy is threatened and the more Soviet prestige mounts all the way from Suez to Singapore. Consequently, the desperate effort to blunt General Giap's brilliant offensive has global implications.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reuters) -- The Justice Department is organizing task forces in key cities to combat speculators engaging in housing frauds on poor people, Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Peterson has told Congress.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 6 -- The new trustee-elect on the Mineola Board of Education, who receives $5 a week as an allowance from his parents -- "mostly for lunches" -- is not unduly disturbed that he will have to help determine educational policy here and spend $10-million in the next year.

Family musicales may have lost their appeal nowadays -- but from nursery school to picnic, from protest march to rock festival we can still hear America singing. And playing. You can hardly climb a mountain peak without finding the young already there, entertaining each other on the guitar.

TEL AVIV -- When the Israelis earlier this year ordered elections of local councils in the occupied West Bank area of Jordan, they figured that in view of Arab guerrilla pressure for an election boycott a 60 per cent turnout would be a political triumph. The turnout in the first-round voting in the northern province of Samaria last March was 84 per cent.

THE American tourists sitting at the tables in Knappogue Castle are middle-aged for the most part and just slightly foundering toward the end of a six-course medieval banquet as they fix their eyes on the "Seneschal of Knappogue," the castle's majordomo who introduces the nightly Pageant of Irish History.

It's just as fashionable to stay at home as to go out these nights. And you don't have to slop around in dumb nightgowns and bathrobes either, though they're still around. To Canadians, it is a symbol of their country's professional supremacy in the sport and, to the players, it is their childhood dream.

ALBANY -- The annual legislative Walpurgisnacht is under way with the state's 207 lawmakers busily engaged in massacring the mother tongue as they act on major legislation they have ignored since convening in January.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 -- A hijacker who extorted $303,000 from Eastern Airlines parachuted into Central America before dawn today, apparently leaving little trace. The crew of the aircraft landed safely in Mexico, exhausted after a 21-hour ordeal that began in Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- -- President Nixon announced today that he would ask Congress next week to provide extra money for the school breakfast and summer lunch programs for needy children.

ATLANTA, May 6 -- In this Southern city known for its hospitality the League of Women Voters was none too kind to men last week at the conclusion of its 30th annual convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- Monroe Baer Jr., a lawyer, is pushing a civil rights suit against the Standard Oil Company of California, for which he worked for 19 years. The suit alleges that Mr. Baer was discriminated against because he is a Jew.

May is a lily month, among other things, particularly the month of the lesser lilies of the fields. In the flower garden the domesticated lilies of the valley come to honey-sweet blossom, of course. But in the damp woods there are whole beds of lilies hurrying to bloom before the deep shade of full leafing overhead closes in.

DACHAU, West Germany, May 7 (AP) -- Five hundred former inmates of the Nazi concentration camp at Dachau marked the 27th anniversary of their liberation by the United States Army today with religious services and a silent procession honoring those who died here.

WASHINGTON CROSSING, N.J., May 7 -- The top-winning Lhasa Apso of 1971, Mrs. Patricia Chenoweth's Ch. Chen Korum-Ti, scored the biggest victory of his career tonight when he was named best of 4,177 dogs at the 43d show of the Trenton Kennel Club at Washington Crossing State Park.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Nixon today called a meeting tomorrow morning of the National Security Council, the Government's principal foreign policy body, and summoned Secretary of State William P. Rogers home from a European tour to attend it.

PARIS -- Is it because the Odeon -- or Theatre de France, as the old neo-classical temple on the Left Bank was then called -- was one of the chief stages of the event of May, 1968? At any rate, the rejection of authority is nowhere more evident than in the realm of drama.

ESTELLA, Spain May 7 (UPI) -- A Spanish princess who was exiled because of her political beliefs slipped back into Spain today to criticize the Government of Generalissime Francisco Franco at a rally of dissent monarchists in this northern city.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Senate's two leaders, Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, returned tonight from their three-week trip to China.

WASHINGTON -- The spreading estrangement of millions of Americans from the two traditional political parties makes increasingly relevant the possibility of a significant new national political base developing -- not just a passing protest vote but an important mainstream development.

IRVINGTON, N, J., May 7 -- Members of the Amalgamated Transit Union voted overwhelmingly today to accept a settlement ending the 68-day Transport of New Jersey bus strike. Service is expected to resume on some lines on Tuesday.

His stock was so poor he had trouble getting stalls, but he patched the critters up and managed to win some races.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 7 -- Five United States Army men who had been given up as dead ended a 13-day ordeal in an enemy-held jungle area last night and described their experiences today at a hospital.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 7 -- In an effort to cut down a rising crime rate, particularly in the downtown area, this city is seeking to enlist 20,000 residents in a controversial crime prevention program.

The mail-order business is receiving increasing scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission. In the last few weeks the F.T.C. has issued two unusually strong orders covering sins of omission and commission by two mail-order companies in the New York area.

Va., May 7 -- More than 100 representatives of the dissident, reform movement in the troubled United Mine Workers of America agreed here today to seek an immediate financial monitorship over the U.M.W. president, W. A. Boyle, under an order that is to be drawn up by the United States District Court in Washington.

The second stack is virgin. On its pages I'm supposed to assemble the pieces of my soon-to-end college career in a way which is both charming and sensible.

ORLANDO, Fla., May 7 (UPI) -- Glenn W. Turner, millionaire founder of the Dare to Be Great program and Koscot Interplanetary, Inc., surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged with conspiracy to commit fraud and conspiracy to violate the state lottery law and the securities act. They are sure to stir debate, as they already have in the State Senate, but they represent overdue reforms.

Representative John J. Rooney pressed the heel of his hand against his aching back. He had got it, he said the other day, in the line of duty, sitting in a draft at a luncheon with Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minister, and Itzhak Rabin, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 9 -- Edwin W. Edwards became Governor of Louisiana today and immediately had 80,000 people out to dinner.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 9 (AP) -- Stan Smith, America's hope for the Wimbledon tennis title, struggled to find his form on a slow court today at the start of his British campaign.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) -- Two former Penn Central executives were ordered held for grand jury action today on charges of fraud and conspiracy.

The Westchester Double Knockout Team Championship, which began in the fall with an entry of 37 teams, ended last week in a convincing victory for Arch McKellar of Mount Kisco, N. Y.; Ron Gerard of Hastings-onHudson, N.Y.; Richard Oshlag of White Plains and Monroe Magnus of Stamford, Conn.
LONDON, May 9 -- Jerry Quarry pounded The Hammer for 10 rounds tonight, evidently when the referee wasn't looking, and nailed down a close decision at the cost of a swollen left hand.
BRASILIA, May 9 -- The United States and Brazil signed an agreement here today intended to regulate the operations of United States shrimp boats in the rich waters off the mouth of the Amazon River.

In the opening round of the New York Presidential primary, leaders of Senator Geroge McGovern's campaign charged that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was trying to avoid a direct confrontation with Mr. McGovern by dealing with party leaders for national convention delegates.
Rear Adm. Rembrandt C. Robinson, who was killed Monday in the Tonkin Gulf, was the first officer of flag rank to be killed in Vietnam, according to the Navy.
VIENNA, May 9 -- Austria has declared a virtual diplomatic boycott of neighboring Czechoslovakia in the wake of a border incident last week that has led to a sharp exchange of notes.

Five magazines -- Architecural Record, The Atlantic, Esquire, Mademoiselle and Philadelphia -- have won the 1972 national magazine awards sponsored by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, it was announced yesterday.
ATHENS, May 9 -- The Government ordered a security crackdown today to stem growing agitation by intellectuals and students for greater freedom.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Attempts to stop the flow of men, weapons and supplies over land routes by the use of air power have uniformly failed throughout the history of the Korea and Vietnam wars.

While last Saturday's victory in the Kentucky Derby by Meadow Stable's Riva Ridge was still being discussed yesterday by horsemen at Aqueduct, hope was raised that King Ranch's Canonero II, the surprise 1971 winner of the Run for the Roses, might return to the races in 10 days.

In ordering the closing of land and sea supply routes to North Vietnam by American military action, President Nixon is taking a desperate gamble that alters the entire nature of the war, that risks the fundamental security and deepest interests of the United States for dubious and tenuous gains, and that runs counter both to Congressional mandate and to the will and conscience of a large segment of the American people.

OMAHA, Wednesday, May 10 -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, withstanding a hard 10-day campaign challenge from Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, emerged today as the winner of yesterday's Nebraska Presidential preference primary.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The worldwide network of earth stations is expected to exceed 80 antennas at 64 sites by the end of this year, Joseph V. Charyk, president of the Communications Satellite Corporation, said here today. He told about 100 stockholders at the annual meeting that 10 countries, including China, were expected to build 17 new antennas this year.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 9 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota coasted to an overwhelming victory over Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama tonight in West Virginia's Presidential preference primary.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The new flurry of enforcement actions by the Price Commission -- some involving price rollbacks -- does not mean any change in the Administration's desire for "a good year for profits," the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

MONTREAL, May 9 -- Several thousand workers walked off their jobs today to protest against one-year prison terms imposed yesterday on three union leaders who defied a back-to-work court order in a recent strike of public service workers in the province of Quebec.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -American military analysts say that the Soviet Union and China have a number of options in responding to the mining of the ports of North Vietnam.

PARIS, May 9 -- Following, in unofficial translation from the French, is the text of an official commentary made public today by the North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks here in reply to President Nixon's address last night:

If there is a Diogenes searching for an honest man in stockcar racing, one possible nominee is Marty Robbins, whose story is a fitting sequel to a study of cheating published here on Sunday. It seems Robbins discovered he was inadvertently cheating in Sunday's Winston 500 at Talladega, Ala., where he finished 18th.
NEW ORLEANS, May 9 (AP) -- The nation's crude oil producing capacity was reported today to have dropped to its lowest level in five years.

Uniroyal, Inc., announced yesterday that it would increase prices by an average of 4 per cent on a number of selected industrial product lines. Covered by the increase, which goes into effect May 15, are conveyor belting, sheet rubber, engineered rubber products and industrial hose.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew rejected today a gift bedspread from Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis of Maine, accusing the Democratic Governor of encouraging an antiwar demonstration that marred his recent visit to the state.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 -- C-130 transport planes flying at 8,000 feet dropped food and ammunition today to the besieged South Vietnamese troops in Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon.

PHUHOA, South Vietnam, May 9 -- The women and children of this dusty, sunbaked village stood anxiously by the road with bundles of their meager possessions today, waiting for the bus to Saigon and safety. North Vietnamese troops attacked Phuhoa last night and promised to return soon.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senate Democrats today passed by a vote of 29 to 14 a resolution "disapproving the escalation of the war in Vietnam."

Born a slave, Frederick Douglass raised himself to change the course of American history. Self-educated to such an extent that his fellow abolitionists worried that audiences would not believe he had ever been a slave, Douglass stunned America (and England) with his oratory.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 9 (UPI) -- Top-seeded Manuel Orantes of Spain dropped only one game today in routing Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., 6-0, 6-1, and advancing to the round of 16 in the $26,650 Belgian open tennis championships.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu tonight asked for emergency powers that would allow him to issue decrees subject to subsequent approval by the National Assembly.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 -- American military officers and South Vietnamese officials today approved President Nixon's decision to mine North Vietnamese harbors, but doubts were expressed that the step would force an early end to the enemy's offensive within South Vietnam.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 (AP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers voted unanimously today to allow quotations on any stock-exchange listed security to be displayed on its automatic quotation system for over-the-counter securities.

Your April 27 editorial on Senator McGovern puzzles me. On the one hand, McGovern's 52 per cent clear majority -- 30 percentage points ahead of Humphrey -- and his sweep of the Bay State's 102-member delegation is "far from conclusive" in Massachusetts.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office asked the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday to "forget about" its contempt case against radio station WBAI and WBAI's general manager, Edwin A. Goodman.

State welfare officials said yesterday that they were seeking a supplemental budget appropriation to add 25 more hearing officers to the present staff of 12 and to provide six supervisors to cope with an expected flood of appeals from relief recipients.

ALBANY, May 9 -- More and more the cricket-like sound of finger-poppings is heard in the Assembly as bills pass in a first show of votes, then members who see possible political damage quickly signal the clerk to put them down as No.

After dozens of birds mysteriously died at the University of Nebraska campus in Lincoln last fall, students accused the school's athletic department of killing them so they would not disturb football fans who gathered at the stadium each Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- The National Weather Service is setting up automateic alarm systems that it hopes will save lives in the flash floods that are a "chronic threat" in many parts of the Eastern United States.

The Ivy League presidents have rendered a great service to higher education in their joint statement of April 19 deploring renewed American bombing of North Vietnam and its civilian population. Making this forthright declaration obviously took tremendous courage.
PEKING, May 9 -- China charged today that United States ships and planes attacked Chinese freighters in North Vietnamese waters over the weekend.

Speculum Musicae (that's musical mirror in Latin) is the name of a young group of 20th-century music specialists that came into being last year. At Alice Tully Hall on Monday night the mirror was adjusted to give images of the recent past, most of the works being either by Igor Stravinsky or Stefan Wolpe, or dedicated to the memory of those composers.

The Air Force's Military Airlift Command announced yesterday it has awarded $131.5million in contracts to 17 commercial airlines for international passenger and cargo airlift estimated for the fiscal year 1973. This compares with the estimated 1972 fiscal-year contracts of about $350million.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 9 (UPI) -- Supreme Court Justice Byron R. White said today that the nation's courts were in deep trouble because of heavy case loads and he urged law schools to find ways of solving legal disputes out of court.

Management and labor in the East and Gulf Coast longshore industry decided yesterday to ask the Pay Board to reconsider its action rolling back a negotiated wage increase from 70 cents an hour to 55 cents.
Russell E. Train, chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, said last night that more efficient uses of oil, natural gas and coal should be found.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -Disappointment is frequently merely the backlash of expectation. I had gone to the Eisenhower Theater at Kennedy Center to see Richard Chamberlain play the title role in "Richard II," and I had gone expecting a great deal.
The nation's securities and commodities markets weakened yesterday in response to President Nixon's announcement of new military initiatives in North Vietnam.

Mark Monday night as yet another potentially historic date in the already symbolismheavy history of rock music. It saw the first rock concert ever at the Radio City Music Hall, a benefit program for the Environmental Policy Center.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches, scheduled to be completed yesterday, were disrupted by rain. The courses around the district of Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey were deemed unplayable with the exception of two.

Salvatore Albanese, 37 years old, who had been sought by the police for questioning in connection with the recent Mafia gang war, was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on probation violations.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that it had summoned a rocket specialist from the Chinese border and made him the new commander of the nation's strategic missile forces.

The Office of the dean of students at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn was occupied shortly after 9 A.M. yesterday by 20 members of the institute's Black Students Union who charged that the dean, Richard Streiter, was "not sensitive to the needs of black students." They demanded his dismissal.
Norton Simon, Inc., a consumer -products company, declared yesterday a two-for-one stock split and an initial 25cent annual cash dividend payable quarterly following the common-stock distribution.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -The Securities and Exchange Commission warned investment managers today that they must be prepared to prove they had a valid reason for placing securities transactions with brokers with wllom they are affiliated, if the affiliated brokers did not offer the best available price.
The New York Giants announced yesterday the shift of their preseason training camp o New Jersey from Long Island. The new camp will be at Monmouth College in West Long Branch.

They would have been a smash ticket anywhere in town, but Sarah Vaughan and Dizzy Gillespie -- who first worked together 30 years ago -- chose the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island for a joint appearance yesterday.

WESTON, Conn. -- A modest anniversary falls this spring. Exactly 25 years ago the Commission on Freedom of the Press, under the chairmanship of Robert M. Hutchins, issued a general report on mass communications entitled, "A Free and Responsible Press."

As Senator George McGovern becomes a more credible contender for the Presidency -especially if the Vietnam war drags -- Wall Street and the business community have begun to worry about his "populist" economic proposals.

Nothing more clearly indicates the double standard many otherwise intelligent people apply to the Vietnam war than the reaction to the sad news [April 26] that the Mylai residents who survived the Calley massacre and were rebuilding their lives with American aid have now been overrun and massacred by the Vietcong.
The commodities futures market for the most part proceeded cautiously yesterday following the President's military action in Vietnam. Trading in general was slow.

TRENTON, May 9 -- The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said today that air quality ratings from its statewide monitoring system would be issued daily to the state's communication media starting next Tuesday.

Concern over Vietnam developments sent stocks down yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The index fell 0.33 to 27.07. This decline was the biggest since Aug. 3, 1971, when the index dropped 0.35. Yesterday's volume totaled 5,945,835, up from 3,147,410 on Monday, a slow trading day.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 9 -- Fritz Peterson had another in his long-running series of dreams the other day.

A Queens housewife who faces possible deportation for failing to tell immigration authorities she had been convicted of torturing Nazi concentration camp prisoners said yesterday that at the time she considered her denials of her past "a truthful answer."

ALBANY, May 9 -- The modified "no fault" auto-insurance bill sought by Governor Rockefeller was defeated in the Senate late tonight after the opposition denounced it as designed more for the insurance industry than for the consumer.

ALBANY, May 9 -- The Senate approved the appropriation of $12-million today for "reforms and improvements" in the state prison system sought by Governor Rockefeller in the aftermath of the rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility last September.

SAN JOSE, Calif., May 9 -An airline ticket agent testified today at the murder-conspiracy trial of Angela Davis that she saw the defendant rushing to catch a plane shortly after the shootings Aug. 7, 1970, during an attempted breakout at the Marin County Courthouse.

Prof. Edward Early's analogy between American support of South Vietnam and the conduct of an intermeddler who persuades one of a pair of quarrelling spouses to disregard a reconciliation agreement (letter, May 1) is an example of a misconception commonly encountered in academic circles.

In 1967 Fernando Arrabal returned for a visit to Spain from his self-exile in Paris. After writing an obscene inscription in a book, he was arrested for blasphemy and calumny. Before he was acquitted, he spent 24 days in jail.

The National Kinney Corporation has agreed to acquire the Holmes Protection Services Corporation, which owns 83.4 per cent of the stock of Holmes Protection, Inc., it was reported to stockholders yesterday by Paul Milstein, president.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Selective Service System announced today that it would order about 9,000 young men with lottery number 1 through 35 to report to the Army in June.

LONDON, May 9 (Reuters) -Radio stations in Eastern Europe were unanimous today in condemning President Nixon's new moves in Vietnam, and several forecast that they would jeopardize the chances of success of his visit to the Soviet Union this month.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -Two incumbent City Commissioners, one of whom was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury on shakedown charges, won re-election tonight in a 34-candidate scramble for five posts.

An album containing the love letters of George Bernard Shaw to Miss Alice Lockett, a nurse, were sold at auction here yesterday for $4,250. The 19 letters, as often acerbic as tender in their expressions, were the items of chief interest in the largest public offering of Shaw material since the Archibald Henderson collection was sold in 1933.
PARIS, May 9 -- European gold, stock and currency markets reacted sharply today to President Nixon's decision to mine North Vietnamese ports.

Italy's Christian Democrats have managed to pull themselves together in crisis and hold their ground against strong challenges from left and right in the sixth Parliamentary election since the fall of Fascism. The unexpectedly strong showing by the Catholic party that has led every Government for 26 years helped contain within manageable bounds a surge toward the neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement.
Lerner Stores Corporation, the country's largest chain of women's apparel shops, said yesterday that its sales for April dropped 14.7 per cent to $30,224,504 from $35,452,694 in April 1971.

William T. Seawell, who took command of troubled Pan American World Airways six weeks ago, told shareholders yesterday that he could not predict when the airline would become profitable again. But he forecast that Pan Am would have a smaller loss this year than last year's deficit of $45.5million.
HANOI, North Vietnam, May 9 (Agence France-Presse) -- The loudspeakers of Hanoi spoke out at 7:50 A.M. today, warning the inhabitants that "enemy planes" were 32 miles to the southeast.

The General Accounting Office has warned Congress that sanitary conditions in the United States food industry "are deteriorating" and that thhe Food and Drug Administration has not been able to "provide the assurance of consumer protection required by the law."
It isn't the state of the hemline that's agitating designers presenting fall collections this week and retailers viewing them. It's whether women are going to bother wearing dresses at all.
McGraw-Hill, Inc., and Time Inc. announced yesterday that they had reached agreement with five minority groups that had challenged the sale of five of Time's TV stations to McGraw Hill.

The president of the Mortgage Bankers Association yesterday accused the Department of Housing and Urban Development of "hiding behind higher and higher mountains of rules and regulations, new certifications and endless paperwork."

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Federal Government will finance a new program that will ultimately develop comprehensive programs on statistics on criminal justice in all 50 states, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -President Nixon's newest tactics in Indochina derive from a recognition that three years of military and diplomatic maneuver against North Vietnam have failed.

BONN, May 9 -- A compromise between Chancellor Willy Brandt's governing coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats and the conservative Opposition to assume ratification of West Germany's 1970 treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland hit a snag tonight.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -United States District Judge Stephen J. Roth denied today a Justice Department motion seeking to intervene in the Detroit school integration case.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of the news conference held today by Henry A. Kissinger, the President's adviser on national security, in the White House. Mr. Kissinger's opening remarks are followed by questions and answers.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Department of Transportation said today that it had adopted new standards of highway safety for the buses that transport almost 20 million children to school.

Your April 10 editorial "Energy Crisis Ahead" is truly startling. First, in the interests of pressing your view that "frivolous energy consumption" should be stopped (i.e., some residential use; certainly not power to run presses to produce multi-hundred-page newspapers on Sundays) you abandon your traditional free-trade position and become concerned with "the political dangers" of increased reliance on fuel imports.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today that the Eli Lilly Company had broken the law by sending a misleading "Dear Doctor" letter defending its painkiller Darvon after a medical journal said the drug was little more effective -- but vastly more expensive -than aspirin.

TEL AVIV, May 9 -- About a dozen Israeli paratroops wearing the white overalls of El Al maintenance crews burst into a hijacked Belgian airliner parked at Lydda Airport this afternoon and rescued 90 passengers and 10 crewmen.
The summit meeting on Willie Mays began here yesterday, and Round One ended a few hours later with the San Francisco Giants and New York Mets statement over price.

LONDON, May 9 -- President Nixon's decision to mine ports and bomb rail lines in North Vietnam won little support in Europe today. Most comment, official and unofficial, expressed regret that he had chosen to open a new phase of military action in the war.

A year ago Dick Tidrow was pitching for Reno in the California League. He appeared in just seven games and finished the season with four victories and no defeats. Last night the 25-year-old, right - handed rookie pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 2-1 victory over Kansas City.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- Secretary General Waldheim said today that "the time has now come when the full machinery of the United Nations should be used" to end the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -The Nixon Administration acknowledged today that the President's decision to seal off North Vietnam's harbors had caused a serious problem for Soviet policy-makers and endangered the course of Soviet-American relations, but said it still hoped that Mr. Nixon could go ahead with his trip to Moscow, as planned, 13 days from now.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said in response to questions today that after President Nixon's speech last night the White House switchboard was jammed by incoming calls "to a greater degree than I can recall."

WASHINGTON, May 9 -Henry A. Kissinger today described the peace proposal outlined by President Nixon last night as a modification of previous American offers and said it would "leave the determination of Vietnam's political future to the Vietnamese."

The Violoncello Society gave its first. Piatigorsky Artist Award to Douglas Davis, in 1961 when he was 20 years old. The organization apparently still thinks highly of him, because it chose him to give a program in Town Hall on Monday night commemorating the 30th anniversary of Emanuel Feuermann's death.
ROME, May 9 -- Final returns for the parliamentary elections held Sunday and yesterday announced this afternoon, appeared to perpetuate the unstable pattern of Italy's democracy.

WASHINGTON, May (AP) -- The chairman of a stockbrokers' association testified today that little hope existed for solving massive, obstructive paperwork problems unless securities transfers could be coordinated.
LONDON, May 9 -- Company profits are on the upswing in Britain, with three out of four companies reporting better performances for their most recent accounting periods.
DETROIT, May 9 -- Gov. George C. Wallace's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination will include a write-in campaign in the California primary next month.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the police had the volatile situation created by the growing number of youth gangs "well in hand" and that they would take a "no nonsense" attitude toward gang members who carried guns or indulged in violence.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- An investigator for a House committee said today there was a link between the biggest national sports concessionaire and what he called a Mafiacontrolled race track near Detroit.

BOSTON, May 9 -- The Stanley Cup that the Boston Bruins won in today's newspapers, on the radio, and over the television was a bit more elusive to capture on Boston Garden ice tonight.
LOS ANGELES, May 9 (UPI) -- A lawyer here is suing Ralph Nader for allegedly concealing facts, withholding funds and engaging in misrepresentations to save money.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The House passed today an anti-secrecy bill aimed at reforming the $75-million-a-year operations of influential Government advisory committees.

PARIS, May 9 -- The basic and thus far unnegotiable demand of the North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegations here -- that President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam leave office -- remains at the center of the deadlock in private and public sessions of the Paris talks.

The first international Festival of Women's Films will be held June 5th through June 21 at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, near 12th Street. The schedule is composed of 13 features, 4 documentary features and 13 programs of short subjects.

A detective and 15 gamblers were indicted and 12 policemen were suspended yesterday in connection with a corruption investigation that has already led to the indictment of 24 other policemen and the suicide of a police lieutenant.
Civil Court Judge Bernard Klieger won acquittal in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of perjury and conspiracy involving political contributions in the 1965 mayoral campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Even though he began to move nearly a week ago toward his decision to mine the harbors of North Vietnam, President Nixon did not give the final signal to the military to execute the plan until nearly 2 P.M. yesterday -seven hours before his speech to the nation and minutes after a final, sober private talk with the two men who were closest to him during his deliberations.

BOSTON, May 9 -- Of course, Bobby Rousseau had read about the preparations for the Bruins' celebration, and he'd seen the Bruin poster, "1972 Champions," which someone had placed in the Ranger locker room.
In a civil complaint that United States attorneys described as "broad and unusual," the Federal Government yesterday charged Westchester County with being a major polluter of the Hudson River.

NEW DELHI, May 9 -- The meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan, tentatively scheduled for late this month or early next, will have to be postponed at least until late June, informed sources said today.

With mass marches, windowsmashing sprees, silent vigils and traffic-blocking sit-ins, antiwar protesters by the thousands took to the streets yesterday in response to President Nixon's decision to mine North Vietnamese ports.
ALBANY, May 9 -- After nearly six arduous hours of speeches, the Assembly voted tonight, 79 to 68, to repeal the liberalized abortion law it barely passed in agonizing debate two years ago.

The New York Knicks can't really think about next season until they know more about the condition of Willis Reed, who has an appointment with a specialist in Oklahoma City on May 22, but a few final words about this season are definitely in order.

Kathleen Kinander, the soprano who made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, may very well have grown up singing. Her father, Robert Kinander, is a voice teacher and she studies with him.

BALTIMORE, May 10 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota campaigned through the fish stalls and vegetable stands of the Lexington Market here today, then flew to New York for secret meetings with past and potential financial backers.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 6 -- Davey, a 16-year-old milkman, stands on bleak Caslereagh Road each evening. "I don't trust the Catholics," he said. "I don't like them, never have and never will. That's why I'm a Tartan."

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 10 -- Greg Ducatte grew up in Plattsburgh, N. Y., becoming a high school quarterback good enough to attract numerous college football recruiters. Like any other premier player he hoped to do well also on a successful college team.

The Gimbels New York division of Gimbels Brothers, Inc., will open its first furniture clearance center this morning in Bergen County, N.J. It will be the first of a number of similar retail home furnishing units presently under consideration, according to Paul A. Salomone, president of Gimbels New York.
PASADENA, Calif., May 10 (AP) -- Scientists who studied closeup photographs of Mars reported today the discovery of a 200-mile-wide permanent ice cap at the planet's south pole.

Romulo Betancourt, the former President of Venezuela, ended eight years of voluntary exile in Europe and headed home. The 63-year-old Mr. Betancourt, who relinquished the presidency in 1964, left Bern, Switzerland, for Genoa, by car, and planned to board a ship there for Latin America.

The Seuffert Band piped rousing rhythms on the promenade of the New York Public Library's main branch yesterday. A high school brass ensemble filled the air with music in front of Borough Hall in Brooklyn.
Following are excerpts from a news conference by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird at the Pentagon yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

The National Broadcasting Company announced major changes yesterday in the television network's programing and news management, effective June 1. The changes, designed to bring forward younger men in the network hierarchy, were announced here by Don Durgin, president of N.B.C.-TV.

EAST HADDAM, Conn. -An accounting of the continuing effort to restore the Connecticut River's oncemagnificent runs of anadromous fish was given to members and guests at the 20th annual meeting of the Connecticut River Watershed Council last weekend.
Thomas A. Martin has been elected president of the Anchor Corporation, succeeding Edward B. Burr, who was named vice chairman.

The City Housing Authority has come under a Federal investigation -- sought by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York -- on the way it has been selecting tenants for the Seward Park Extension project on the Lower East Side.

Instead of purchasing all five of the television stations licensed to Time-Life Inc., McGraw-Hill, Inc., will be acquiring only four. The fifth, a very high frequency (VHF) Station in Grand Rapids, Mich., will be retained by Time-Life.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 10 -In drastic efforts to cut costs, many public school districts on Long Island are reducing teaching and administrative staffs, increasing class sizes, eliminating special programs and, in a few cases, closing elementary schools.

ALBANY, May 10 -- Following is the Senate roll-call vote in which a "no-fault" auto insurance bill sponsored by Senator Bernard G. Gordon was defeated last night by a vote of 33 to 22 and a rival bill sponsored by Senator Thomas Laverne was approved, 44 to 13.
Coach Lou Carneseeca of the Nets was obviously delighted, as he has been many times in the past month, following his team's 117-115 triumph over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night in Indianapolis.

James A. Farrell Jr., a member of the Westminster Kennel Club since 1944, provided some backstage anecdotes from his long association with the organization at yesterday's luncheon of the Dog Fanciers Club in the McAlpin Hotel.

YONKERS, May 10 -- John Simpson Jr. has had only two driving assignments at the current Yonkers Raceway meeting and he finished out of the money both times.

Those lammisters of yesteryear, the Dodgers and the Giants, follow each other into Shea Stadium for the next few days and they always create excitement in our village whenever they return. If there is an extra smidgeon of excitement right now, it has been caused by the possibility that the Giants might be ready to hand back to New York fans their one-time idol, Willie Mays.

The Vera Institute of Justice yesterday released the full details of its controversial proposal for an experiment in short-term heroin maintenance for addicts who have failed on methadone maintenance.

A questioner at Henry Kissinger's news conference recalled that, for ten years and through three Administrations, mining the North Vietnamese harbors had been considered to pose an unacceptable risk of confrontation with the Soviet Union. "Can you tell us what has changed to make that risk now acceptable?" he asked.

Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks grew by $450-million in April -- a $280million inflow of new deposits plus $170-million of interest payments, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

Seven awards for excellence in different fields of journalism were bestowed last night by the Deadline Club, the New York professional chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, the national journalism society, at the Americana Hotel.
Bargain hunters dominated trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. As a result, the index closed at 27.20, up 0.13 in slow volume.

DUBLIN, May 10 -- The Irish voted in large numbers today to determine whether they will go it alone in impoverished independence or take a chance on a more prosperous future as members of the enlarged European Economic Community.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- California delegates now think they can crown their party's nominee for President in a winner-take-all-271-delegates primary four weeks hence, and in tones of disbelief they are saying that Senator George McGovern is becoming the front-runner in the race.

The Long Island Lighting Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (S.E.C.) 2,022,000 common shares in connection with a rights offering whereby shareholders may subscribe to one common share for each ten shares held of record May 31.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -The House of Representatives began debate today on legislation that would increase the Federal minimum wage for most nonagricultural workers from $1.60 to $2 an hour.
The chief architect of a heroin-maintenance program unveiled yesterday performed one of his typically delicate catalytic missions over dinner at the Harvard Club one night last summer.
Five poet friends of John Berryman, who died Jan. 7, gathered Tuesday evening at the Donnell Library to read from his work and to reminisce a little about the man.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu imposed martial law on South Vietnam tonight.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 10 -- William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, charged today that unrestricted membership on the nation's stock exchanges by institutions would impair the fairness of the stock market.

NEW CITY, N. Y., May 10 -- The driver of the school bus that collided with a freight train last March 24 in nearby Congers, killing five Nyack High School students, was indicted here today on five counts of criminally negligent homicide.

The New York City Ballet presented its usual if schematic one-act version of "Swan Lake" Tuesday night for the first time this season at the State Theater. This was also the first time that Melissa Hayden and Peter Martins had appeared together as the principals, Odette and Siegfried.

Bond prices staged a general, though restrained, advance yesterday that left most interest rates at about the levels that prevailed before President Nixon announced his new Vietnam strategy Monday night.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that two management consulting firms had recommended that the sales charges on mutual funds and variable annuities be based, in part, on the costs that an investor would incur if he tried to purchase his own diversified portfolio of stocks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 11 -- United States planes bombed targets in Hanoi and Haiphong yesterday and also struck at the rail lines leading from China in a continued effort to seal off North Vietnam from its sources of military supplies.
Pepsi-Cola, an advertiser in the $30-million class, confirmed yesterday that it was close to a new campaign that could replace "You've got a lot to live and Pepsi's got a lot to give."

A rift has developed between the head of New York Typographical Local 6 and the union's international president over the local's proposed extension of The Morning Telegraph strike to The Daily Racing Form, which is published in New Jersey.

With bigotry a source of good-humored acceptance -- witness the Archie Bunker show -- there should be little wonder that Gov. George Wallace is sweeping the country in his bid for the Presidential nomination. But what an indictment these not altogether unrelated events are!

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that it would appeal the decision last week by Judge Constance Baker Motley in Federal District Court here upholding the Teleprompter Corporation's transmission of C.B.S. shows and movies to its cable TV subscribers without payment of copyright.

OMAHA, May 10 -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota won a solid victory yesterday in Nebraska's Presidential preference primary, but his chief rival, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, held a narrow and uncertain lead today in delegate strength in the state.

ROME, May 10 -- A Vatican weekly said today that the Roman Catholic Church in the United States was being shaken by a "tremendous earthquake" and seemed on the verge of collapse, but it voiced the hope that it would be saved by its "silent majority."

The presidents of 11 major airlines sent the Nixon Administration an urgent message yesterday urging large additions to Federal forces assigned to airports to prevent hijacking and sabotage of aircraft.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Retails sales slipped back in April from the record March level but remained higher than any month prior to March, the Commerce Department reported today.
HONG KONG, May 11 -- China today branded President Nixon's decision to mine North Vietnam harbors as a "dangerous move" and a "flagrant provocation against the people of Vietnam and the world over."

The City Council voted 29 to 7 yesterday to ask the state for permission to pay $400,000 to consultants for advice on investing money for the city's pension-fund investments.

Genesco, Inc., the nation's largest apparel producer and retailer, yesterday reported sharply reduced earnings for the third quarter of its fiscal year and also announced a reshuffling of some top management responsibilities.
The Paper Moon is a small shop, but it does have a large selection of basketware -- American Indian baskets, baskets from Ethiopia, Upper Volta, Hungary, Poland, Italy, Ireland and Colombia.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 10 -- Although the Yankees didn't score any runs against Jim Perry and Wayne Granger tonight, their hitting nevertheless provided one of only two interesting aspects of Minnesota's 2-0 victory.

Of all the old fairy-tale ballets, "The Sleeping Beauty" is probably the least mysterious but the most satisfying. It is a myth about providence and virginity deriving from a time when virginity was not a myth and providence a possibility.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 -- Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, arrived in Damascus today on a four-day visit for talks with Syria's military leaders and an inspection of Syrian defenses on the front with Israel.

PARIS, May 10 -- The dollar came under selling pressure again today, but the recent spectacular advance in gold was halted as nervousness over intensification of hostilities in Vietnam continued to dominate sentiment in the European market centers.

PARIS, May l0 -- For the first and probably last time, all but one of the paintings by Georges de La Tour known to date have been brought together at the Musee de l'Orangerie in Paris. Thirty one originals, plus 31 canvases labeled as "copies," make up the year's most important exhibition.
Paul Zindel, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, has written a new comedy, "The Secret Affairs of Mildred Wild," which will star Maureen Stapleton on Broadway in November.

The militance of the Federal Trade Commission has awakened a militance in the Television Bureau of Advertising, for 16 years the silent selling service of the medium.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- One of the witnesses who did testify at the House crime bearings today was Lester Smith, former vice president of Hazel Park. He said he had been removed from his $19,000 post after he had testified for the Government in the trial of Zerilli and Bellanca.
The president of a New York export-import concern, John P. Bauer, pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of having delivered a false report about egg futures to news outlets.

A Government survey released yesterday reported an increase of 57,000 jobs last March in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area, but the increase was said to be below the season expectation for the month.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- The President will have an opportunity in Moscow, if he goes, to break through the impasse in Soviet-American trade relations, but to do so would require a high degree of imagination and statesmanship.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 -- W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, testified before a Federal grand jury today about the origin and purpose of a special union fund that the Government says is connected with the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 10 (UPI) -- Capt. Charles Conrad Jr., the astronaut, bailed out of a damaged trainer jet over an Air Force base in central Texas tonight and parachuted to safety within 100 yards of the base operation office.
A woman and her 9-year-old son were stabbed to death last night in their Lower East Side apartment, the police said. The multiple murders were discovered and reported by the woman's 8-year-old son.

World No. 11 sugar futures closed 13 to 26 points lower yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Sales totaled 3,551 contracts.

State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger proposed yesterday that the city be required to pay welfare recipients' rents and security deposits directly to landlords, instead of giving rent checks to the clients.

ALBANY, May 10 -- By a vote of 30 to 27 the Senate gave final legislative approval to a bill repealing New York's two-year-old liberalized abortion law and reinstating the old statute permitting abortions only to save the life of the woman.

Its sound and style have remained so consistently the same over those years that Mr. Shearing even ventures a feeble joke about still having the original personnel (which he does not).

PARIS, May 12 -- Le Duc Tho, a leading member of the North Vietnamese politburo, today rejected President Nixon's latest proposal for a settlement in Vietnam, but said that he would stay on in Paris and was ready for serious negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -House-Senate conferees have decided to reject an appropriation of $320-million for money due from the United States to the World Bank but have pledged that this and two other installments of the same size will be approved later.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -Equipment that was patented this week automatically spots a truck that is too noisy, records the sound and photographs the vehicle and its front license plate. The apparatus was invented at C.B.S. Laboratories, Stamford, Conn., for authori ties to use in enforcing any state or local regulations limiting vehicle noise.

Heat and humidity are not far off, and many city families are already busily planning their escape. Children are ticking off the weeks until vacation time and the flight to camp or countryside. For countless city youngsters, however, the only prospect of relief is the spray of the uncapped hydrant and the sun-softened asphalt of streets and crowded playgrounds. Rural America for them will remain a picture on the television screen.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 13 -- It was a medical researcher's wife -- a historian, not a physician -- who made the suggestion that led Air Force doctors to devise a radical new experimental technique to treat patients dying from liver coma, a condition that kills thousands of Americans every year.

The tone and content of your May 6 editorial "Politics and F.B.I." suggest the conclusion that any appointee who enjoyed the personal trust and confidence of the President would be prima facie suspect in the eyes of The Times, regardless of his qualifications.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- If there is any redeeming quality about this goofy nuclear age, it is that Moscow and Washington seem to know when to hold back when one of them risks a major collision with the other. They, both go crazy from time to time, but not together.

THE phone rings. A friend's voice tells you, "Miriam died, you know." You think back. You're a young actor, arrogant and insecure, confident and afraid. President Nixon's decision to mine the harbors and coastline of North Vietnam and expand the bombing of the North follows a significant build-up of United States air strength in Southeast Asia, renewed bombing of military targets in the North and increased doubts that the South Vietnamese can assume the burden of combat in the South.

SAIGON. AMONG the ever-increasing scores of graves in Mac Dinh Chi cemetery, the oldest and most prestigious one in Saigon, now spread across several blocks near the American Embassy in the downtown area, are two unmarked slabs of marble around which miscellaneous mourners occasionally place wreaths or scatter a few flowers.

Soon after hearing that Ernest Hemingway had killed himself -- it was a Sunday, July 2, 1961 -- a number of excited people got in touch with Philip Young, a professor of English at Penn State University. He wryly describes their more or less common message ("you called it, Young!") as belonging to "a rare species of the genus Congratulation."

About 20 million American school children ride to class in 256,000 school buses every day. There have been frequent charges that many of the buses are unsafe, and the drivers ill-trained. The response has been minimal. Then, seven weeks ago, a school bus collided with a freight train in New York's Rockland County.
NEW MILFORD -- When an accident victim here is surprised by being helped by a teen-aged ambulance corpsman, he shouldn't be.

Ara Parseghian, one of college football's most successful coaches, will receive the first champions award of the New York County Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society for his efforts against the crippling neurological disease.

WHITEHOUSE -- Why would the successful industrial relations and personnel director of a multi-million-dollar Fifth Avenue, New York, beauty-aids concern suddenly quit her job to buy and operate an antiques emporium and miniature golf course in this rural Hunterdon County community where horses outnumber people?

The well-reasoned May 1 article of your editorial writer Robert Bendiner, "A Quota by Any Other Name . . .," deserves to be read for the implications far and beyond the immediate subject matter. Although it deals primarily with the requirement that the respective state delegations to the Democratic National Convention reflect their state populations in terms of minority groups, women and young people, it points out clearly the kind of society we are becoming.

CHICAGO, May, 13 (UPI) -- The Democratic Party's Credentials Committee has agreed to hold hearings on challenges to the Chicago delegation that Mayor Richard J. Daley plans to lead at the party's national convention.

HACKENSACK -- A young woman from a midwestern city who recently moved to Fair Lawn to teach at Bergen County Community College one mile away in Paramus did not have a car, and had to use public buses.
Women do have a more difficult time than men obtaining credit, if irate letters received by the National Commission on Consumer Finance are any indication.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 -- Two well-known St. Louis residents and an antiwar veterans group have taken legal action aimed to force the United States to set a date for withdrawing all military forces from Indochina.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 14 -- A teen-age girl was shot dead here tonight, the ninth person killed in the worst weekend of shooting, bombing and arson in Belfast in the last nine months.

Teresa Rutkowska, a Polish pianist who teaches at the Warsaw Conservatory, made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon playing a program of music by Chopin. It included the Fantasie-Impromptu in C sharp minor, Polonaise in F sharp minor and groups of Mazurkas, Waltzes and Preludes in addition to other works.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 13 -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson has developed permanent congestive heart failure as a complication of a recent attack, according to his physician.

Some of the nation's religious leaders have voiced grave concern over President Nixon's war policy in Southeast Asia and the bombing of North Vietnam.

In a far-fetched soap opera cheered by 35,505 fans in Shea Stadium, Willie Mays not only made his playing debut as a member of the Mets yesterday but also hit a fifth-inning home run that defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-4.
A large number of bridge players who travel abroad seek out opportunities to play, thus obtaining not only recreation but also opportunities for social contacts.

HAVANA, May 14 (Reuters) -- Cubans can now buy more food and consumer goods than at any time in the past few years as the Government moves to absorb excess money in circulation and create more incentive.

A Times front-page story on April 17 announced the "critical re-examination of Lincoln Center's performing arts program for young people." The center's education division discovered that young people are reluctant and infrequent visitors to their great edifice. To get this information, the theater paid over $79,000 for a study which might have been obtained more easily and inexpensively from a box-office clerk.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have made substantial progress toward a comprehensive trade agreement, the first between the two countries since the early years of the cold war, senior Administration officials said today.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 14 -- A five-pound Pomeranian, Ch. Sheeba's Little Dragonfly, the smallest dog in the final at the Windham County Kennel Club show, scored the big-best victory of his career today when he was named best in a field of 1,523 at Recreation Park today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The Democratic Platform Committee starts its work tomorrow, with most of its members not chosen and with a deadline that would give convention delegates a chance to study the party platform thoroughly before adopting it.

BRUSSELS, May 14 -- The outlook for a solid rally on the Eurobond market is continuing to improve with new issues in all sectors favorably received and prices on the secondary market firm despite the money and stock market jitters following President Nixon's latest moves in Vietnam.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 14 -- The sting of defeat has eased and the "Crush India" billboards, hastily erected during the two-week war last December, are slowly coming down. The economy is still largely stagnant, but workers are once again laying bricks on unfinished buildings, exercising polo ponies and planting spring flowers.

King Hussein of Jordan has recently come out with a proposal for the solution of the Palestinian "problem." This is one of many proposals put forward by deeply or remotely involved parties, and it remains striking that so far no proposal has been made public by the party most concerned -- the Palestinian Arabs.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Seven years after the White House first called on Federal installations across the country to stop polluting, Federal officials feel that the corrective program is within sight of its goal.

Dr. Richard Schueller, a former Austrian statesman and educator, died yesterday in Washington at the age of 101. He lived in Washington, having moved there from New York three years ago.

Chris Chambliss's short baseball career has been wrapped in success stories to which he added another chapter yesterday.

The State Environmental Conservation Department will propose state restrictions on gasoline lead content in the New York City area that would be more stringent than the proposed Federal guidelines, according to Commissioner Henry L. Diamond. The Commissioner said yesterday that levels of airborne lead in the New York area were regularly "so high as to pose a risk to public health."

RYE, N. Y., May 14 -- A couple of Comet Class boatbuilders from Westmont, N. J., went to the head of the Star Class today, defeating 37 other skippers in an Olympic qualifying regatta at the American Yacht Club.

DETROIT, May 14 -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota joined Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, his main rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, today in wavering on the question of busing children to achieve a racial balance in the public schools.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 -- Mickey Mouse, the 44-year-old superstar whose name was the password for D-Day in World War II, and his Disney cohort reached new heights of respectability today at Sotheby Parke-Bernet auction house in Los Angeles when 170 lots of Disney memorabilia brought almost $15,000 from collectors.

ATHENS, May 14 -- The general in charge of Greece's military forces welcomed today plans for permanent "home ports" for American warships near Athens, and dismissed suggestions that the presence of United States Navy families here might raise social problems.

The New Films by New Filmmakers program that opened Friday night at the Film Forum features the work of Curt McDowell, a San Franciscan, whose "Wieners Buns Musical" and "Pornogra Follies" dominate the program. As the titles suggest, Mr. McDowell belongs to the entertainment rather than the exploration-of-inner, reality wing of independent cinema production. But as the titles may also suggest, he offers entertainment of a somewhat unusual order.
DETROIT, May 14 -- Michigan's Democratic party made an 11th-hour effort this weekend to block a victory for Gov. George C. Wallace in the state's Presidential primary Tuesday.

Three players tied for first place as the 21st annual national chess tournament ended last night at the Group Health Insurance, Inc., building, 230 West 41st Street. PEKING, May 14 (Agence France-Presse) -- Premier Chou En-lai today described the mining of North Vietnam's ports as a serious step-up of the war by the United States.

The Princeton athletes, six of them freshmen, upset Radcliffe College, to whom they had lost a previous race by four seconds, in winning by a little under a boat length.

The years go by but Ella Fitzgerald's voice continues to be a remarkable instrument for projecting a warm, gentle interpretation of a pop ballad, filled with subtle colors and accents. DETROIT, May 14 -- Hubert H. Humphrey has been saying for months that none of the Democratic Presidential candidates stand to win a first-ballot nomination.
