WARSAW, May 14 -- American scientists are preparing to give Poland a big gift to mark the celebration next year of the 500th anniversary of the birth of Nicolaus Copernicus. It is a $1,000,000 astronomical research center.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Securities Investor Protection Corporation warned today that it is going to be some time before it can develop the most efficient possible liquidation procedures for failed brokerage firms, before it can recommend detailed new rules for preventing such failures and before it can move to a system of variable insurance assessments for different types of brokers.

DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d, board chairman of the Ford Motor Company, today labeled as "completely false" charges by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, that Ford had suppressed poor test results of a General Motors car, the Chevrolet Corvair.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Administration officials said today that Soviet and other vessels in Haiphong harbor were "completing their unloading" -- apparently without molestation by United States aircraft or warships in the area.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Britain's railroads remained shut down by their Government today while lawyers argued whether 300,000 workers should be asked to vote on accepting a pay offer.
The United States Olympic soccer team beat Jamaica, 2-1, yesterday to gain a berth in the Olympic Games in Munich for the first time since 1956.

HUE, South Vietnam, May 14 -- Government troops moved out from two points southwest of Hue today and by nightfall had advanced to within half a mile of Fire Base Bastogne, which fell to the enemy more than two weeks ago.

Dance Uptown presented Program II of its 10th annual series Saturday night in and around the Minor Latham Playhouse on the Barnard College Campus. Dan Blocker was one of those actors whose career became inextricably wound with that of the character he was known for playing. Unser, who won the 500 in 1968, ran 17.244 m.p.h. faster than the previous qualifying record of 178.696, set last year by Peter Revson.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, May 15 (Reuters) -- About 100,000 students, workers and civil servants marched on the Presidential Palace here today, demanding the release of student leaders arrested in three days of violence that has resulted in at least 25 deaths.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Shortly after Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was shot today, President Nixon ordered Secret Service protection for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn and Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Immediately after hearing of the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace, President Nixon today called Mrs. Wallace at her husband's bedside and told her that she had the hopes and prayers of himself and Mrs. Nixon for the Governor's recovery.
NAHA, Okinawa, May 15 -- Price mark-ups and conversion of the currency from dollars to yen inaugurated Okinawa's new status as a Japanese prefecture today.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 15 -- Within two or three months, someone will "wave the magic wand" and Ecuador will be transformed from a banana economy into the second biggest petroleum producer in Latin America.

DETROIT, May 15 -- The spring car-sales boom continued in the first third of May with the four auto manufacturers reporting 254,010 deliveries of United States models, up from 217,619 the year before.

The New York Stock Exchange's Central Certificate Service yesterday announced jointly with the State Street Bank and Trust Company of Boston that $170-million worth of shares held by the bank in custody for a mutual fund were being placed in the stock depository.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The young white man arrested as a suspect today in the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace is a 21-year-old resident of Milwaukee who pasted Wallace bumper stickers on his car and his apartment door and was exuberantly cheering the Democratic Presidential candidate only moments before the shots rang out.

Scattered antiwar protests in college towns and elsewhere yesterday brought group arrests in Princeton, N.J., and Lebanon and Portsmouth, N.H., and a 15-minute sit-in on the West Side Highway here during rush-hour traffic.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers, his voice rising in anger, today defended the mining of North Vietnam's harbors and said that if the Johnson Administration had taken the step earlier, the war might have ended long ago.

PARIS, May 15 -- A group of Americans in France protested today the appointment of Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson as defense attache at the United States Embassy in Paris.

TRENTON, May 15 -- A $145-million package of increased taxes, including an immediate increase of 5 cents a pack on cigarettes and a 1-cent-a-gallon increase in gasoline, received final legislative approval today in the State Senate.

The director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism appealed here yesterday to the liquor industry for help in combating alcoholism. Dr. Morris E. Chafetz asked for aid in promoting the fundamentals of "the responsible use" of alcohol, the avoidance of drunkenness and the elimination of the use of alcohol as a problem-solver.

OTTAWA, May 15 (Canadian Press) -- Canada had a curent account deficit of $532-million in its dealings with other countries for the first three months of this year, Statistics Canada reported today. There was a $78-million surplus in the first quarter of last year.
MATSU, May 15 (AP) -- The landing ship lay nosed into the sand, her bow doors gaping like the jaws of a beached whale, as Chinese Nationalist soldiers trooped aboard.

The St. Joe Minerals Corporation, the nation's leading producer of lead, said yesterday it was entering the oil and gas field through the proposed acquisition of 93.6 per cent of the outstanding stock of CanDel Ohio, Ltd., a Canadian subsidiary of the Sohio Petroleum Company.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) -- A House subcommittee battling secrecy in government apologetically told a witness today it would have to go into secret session to hear his testimony because the State Department had designated it "classified."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15 -- The United States turned over its huge Camranh Bay air base to the South Vietnamese today.

FIRE BASE ANDO, South Vietnam, May 15 -- Allied officers at this artillery base eight miles west of Hue pointed this afternoon to a ragged strip of churned orange clay six miles to the south where artillery shells were exploding.

A suspended Department of Social Services caseworker was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing $42,000 from the city in three months through the preparation and issuance of fraudulent relief checks. He is alleged to have used part of the money to buy a $10,000 Cadillac for himself and a $2,500 Ford for his girlfriend.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -- The International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union accepted today a Pay Board cutback in its new wage rates, ending a threat that the West Coast dock strike would be renewed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15 -- Dr. Matina Souretia Homer, a psychologist best known for her investigations of why women avoid success, was named president of Radcliffe College today at 32 years of age.
MENLO PARK, Calif., May 15 (AP) -- A pipe bomb ripped a building housing the company that manufactures non-lethal police "stun guns" used in riot control, the police reported today.

DALLAS, May 15 -- Increased spending among consumers reflecting restored confidence in the economy produced record sales and income for the first quarter of 1972, the chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., Gordon M. Metcalf, said today at the company's annual meeting.

GROSSE POINTE PARK, Mich., May 15 -- The Democratic Presidential primary campaign in Michigan ended tonight, overshadowed by the shooting this afternoon of Gov. George C. Wallace in Laurel, Md.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today bills that would liberalize the G.I. insurance program and extend full-time coverage to National Guard and military reserve members.

CAIRO, May 15 (UPI) -- President Anwar el-Sadat conferred again today with the Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, whose second visit in four months was believed to be linked with supplies of new weapons to the Egyptians.

PARIS, May 15 (Reuters) -- A French secretary of state, Phillipe Dechartre, found by a court to have been involved in a building scandal resigned from the Government today. Informed sources believe that President Pompidou had intervened personally to persuade Mr. Dechartre to resign.

Martin Berinbaum, trumpet and friends were on hand at Carnegie Recial Hall Sunday night for their third annual session of mostly baroque music-making. Your May 5 editorial "Aiding Church Schools" again points out the two vital arguments that are the heart of the issue of aid to parochial schools. While the separation of church and state must be maintained, a system of nonpublic schools must also be maintained to prevent a state-imposed monopoly.

A former supervising agent of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics has sued the author of "The French Connection" and the producer and distributor of the film version for $1-nliilion, charging invasion of privacy and defamation of character.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Many conventional intercity train fares in the Eastern United States will drop between 10 and 25 per cent soon, but those in the West and on the New York - Washington Metroliners will rise about 10 per cent, Amtrak announced today.

Chou Croute, the 4-year-old daughter of Lt. Stevens who has been visiting the winner's circle at an assortment of tracks for the last year as if it were home, scored her 10th straight victory yesterday as thoroughbred racing made its 1972 debut at Belmont Park.

Two major events make this charity bridge week in New York. The Alvin Landy Memorial game, honoring one of the great figures in bridge history, will be played tonight at 14 clubs in New York City and Long Island. And a two-session Swiss team championship will be played Sunday at the New York Hilton, sponsored jointly by the Greater New York Bridge Association and the American Bridge Association's Metropolitan Bridge Unit.

POMONA, N. Y., May 16 -- Summit House is a nine-month-old therapeutic community for the young drug addicts of Rockland County. Its spotless rooms are bright and sunny. It has color television and stereo and acres of grounds. Its residents proclaim its success with the fervor of the saved.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The United States balance of international payments, by two of the four measures used, showed a marked improvement in the first quarter of this year but remained in substantial deficit, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Federal agents and the local police were investigating today the possibility that the 21-year-old suspect arrested yesterday in the shooting of George C. Wallace had stalked the Alabama Governor for at least several days.

Building-trades unions representing 255,000 workers in the metropolitan area are seeking higher wages and shorter contracts in critical negotiations that are expected to reach a climax by the time current contracts expire on June 30.
The sea is the most persistently awesome primal force in nature: Its storms, its deeps, its tides and swells are a constant reminder of the overriding power that submerges man in time.

GENEVA, May 16 -- Rene Maheu, the Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, has been rebuked by an international administrative tribunal for refusing to renew the contract of a Czechoslovak member of the agency's staff.
Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, was honored last evening at a testimonial dinner at the New York Hilton Hotel by the Bill of Rights Foundation.

DENVER, May 16 -- With a sweep of precinct caucus meetings in Colorado and Utah, Senator George McGovern seemed assured today of the lion's share of the 55 delegate votes of the two states at the Democratic National Convention.

Mrs. Archie Bunker, better known as Edith, is probably America's most famous housewife. She is also the antithesis of women's liberation, a slow-witted, oppressed "dingbat" who lives in a working class neighborhood in Queens.

The National Institutes of Health has largely given up hope of finding a vaccine against the common cold.

I take it from your story of April 18 and from other developments that the National Park Service as we have known it is doomed to virtual extinction and that we might as well from now on forget the basic law which established our National Park System.
A Treasury Department official said yesterday that "the tide is turning" in the fight against cargo thefts in international commerce.

As the military debacle accelerates in Vietnam, desperate elements among the top military brass intensify their efforts to convince Americans that the war could have been "won" were it not for the "defeatist" influences of an assortment of "unpatriotic" activists. This is the Pentagon's equivalent of the "stab-in-the-back" myth so artfully manipulated by the German General Staff to the ultimate advantage of German fascism.
A Police Department artist's sketch of a man wanted for the slaying last Saturday of the wife of a Brooklyn textile executive was circulated yesterday.
Meyer Drucker, 54-year-old director of mediation for the State Mediation Board, has resigned and joined the law firm of Howard F. Cerny, 345 Park Avenue, with offices in Washington and London.

RALEIGH, N. C., May 16 -- Senator B. Everett Jordan formally called today for a runoff Democratic primary June 3 against Representative Nick Galifianakis, who came within 1 per cent of a majority in the first primary May 6.

Once last year, some students from the all-girl Walton High School went to their nearby Bronx neighbor, the all-boy DeWitt Clinton High School, and tried to get the Clinton boys to desert their classes and join them in a walkout over a now-forgotten issue.

SILVER SPRING, Md., May 16 -- Doctors caring for Gov. George C. Wallace said today that he would need further surgery to remove from his back a bullet that is apparently causing paralysis of his legs.
Five men were arrested here and two were arrested in Paris yesterday as international narcotics agents blocked an attempt to smuggle $50-million worth of heroin -- 264 pounds -- into New York City.
The stock market finished slightly lower from Monday's close in continued quiet trading yesterday.

ALBANY, May 17 -- Legislation creating 21 new judgeships in the state appeared headed for oblivion tonight as Governor Rockefeller's office returned the bill to the adjourned Assembly because of a "technical deficiency."
DETROIT, May 16 -- George C. Wallace won his first election in the North tonight, sweeping the Michigan Democratic Presidential primary with massive support from Republican and independent voters.

GAMBIER, Ohio -- Gambier is a small town some 50 miles northeast of Columbus, surrounded by undulating fields touched by the spring green. It is the home of Kenyon College, a moderately sized liberal arts school recently gone coed.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A Brooklyn banker told a Senate subcommittee here today that local Federal Housing Administration officials had discriminated against his bank and in favor of mortgage-banking concerns and that kickbacks and payoffs were "very widespread in our metropolitan area."
BALTIMORE, May 16 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, recovering in a Silver Spring hospital from a gunman's bullets, scored an impressive victory in the Maryland primary today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has completed the first major divestiture under a Justice Department consent decree enabling I.T.T. to keep the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, it was learned yesterday.
HARTFORD, May 16 -- The Connecticut General Assembly, summoned today to a special session to pass a bill on abortion, was handed one that would make abortion illegal except to save the mother's life.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 (AP) -- Denny McLain took pills to lose weight but lost his strength, his fastball and his job with the Oakland Athletics.

Melvin Van Peebles, actor, singer, film director, writer, lyricist, composer, theater director and publicist supreme, is continuing the Blacking of Broadway. Last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, his new comedy musical, "Dont Play Us Cheap," arrived with the joyous air of a Saturday night block party.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Boston School Committe has directed its counsel to ask the United States District Court to include 65 cities and towns within a 35-mile radius of Boston as codefendants with the committee in a school desegregation suit.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Two Soviet flotillas comprising eight naval vessels have joined forces 200 miles east of the Vietnamese coast, Administration officials disclosed today.
The American Express "Money Card" will be honored in all the Bonwit Teller stores as a result of an agreement reached by Bonwit, a subsidiary of Genesco, Inc., and the American Express Company.
SAN JOSE, Calif., May 16 -- Judge Richard E. Arnason was asked today to direct a verdict of acquittal in the murder, kidnapping and conspiracy trial of Angela Davis.
" Beaujolais," said Paul Kovi, "is like a pretty young girl; lovely hair, beautiful features, bright smile -- but no sex."

KINSHASA, Zaire, May 16 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Mobutu Sese Seko ended a four-month conflict with the Roman Catholic Church yesterday when he authorized the Archbishop of Kinshasa to return from Rome.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Representative Leslie Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, read into the Congressional Record today what he said was the last of his four interviews with former United Service Organizations employes, which purported to detail fraud and other abuses by U. S. O. personnel in South Vietnam.
Pierre Cardin provided the derring-do while Donald Brooks and Mollie Parnis supplied the elegance in the latest round of fall fashion openings on Seventh Avenue.
TEL AVIV, May 16 -- Yitzhak Ben-Aharon, who resigned Sunday as Secretary General of Israel's powerful General Federation of Labor, announced tonight that he was resuming office.
It wasn't a case of try, try again to succeed as far as Rick Monday was concerned last night in Philadelphia, where the Cubs beat the Phillies, 8-1.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary of the Treasury John Connally suddenly emerged last week as the new big insider at the White House, and then before you could say "oil depletion allowance," he was out. It was all a little odd: they didn't even hold the announcement long enough to give poor George Wallace his day of tragic glory.

Israel cheered last week when Israeli paratroopers, disguised as mechanics, burst into a captured Belgian airliner at Lydda Airport to free ninety passengers and ten crew members who had been held hostage for 23 hours. In a short but wild gun battle, the tough paratroopers killed two Palestinian guerrilla gunmen and captured two female accomplices, wounding one.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Dr. Yale Brozen, who has recently been the most outspoken critic of the Federal Trade Commission as well as a consultant to one of its targets, launched another attack here today before a sympathetic audience -- representatives of the advertising industry.
Your May 2 editorial "Abusing the Diploma" displays an unwarranted contempt for both the legislative and educational processes.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Taking their cue from the attitude of their wounded rival, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, the other candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination prepared tonight to resume active campaigning.
The Foster Wheeler Corporation has elected William D. Stevens as senior vice president. He will be responsible for the overall activities of the company's equipment division.

TULSA, Okla., May 16 -- The Federal authorities here today identified William Allen Bremer, brother of Arthur H. Bremer, the suspect in the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, as the operator of an alleged reducing salon swindle.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Nixon announced today the resignation of John B. Connally as Secretary of the Treasury and said he would nominate George P. Shultz, director of the Office of Management and Budget, as his successor.

Most of the mothers in the commencement audience of 4,000 wore corsages. Fathers and other relatives carried cameras, and youngsters played tag on the freshly cut grass as the college president led the academic procession across the campus with its flowering dogwood and azalea and budding oaks.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- With the sounds of antiwar and religious songs echoing through the Rotunda, about 120 persons were arrested here today when they refused to end a sit-in in the Capitol.
The New York Mets made it five in a row last night by defeating the Montreal Expos, 7-3, in another galloping performance at Shea Stadium.

Peggy Wood, who recently celebrated her 80th birthday as well as more than 60 years in the legitimate theater, was the recipient yesterday of the third annual Strawhat Achievement Award. It was presented by the Council of Stock Theaters, comprising major summer theaters in the country, in association with Faberge, Inc., the cosmetic concern.

Frederick D. Jones, president of Eduforce, Inc., and New York City regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was found dead in his apartment yesterday apparently a stabbing victim.

In the half-century since it was first published, James Joyce's "Ulysses" has been subjected to such a bewildering variety of interpretations that it remains difficult to separate the book from the commentary, let alone to pick out an interpretation that works. However, one simple pattern has emerged consistently -a tendency among critics to gravitate toward two opposed but equally reductive points of view.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury will begin an investigation tomorrow into the collapse of the Penn Central Railroad.

KENT, Ohio, May 16 (UPI) -- The American Association of University Professors has asked President Nixon to call for a federal grand jury investigation into the killing of four Kent State university students by National Guard troops on May 4, 1970.

SAIGON, May 16 (AP) -- The United States command, in its summary of the results of a week of air strikes, said Air Force F-4 jets had attacked North Vietnam's main air defense complex at Bachmal airfield three miles south of Hanoi, "destroying several structures."

The city's Master Plan is "illegal" and will be challenged in the court on environmental grounds, Robert N. Rickles, the city's former Air Pollution Control Commissioner, told the City Planning Commission last night.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- Jockeys and harness-horse drivers on Illinois tracks may soon be required to take breath-analysis tests for intoxication, similar to those given motorists suspected of drunkenness.

Supported mainly by commission house and local short covering, which was brought about by the higher prices on the London market and the strength in gold, silver futures finished only slightly off their highs yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here.

Having returned recently from the Southern Sudan, I should like to add a postscript to the news report [March 24] that told of the ending of hostilities between the Government forces and the Anya-Nya [the Southern Sudanese guerrilla forces].

The opening here today of "Fillmore," a documentary film about the West Coast rock showcase and its impresario, Bill Graham, has been canceled by 20th Century-Fox, the distributors, pending an appeal of its "R" rating.
Stock prices eased yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

Mario Merola, head of the City Council's Finance Committee, said yesterday he would recommend that Mayor Lindsay raise the anticipated revenue from offtrack betting from $43-million to $70-million for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

PARIS, May 16 -- With the resignation of John B. Connally as Secretary of the Treasury, European economic officials are rereading with intense interest the proposals of the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, for monetary overhaul made last Friday in Montreal.

The American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., presented an optimistic forecast of operations this year for some 250 stockholders who attended its hour-long annual meeting in a company studio here yesterday.

City Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that landlords and developers using the scandal-ridden Municipal Loan Program owed the city more than $3.7-million in mortgage payments and had defaulted on loans totaling $25.4-million.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 16 (UPI) -- John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist, has confirmed that he would run for the Senate against Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, under certain conditions.

PARIS -- The distant and exotic island republic of Madagascar seems to be in the throes of some kind of revolution and while most Americans know little of that distant land and it ranks very low in the world power hierarchy, what happens there is important.
FREEPORT, L. I., May 16 -- A controversial plan to rezone both sides of deteriorating North Main Street here was approved today by the Village Trustees.
ALBANY, May 16 -- Governor Rockefeller today signed into law, a bill designed to promote sex equality in public schools, including the increased mixing of girls and boys in sports.
Corporation reported today lower earnings for the first quarter of 1972 and said it had developed a battery that could power a medium-small car for 100 miles without recharging.

Aldo Ceccato, a 38-year-old Italian conductor, has been appointed principal conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra. The two-year contract will become effective with the beginning of the 1973-74 season.

Second-quarter sales and earnings of the Coleman Company are expected to be above those of the first quarter, when the company cleared $1,869,000, or 26 cents a share, on sales of $41,566,000 Sheldon Coleman, chairman, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Wichita, Kan.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 16 -- Today was just an average day in Alabama, and for that matter in the rest of the South.

UPTON, L. I., May 16 -- The continued use of fossil fuels at projected levels will mean a 20 per cent increase in the amount of carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere by the year 2000, a leading meteorologist predicted today.

SILVER SPRING, Md., May 16 -- Gov. George C. Wallace was removed from the critical list today, but two Alabama doctors treating him at a hospital here said he would require additional surgery for the removal of a bullet lodged against his spine and apparently causing paralysis from his hips down.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- About 60 per cent of the material that 32 companies have filed with the Federal Trade Commission to substantiate advertising claims is either of doubtful adequacy or too technical, according to staff study.

BUFFALO, May 16 (UPI) -- George (Punch) Imlach ended a 13-year National Hockey League coaching career today when he relinquished his coaching duties with the Buffalo Sabres. Imlach said he would remain with the Sabres as general manager.

George Pratt Shultz, the man named yesterday by President Nixon to succeed John B. Connally as Secretary of the Treasury, is now back where he started financially when he came to Washington in 1969 -- but far ahead in prestige.
Fifty women editorial employes at Newsweek magazine filed a complaint yesterday with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charging the magazine with job discrimination against women.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- President Nixon signed today legislation intensifying efforts to find a cure for sickle cell anemia and providing new assistance for its victims.
Jacques Habert is resigning as publisher of the New York-based French weekly France-Amerique after 19 years, three months and 1,000 issues of publication.

Doctors treating Gov. George C. Wallace said he was struck by four and possibly five bullets. The areas shown in the accompanying diagram indicate the approximate locations of the bullet penetrations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 17 -- The United States command said yesterday that air strikes over the last five days had cut North Vietnam's main fuel pipeline to the South by destroying all its pumping stations in the southern panhandle.

Interest rates moved indecisively yesterday as the credit markets remained in their basically trendless pattern of recent weeks. Nothing in the news or technical situation was sufficient to get the market off dead center, although specialists reported some pickup in demand for corporate and tax-exempt securities late in the day.

Stockholder of the J. C. Penney Company were told at the annual meeting in Atlanta yesterday that net income in the first quarter, ended April 29, rose 19.2 per cent to $19,786,312, or 35 cents a share, from $16,600,833, or 31 cents, in the corresponding quarter of 1971.

Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, who trailed Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in a similar April poll, has taken a clear lead over him in a poll of New York State Democrats this month, WCBS-TV News said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The attempted assassination of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama with an American-made, $80 bargain revolver of a type that has been barred as an import since 1968 spurred anew here today the periodic and usually unsuccessful efforts of gun law reformers to tighten Federal firearms legislation.
NEWPORT, R. I., May 16 (AP)---Chester T. Minkier, inventor of a dept bomb used against German submarines in World War I, died today. He was 89 years old.
The city proposed legislation yesterday requiring owners to clean up immediately any mess their pets make in the streets.

In an extraordinary private memorandum, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has said that when he was appointed Police Commissioner in 1970, he was astonished and appalled by the corruption and lack of discipline he found in the department.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Senate accepted today, by a vote of 47 to 43, an Administration proposal that withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam be conditioned upon an internationally supervised cease-fire.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, whose $22.6-billion trust and investment division is the largest of any American bank, is giving the public a peek at its holdings for the first time in its 108-year history.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 16 -- Allied officers feel increasingly confident that it is possible that the city of Kontum in the Central Highlands can be held against an expected assault by the North Vietnamese Army.

Stacy Keach, Colleen Dewhurst and James Earl Jones will co-star in the New York Shakespeare Festival production of "Hamlet," which will be offered free at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park for three and a half weeks starting June 28.

The fourth World Team Olympiad, which begins in three weeks in Miami Beach, will offer the United States a good chance of winning two major world titles for the first time. A public offering of two mil lion shares of PPG Industries, Inc. common at $45 1/4 a share was announced yesterday by the First Boston Corporation as manager of an underwriting group handling the sale of the shares which were offered, accoring to the underwriters, by the Pitcairn Company, a per sonal holding company.
WNET/Channel 13 plans to announce a major reorganization of its national and local programing units later this week. Staff reductions are also expected.

WARSAW, May 16 -- One of the most enduring issues of postwar Polish life has been the struggle between the Communist Government and the Roman Catholic Church. Lately it has appeared as if this struggle might endure well beyond a negotiated accord.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday that it had withdrawn from involvement and association with the National Black Political Convention "because of a difference in ideology."

BONN, May 16 -- On the eve of the scheduled vote in the West German lower house on ratification of friendship treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland, the conservative opposition split today into three groups over the issue.

CHICAGO, May 16 (UPI) -- Lawyers for The Chicago Tribune have attempted to quash grand jury subpeonas served on six Tribune reporters for their investigative series on voter fraud.
John B. Connally's 15-month performance as Secretary of the Treasury drew mixed but generally favorable reviews yesterday from businessmen, bankers and economists.

ATLANTA, May 16 (AP) -- The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Frank Wille, endorsed today the removal of interest ceilings on deposits. He said it would force banks to compete with the rates available through direct market investments.

One of the hardiest illusions in legislative halls is that the mountainous burden of public welfare would melt to anthill proportions if relief recipients could only be made to work. PARIS, May 16 -- The Vietnamese Communists proposed today that the Paris peace conference resume on Thursday. The United States promptly refused to attend.

UNIONDALE, L. I., May 16 -- Billy Paultz is a 6-foot-11-inch 240-pounder. Ever since he left St. John's University with a season of eligibility remaining to sign with the New York Nets, there was no doubt he was big enough to play center in the American Basketball Association.

Students and faculty members at New York University's School of Engineering and Science are angry and worried over the State Legislature's authorizing Bronx Community College to buy N.Y.U.'s University Heights campus in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Industrial production rose strongly in April, and the increase was the biggest for any month in the brisk expansion that began last September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BUFFALO, May 16 -- Federal Judge John T. Curtin ruled today that state correction officials must permit newsmen to interview willing inmates unless there was "a clear and present danger of the breech of the security or orderly administration of the facility."
The Ozite Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices on many carpet products. They will go into effect on May 26, and will range from 1 per cent to 7.5 per cent.

In the final hours of the 1972 session last week the State Legislature passed, without debate or publicity, a measure that could have some important implications for New York straphangers.

Human error in gauging steam pressure is one of "several possible factors" being studied by a board investigating the explosion that killed seven persons May 3 at 80 Pine Street, Joseph Stein, Commissioner of Buildings, said yesterday.

Gil Evans, the jazz pianist, composer, arranger and conductor who has provided Miles Davis with some of his most viable settings, celebrated his 60th birthday last weekend with his large band at the Westbeth Cabaret, 155 Bank Street, where the group is playing every Saturday and Sunday.

The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday that its directors had voted to omit the quarterly dividend normally paid at this time. The Bethpage, L. I., aircraft and aerospace concern had been paying quarterly dividends of 25 cents a share.

" Music From Bennington," the program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night, had the informal agreeable atmosphere of a family gathering. Faculty and students from Bennington College in Vermont mingled as composers and performers, with the teachers bearing their responsibilities like true "amateurs," in love with their work.
HANOI, North Vietnam, May 16 -- North Vietnamese officials are telling diplomats and journalists that they expect heavier American bombing and other attacks before long and are prepared to meet them.

WHITE PLAINS, May 16 -- Apawamis Club of Westchester won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional team matches today by defeating Piping Rock of Long Island and Montclair of New Jersey.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 16 (UPI) -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation denied today for the first time in Chile that it plotted to prevent the inauguration of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 16 -- President Park Chung Hee reaffirmed today South Korea's readiness to cooperate with any countries, including Communist nations, for world peace as long as they did not commit "hostile acts" against his country.
MOSCOW, May 16 -- The Soviet Union opened a publicity campaign today to justify its scheduled talks with President Nixon next week against the background of the mining of North Vietnamese ports.

DALLAS, May 16 (UPI) -- Police arrested retired Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker in a park early today for violating a curfew by holding a "prayer vigil" for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

Some of America's leading songwriters got a chance to say, "They're playing our song" Monday evening in the Grand Ballroom of the Americana Hotel. Thirty-one songwriters who were being inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame not only heard their songs played but several also seized the opportunity to sing some of their hits.
DAVENPORT, Iowa May 16 -- The aluminum industry is now operating "just about on balance," John D. Harper, chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, said today.

BANGKOK, Thailand -- The world's attention in recent months has been turned toward the Mideast -- Turkey, principally -- as the source of illicit supplies of heroin. But the fact is that the fabled "Fertile Triangle" of Southeast Asia -- Thailand, Burma and Laos -- continues to produce two-thirds of the world's known supply of opium, from which heroin is derived.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 16 (AP) -- President Juan M. Bordaberry signed a declaration today extending Uruguay's "internal war" against the leftist Tupamaro guerrillas for 45 days.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that consideration should be given to the creation of a national institute of justice, patterned after the National Institutes of Health, to help solve Federal and state judicial problems.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 16 -- Texas oil wells will continue in June to produce as much as they can without causing waste or the threat of salt-water pollution.

Picking her way cleverly through a cluster in front of her in the stretch drive, Country Belle of the Calumet Farm won the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. Angel Cordero steered the daughter of Herbager to a 1 3/4-length triumph over Kings Peace in the one-mile test for 3-year-old fillies.

Local and Federal authorities said yesterday that a black couple arrested May 5 in Columbia, S. C., and charged with the illegal possession of firearms were also wanted for questioning in connection with the murder of two policemen in the East Village earlier this year.

DENVER, May 16 -- C. Williard Heckel, a professor and former dean of the Rutgers University Law School was elected today to be Moderator of the 184th General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

YONKERS, May 16 -- "Who's afraid of Strike Out?" might have been this morning's battle call of 10 trainers and drivers as they dropped $2,000 checks into the entry box to cover the starting fees for their charges in Friday night's Cane Pace, the first leg in the series for the triple crown of pacing.

PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 16 -- In the entrance hall to Pyongyang's Kim Il Sung University there is a large statue of Korea's leader. A home medical guide, dated 1971 and offered as a bonus to advertisers to Ralph Ginzburg's consumer newsletter Moneysworth, was actually written in Germany at least 20 years ago, a search of records has revealed.

DETROIT, May 17 -- George C. Wallace trounced his liberal opposition in yesterday's Michigan Presidential primary, but there was immediate maneuvering today over his delegate seats at the Democratic National Convention.

The Unilever group of companies reported yesterday that their consolidated earnings in the first quarter of 1972 were 18 per cent higher than in the year-earlier period on a sales gain of 13 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Every time some high-standing politician utters that line about our not even wanting anything in return for all the fighting we have done in Vietnam and all the money we have spent out there, somebody ought to stand up in the audience and cry, "Why not?"

MINEOLA, L.I., May 17 -- Assemblyman Eli Wager charged today that the Republicans were "openly supporting" his Democratic primary opponent, Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, in Nassau County's new 20th Assembly District.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The rise and fall of a scheme to buy two-family houses in Government-insured mortgages, rent them to welfare families and get high returns for private investors was described here today to a Senate subcommittee.
The discussion in your May 10 editorial "Mr. Nixon's Brinkmanship" and on the Op-Ed page the same day of the President's Vietnam policy shift makes interesting and somewhat painful reading.

Lee Michaels is a singer-keyboard player whose special conceit is that he performs accompanied only by his own electric organ playing and a drummer. At Carnegie Hall Tuesday night, one was less impressed by the self-conscious pretensions of Mr. Michaels's tour de force than by the fact that he was able to get so much sound and so little music out of the extensive resources of the two instruments.

Mr. Harry Reasoner recently took to his television newsdesk and delivered a commentary. He said that he knew a man who had a pain in the neck about actors getting into politics. He warned President Nixon and Senator McGovern about actors' support. He said, "Presidential candidates should leave endorsements to makers of false teeth cement."

The Essex House at 160 Central Park South, has agreed to refund 35,000 customers a total of $68,533.24 it overcharged them between Oct. 28, 1969, and July 1, 1970, and promised not to levy "deceptive" and "illegal" charges in the future.

A 70-year-old man, identified by authorities as a former bodyguard of Meyer Lansky, the underworld figure, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday in Queens to first-degree manslaughter in the shooting death Jan. 7 of the president of an association of independent unions.
The body of a 26-year-old member of the Chinese mission to the United Nations who died suddenly more than three months ago is still in the city morgue.
Offtrack betting's Preakness Special opens today, and assorted touts reportedly are urging Mayor Lindsay to parlay his Kentucky Derby winnings onto Riva Ridge.

The Royal Ballet's triple bill at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night started dismally but moved forward to magnificence. The bad news first, if only because it opened the program and we can at least get it over with. This was John Cranko's "Poeme de l'Extase."

Columbia University obtained a court order yesterday temporarily barring a faculty-student antiwar group and three individual adults from occupying Pupin Hall or otherwise disrupting the activities of the university.

TAPIEI, Taiwan, May 17 -- The standing committee of the Central Committee of the ruling Nationalist party today voted to urge President Chiang Kai-shek to appoint his elder son, Chiang Ching-kuo, to the Premiership.

West Germany's friendship treaties with Russia and Poland now seem certain of ratification by the end of the week -- not with the solid Bundestag majority Chancellor Brandt had anticipated but by default of the Christian Union opposition. Unable to agree on any other strategy, the opposition decided to abstain on the critical vote yesterday. As a result, the treaties were approved with 248 votes, exactly half the Bundestag membership.

Wendy Hilton, a specialist in 18th-century dance, performed eight of these Baroque dances Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall in a program shared with other artists, entitled "One Hour of Chamber Music." The event, directed by Jens Nygaard, was presented at a convenient time for zipping in after work (5:40 P.M.).

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, called on Congress today to pass a new copyright law that will provide "an independent, objective tribunal" to determine fair payment for use of copyright works, including movies, on cable television.

Bruce K. MacLaury, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, challenged yesterday the notion that there is a deep-seated difference between Arthur Burns and Paul Volcker over international monetary reform.

The undersigned, members of the faculty and other officers of instruction of the School of Law of Columbia University, enthusiastically support the candidacy of Judge Nanette Dembitz of the Family Court of New York for the Democratic nomination to one of the three vacancies on the New York State Court of Appeals.
Vice President Agnew has a clear lead as the first choice of the nation's Republican voters to repeat as President Nixon's running mate in November, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- In what they called a "Republican declaration of conscience," 10 Republican Senators today reaffirmetd support of a national policy aimed at desegregating the nation's schools.

BONN, May 17 -- One could imagine tonight that from the Atlantic to the Urals, politically minded Europeans gave a muffled sigh of relief at the news that the Bonn parliament had ratified the treaties that offer the hope of East-West cooperation.

While students on campuses all over America were griping about the gray meat and glutinous pudding served to them in college dining rooms, a lucky group of Barnard roommates sat down on a recent evening in their Plimpton Hall suite to an elaborate meal of original dishes that would do credit to most New York restaurants.

A committee of the Medical Society of the County of New York has adopted a resolution calling on officials of methadone-maintenance programs in the city to terminate take-home privileges for addict-patients and administer the drug exclusively in clinics to arrest the spread of the methadone black market.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- It was undoubtedly the most unusual and dramatic post-operative procedure that Dr. Joseph F. Schanno had ever been through.

WARWICK, R. I., May 17 -- An organized group of union officers and high school students at the airport here was the only large crowd that greeted Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today in the first resumption of campaigning since Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was shot.

A special Columbia University committee on the arts has recommended the setting up of a new theater-arts program for undergraduates, in a report submitted yesterday to Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia.
GUILDFORD, England, May 17 (UPI) -- Patti Hogan showed her temperament again today at the Rothman's tennis tournament.

Intellectuals, artists and other savants gathered here yesterday to warm one another's spirit and to renew old friendships. They did it at the annual ceremonies of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters, and they did it with a flourish.

It seems to me that American life has rushed forward so rapidly that it has created a vacuum behind it, and that it has become the special mission of certain Southern writers to fill that vacuum, to bridge the enormous gap between, say, life in Manhattan and in Mount Salus, Miss., where Eudora Welty has placed "The Optimist's Daughter."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Securities Industry Association and the Municipal Finance Officers Association both endorsed in principle today the idea of giving state and local governments the option of issuing taxable bonds with an automatic interest subsidy from the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A report by the General Accounting Office on the status of the Strategic Army Forces in the United States concludes that "many units are not combat-ready."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board has stirred a storm of protest among the nation's bankers with its proposals to overhaul the rules governing bank reserves and check-collection procedures.

The Board of Education gave final approval last night to the choice of Nathan Quinones to fill one of two vacancies on the Board of Examiners, but decided to postpone a vote on the nomination of Dr. Sylvester King, a former Harlem principal once charged with harassing union teachers, to fill the second vacancy.

Mayor Lindsay, who set forth on the road to the White House with great ebullience, although an admitted long shot, has returned to City Hall stung by his defeat in the primaries, working harder than ever while soberly reassessing his role as Mayor and his political future, according to his closest advisers.

The criminal assault on Governor Wallace has once again spotlighted the nation's hideous crime against itself -- its refusal to take effective measures to control the manufacture, sale and ownership of guns. The depressing aspect of recurrent flurries of public interest and Congressional response is that these all quickly evaporate in surrender to the gun lobby's powerful propaganda machine.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 -- Freddie Lewis, the 6-foot Indiana Pacer guard, gets more attention from the fans in the Other American Basketball Association franchise cities than he does in Indiana. The hometown fans often boo him and make him a scapegoat in defeat.
ATHENS, May 17 -- A magazine publisher has sued officials of the United States Information Service in Athens for invading his privacy by mailing "unwanted propaganda material" to his home.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17 -- All of South Vietnam's institutions of higher learning closed today in accordance with President Nguyen Van Thieu's emergency mobilization decree, and students of both sexes prepared for military or paramilitary training.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., May 17 -- Chet Marcin, a former harness racing driver and trainer, was the surprising leader at 72 after the first round of the Long Island open golf championship today.

It is distressing to learn of the announcement (news story April 27) by Treasury Under Secretary Paul A. Volcker to the effect that a "Group of 20" may negotiate reform of the world monetary system. If any new monetary system comes into being, it will remain a piecemeal effort toward solving the broader international economic disequilibrium.

Duplicate bridge enthusiasts who wish to play at home have the following options if they have two tables: a match between two teams, a contest between four pairs, which amounts to three short matches, and an individual contest, which is like playing seven brief matches with a different partner and a different assortment of teammates each time. All these are best scored by international match points.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Mrs. Coretta Scott King, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., reportedly will announce tomorrow in Los Angeles that she is supporting Senator George McGovern's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
PARIS, May 17 -- The speculative flurry in gold intensified today as the price in the free market centers of Zurich and London rose another $2 an ounce to $57.75.
I strongly endorse your May 10 editorial "Mr. Nixon's Brinkmanship."
The bond market seemingly paid little attention yesterday to the latest batch of economic data and remained in what has become an unusually long period with no pronounced trend in rates.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A House-Senate conference committee agreed today on legislation that would delay for up to 19 months the implementation of court desegregation orders that require busing.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- School busing is a legitimate method of desegregating schools, and people who oppose busing oppose school desegregation, said a report issued today by the United States Commission on Civil Rights.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 17 -- Buoyed by reports that Gov. George C. Wallace was no longer on the critical list, the Wallace for President campaign headquarters got almost back to normal today.
Much more than a floodtide of sympathy over the despicable attempt on his life went into the victories scored by George C. Wallace in this week's two key Democratic primaries.

BALTIMORE, May 17 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabana captured 39 per cent of the popular vote in the Maryland primary yesterday, but the real meaning of that victory, in terms of convention-delegate votes, remained unclear today.
The American Home Products Corporation has reached an agreement to acquire the Much Group of companies of Bad Soden, West Germany, for stock worth more than $39-million, it was announced yesterday.
Shares on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday. The exchange's index managed to edge upward by 0.03 to close at 27.61, continuing a slow uptrend.

A woman found stabbed to death on Long Island Tuesday night was identified yesterday as the wife of a Nassau County private school operator who has been accused by the state of running a fraudulent educational counseling scheme.

It was disclosed yesterday that the New York Urban Coalition had submitted an "immediate" resignation from the city's policy-making Council Against Poverty -- an action that would automatically displace its often-controversial representative, David J. Billings 3d, the council's chairman.

TRENTON, May 17 -- Gov. William T. Cahill will urge the New Jersey Legislature tomorrow to approve a tax reform program that includes an income tax and a statewide property tax of $1 for every $100 of true value. It is designed to raise $2-billion a year.

Obedience training devotees agree that high scores are attained as a result of a team operation between the dog and his master or mistress. "One must be patient and firm with the dog, not cruel," said Carlyle and Gabrielle Fabian of Voorhees, N.J. "You start working from 20 minutes to a half-hour a day with the basic training and strive to establish'good habits with the

HANOVER, N. H., May 17 (AP) -- The president of Dartmouth College, John Kemeny, said today that a committee had been set up by the school to advise the trustees on relations with corporations that might have "possible adverse impact on desirable social goals."
WARSAW, May 17 -- "Is your President still coming?"

The two-day rise in the price of soybean futures came to an abrupt halt yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Sell-offs erased the early fractional increases as well as other rises later in the session.

The loose, unbuttoned cardigan jacket by Saint Laurent out of Chanel is everybody's favorite wrap-up theme for fall. Several designers combine it with the monotone look which pulls together the multitudinous parts that make up the newest fashions.
The world champion Pirates are beginning to look the part.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a Federal District Court today to halt the sale of Glenn W. Turner's pyramid franchising scheme on the ground that it is nothing but "a device, scheme and artifice to defraud."
SILVER SPRING, Md., May 17 -- Gov. George C. Wallace's neurosurgeon said today that the Governor had less than a 50-50 chance of regaining the use of his paralyzed legs.

DALLAS, May 17 (UPI) -- Former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker continued his prayer vigil for Gov. George C. Wallace for the third day today but he has apparently ended his conflict with the city's curfew laws.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 17 (AP) -- Guerrilla gunmen fatally wounded a British soldier and shot another in the leg tonight. Other violence in Northern Ireland during the day also left one civilian dead and 21 injured.
Three leading Democrats endorsed Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz yesterday in her effort to become the first woman to sit on the State Court of Appeals.
Posing as polished art lovers, detectives arrested a Manhattan art dealer yesterday and seized seven paintings that they said he had falsely labeled as valuable works of the 18th and 19th centuries.

ANACONDA, Mont., May 17 (AP) -- Saying "nobody likes some of the things that have had to be done," John B. M. place, president of the Anaconda Company, told a stockholders meeting today that brighter days were ahead.
ALBANY, May 17 -- Governor Rockefeller's rejection of a bill passed by the Legislature to create new judgeships stirred confusion and speculation today among political leaders in the state.
LONDON, May 17 -- "Pupil power," a budding movement that has stirred teen-agers and annoyed teachers, held a noisy, surging demonstration here today in a mood of angry militance.
Three reporters for The New York Daily News have won Columbia University's 1972 Meyer Berger Award for an investigative series on organized crime at Kennedy International Airport.

By doing at once what a Presidential commission had suggested be spaced "over a period of years," the House Appropriations Committee has dealt a potentially crippling blow to the United Nations and to this country's position in the international community.
BANGALORE, India, May 17 (AP) -- Australia clinched the Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis final by beating India in doubles today, but lost her No. 1 player, 37-year-old Mal Anderson.

George McGovern now heads west as the Democratic leader in the number of delegates pledged to him. He is the favorite in the virtually uncontested Oregon primary, which ought to give him a good lift into the showdown California primary on June 6. Behind him in New York he leaves a good lead over Hubert Humphrey, both as measured in a poll by WCBS and in the opinion of professionals eying the delegate slates.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury investigating the Penn Central collapse called its first two witnesses today, one of whom explained the corporate intricacies involved in the 1968 merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads
HONOLULU, May 17 -- City garbage workers returned to their jobs this morning, ending a five-day strike.

Tonight, at 8:30, Playhouse New York's current series on "The '40s" continues with "Hollywood -- You Must Remember This." With Victoria Hochberg as producer and Richard Shiekel, the film critic, as writer and associate producer, the 90-minute program examines the art and industry of American films during the decade that was dominated by the production of World War II.

West Side youngsters found a police station a happy place yesterday as the $2,816,000 20th Precinct station was formally dedicated. The 20th Precinct Community Council staged a block party to mark the dedication.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 17 (AP) -- The sales impetus of F. W. Woolworth for the first four months of 1972 was "exceptionally strong" and the company is exceeding its projected 10 per cent increase over last year, the company's chairman and chief executive officer said today.
The New York Mets added to the best record in baseball last night with a 12-2 mauling of the Montreal Expos for their sixth straight victory.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Administration officials said categorically today that no ships had entered or left Haiphong harbor since President Nixon ordered it mined. They also said that reconnaissance showed no minesweeping activity at Haiphong or other North Vietnamese ports.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Martinis was asktd to disqualify himself from the Harlem Four case yesterday by the defense, which said he had concealed information and, in effect, deceived the defense, in the public about a crucial event in the case.

NEW DELHI, May 17 -- Informed sources said today that the meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan was likely to be enlarged to include Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh.

NEW HAVEN, May 16 -- Patrick Power, the tragic hero of Bill Morrison's new play, "Patrick's Day," the final production of the season at the Long Wharf Theater, is a self-made failure. Taking his pseudonym from a bottle of whisky, he has transformed himself into a prize-winning novelist with the dimension and pretension of Hemingway.

CLEVELAND, May 17 -- Eight strong innings of pitching by Steve Kline and Jim Roland went to waste for the New York Yankees at Municipal Stadium tonight when the Cleveland Indians rallied against Fred Beene in the ninth to post a 2-1 triumph and maintain their position atop the American League Eastern Division.

City Councilwoman Carol Greitzer charged yesterday that at least 13 of 63 staff members recently given layoff notices by the Metropolitan Museum of Art were being released because of "political and retaliatory reasons."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 18 -- South Vietnamese troops transported by helicopter moved yesterday within two miles of the besieged and battered city of Anloc, senior American officials here said. The advance, by paratroopers and units of the South Vietnamese 21st Division, was said to have met only sporadic opposition.

The New York Times's primary election surveys indicate strongly that a third-party candidacy by Gov. George C. Wallace would be likely to cut far more sharply into President Nixon's vote than into that of the Democratic nominee.
BALTIMORE, May 17 -- Riva Ridge, the Meadow Stable colt and his entrymate, Upper Case, dominate the Preakness picture.

An eight-day occupation of the Student Center at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn by black and Puerto Rican students ended last night after the school's administration and trustees agreed to either implement or investigate the protesters' nine demands.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday its first quarterly loss in two years.
WARSAW, May 17 -- The West German Bundestag's ratification of the 1970 Moscow and Warsaw treaties was welcomed here today.

Mrs. Minnie Lee Tananbaum, vice president of Ferdinando Sarmi, Ltd., designers of women's fashions, was married here last evening to Dr. Alberto Lomeo, a gynecologist and obstetrician in practice in New York.

Jewish students enrolled in the City University of New York who also attend Jewish teachers seminaries and yeshivas will receive transfer credits for work in these institutions on a more uniform basis than in the past in accordance with a new policy announced by Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee.

Pennsylvania's crusading insurance commissioner, Herbert S. Denenberg, who not long ago published a list of life insurance companies together with the prices they charge, has come out with a new list.
PARIS, May 17 -- Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam said in an interview published today that his side would negotiate an end to the war in 24 hours, if it could.

The Germans, the Poles and the Russians have served each other as often as they have fought each other since they first emerged as nations on the European scene 11 centuries ago. The three nations have been inextricably mixed in cooperation and in conflict since their beginnings.

BONN, May 17 -- After more than two decades of postwar hostility between West Germany and Eastern Europe, treaties of friendship with the Soviet Union and Poland were approved today in the lower house of the West German Parliament.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The White House today released a rough outline of President Nixon's trip to Moscow. It indicated that his visit would emphasize official business at the expense of ceremony.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (Reuters) -- The State Department acknowledged today that the United States has been informed of Egypt's decision to reduce her staff here to 10 -- five diplomatic and five administrative personnel.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 17 (UPI) -- The president of American Airlines, George A. Spater, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that a 6 per cent fare increase last May and another 3 per cent fare increase this year are not enough" and "further increases will be required."

The defendants in the Howard R. Hughes "autobiography" case filed a Federal suit yesterday demanding the return of more than $91,000 that they said was seized illegally last month by the Internal Revenue Service.
R. Stanley Laing resigned yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the National Cash Register Company.

E. R. Squibb Sons, Inc., has named Dr. Barry Davis, executive vice president, responsible for worldwide operations; Dr. Lawrence Marks, vice president of corporate development and Vahan Hogroian, vice president of planning and systems.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Dr. Yale Brozen, who yesterday again attacked the Federal Trade Commission, was charged today with "gross distortion" by a high official of that agency.

Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday toward a compromise on the controversial low-income housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, by naming Mario R. Cuomo, a lawyer, "to make an independent exploration of possible revisions" in the development now under construction.

Dr. Marina Whitman, the only woman member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, and Dr. Walter W. Heller, chairman of the council under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, were in substantial agreement yesterday that the economy would improve measurably during 1972.
YONKERS, May 17 -- Twelve, an unusually large field of 3-year-olds for this stakes event, will go postward in the $27,700 Bronx Filly Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

Deportation hearings for John Lennon and his wife, Yoko Ono, closed yesterday with the British musician telling the Immigration Service inquiry officer: "I don't know if there's any mercy to plead for because this isn't a Federal Court. But if there is, I'd like it, please."

A recovery in the last half-hour enabled the stock market to finish mixed yesterday in lackluster trading as many investors continued to remain on the sidelines, mainly because of the unsettled Vietnam situation.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 17 -- A two-time winner, Babe Lichardus of Shackamaxon, broke out of a three-way tie for the lead today with a second-round 72 and a 36-hole total of 140 in the ninth annual $25,000 Dodge Dealers open.

LOS ANGELES, May 17 (UPI) -- More than 100 heavily armed policemen ringed the bank, crouching behind patrol cars, rifles and shotguns ready. Snipers peered from surrounding buildings. A police helicopter hovered overhead.

MOSCOW, May 17 -- With the visit of President Nixon only five days off, the Soviet media are conveying the impression that the American mining of Haiphong have fostered new collaboration between the Soviet Union and China.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, May 17 -- A subcontractor who last March charged that there were "serious problems of plant safety" at Consolidated Edison's new Indian Point nuclear generating plant said today that "my concern about the safety of the plant has been eliminated.''
The present rate of business improvement will continue throughout the year, but there is no boom in sight, the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc., reported yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17 -- The Government of Iraq today served a two-week ultimatum on the Western consortium that exploits and markets Iraqi oil.
The Columbia University Club last night overwhelmingly approved a constitutional amendment permitting women to join as full members.

The women's jockey colony at New York's metropolitan, thoroughbred tracks continues to grow. Four women turned up for riding appointments at Belmont Park yesterday, a record for a single program. The previous mark was three.
HAIPHONG, North Vietnam, May 17 -- The North Vietnamese say they are clearing American mines from the Haiphong harbor as planes drop them, and moving ships in and out.

Cases have been closed arbitrarily, assistance has been erroneously denied or delayed and the homebound poor have encountered difficulties since the Department of Social Services separated income-maintenance and service functions nine months ago, the Community Council of Greater New York said yesterday.

If attendance figures are taken as a reflection of fan interest, the players' strike had no discernible effect on public responsiveness to major league baseball, according to statistics for the first four weeks of the season.

The City Planning Commission yesterday evening approved the $1.2-billion Manhattan Landing development project, which would provide a massive complex of apartments and commercial facilities on platforms above the East River bordering Lower Manhattan.

Security, President Nixon announced the appointment of John S. D. Eisenhower as a chairman of the Inter-agency Classification Review Committee. The committee will oversee the implementation and operation of the new system for classification and declassification of Government documents established by the President. Also on the committee will be senior representatives of the Departments of Defense, State and Justice, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Atomic Energy Commission.

A very important case, Rosario v. Rockefeller, is now pending before the Supreme Court of the United States. At issue is the validity of Section 186 of the New York Election Law. This restrictive law prohibits young voters and others not registered on Oct. 2, 1971, from voting in the June 20 New York Presidential primary.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Spurred by the attempt to assassinate Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, a Senate subcommittee voted today to bar the sale of most snub-nosed pistols.

One of the hard-fought perennial debates in Albany concerns a change in legal procedure to permit the judge, rather than the defense and prosecuting attorneys, to question prospective jurors in state criminal cases. Although its supporters have labeled this a mere "technical" change, intended to reduce court delay, it has nevertheless been defeated in the past, with the opposition not only of defense lawyers, but of some prosecutors and judges.

Seventeen New York policemen will receive, eight of them posthumously, the department's highest award, the Medal of Honor. The eight were killed in the line of duty.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- In the second largest case of its kind, the Treasury Department said today it was investigating whether aluminum ingot imported from Canada was being sold at illegal prices in the United States.

George Balanchine's "Jewels" revels in the concept and execution of classical dancing and quite unself-consciously teases some of its conventions as well. At the State Theater Tuesday evening, the New York City Ballet presented a bright and warm performance of the work.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 17 (UPI) -- The executive director of the National Urban League fears that "black people are going out of style" and white Americans, weary of the racial struggle, will let the movement wither as whites did after the Civil War.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- An American Bar Association committee recommends in a report released today that police departments make far fewer arrests and hire legal advisers to help shape law-enforcement policy.

Fairchild Camera Instrument Corporation in a prospectus filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 750,000 shares of its, common stock, disclosed that the Internal Revenue Service maintains the company owes $23-million in additional Federal income taxes for the years 1964-1969.

LIMA, Peru, May 17 -- The Peruvian military Government decreed new standards today to restrict television and radio programing and advertising. The decrees say that all programs broadcast must reflect "human values" and be "socially useful."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Gov. George C. Wallace scored his breathtaking sweep in Michigan yesterday -- Walter Reuther's and G. Mennen William's and Philip A Hart's Michigan, the most liberal of the Middle Western industrial states, with its proud history of racially open politics -- for one essential reason.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Stuart T. Saunders, the former chairman of the Penn Central Transportation Company, said today that the causes of the railroad's financial failure "involved problems not of mismanagement but problems which were unmanageable."
An ambitious plan to involve millions of people in the metropolitan area in a two-way dialogue on major regional development issues was announced yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- The Soviet Union disclosed tonight that regional members of its top leadership had been summoned to Moscow for what appeared to be a full meeting of the Communist party's ruling Politburo, possibly to prepare for President Nixon's visit next week.

The twin-engine six-passenger Beechcraft owned by the New York State Teachers Association slipped out of the low-hanging rain clouds and taxied to a stop at the nearly deserted Adirondack Airport at Lake Clear.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange made a significant gain yesterday as measured by the index, which rose 0.14 to close at 27.75. Volume increased to 4.7 million shares from 3.9 million.

DACCA, Bangladesh, May 18 -- In a ceremony attended by the clinking of teacups instead of the usual champagne glasses, the United States diplomatic representation in Dacca -- formerly called "mission" -- officially became an embassy today.

Imagine, if you can, a peaceful primeval Brooklyn, the air suffused with mysterious melodious notes creating a pervasive spiritual serenity "until we came, and drove it away." Such is the wistful atmosphere conjured up in 15-year-old Theresa Schoenacher's "the Place."

Interrupting her official state visit to France, Queen Elizabeth II had tea and her fourth reunion with her uncle the Duke of Windsor, at his home in the Boulogne woods on the western perimeter of Paris.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to make the Federal "locater" service available in tracking down "runaway fathers" of all income levels who fail to support their children.
