YONKERS, May 18 -- With Romalie Hanover, the 1-2 favorite from the No. 7 post slowed by traffic problems, top honors in the 16th annual Bronx Filly Pace tonight went to the Billy Haughton-driven Pammy Lobell at Yonkers Raceway.

The Times has taken a strong stand against the marine mammal protection act, House Bill 10420. Let us examine the facts. The bill prohibits the killing or harassment as well as the importation of any marine mammal or part thereof anywhere in the United States.

Whether one likes or deplores the results of the Democratic primaries in Michigan and Maryland, they were perfectly clear: Gov. George C. Wallace won in both states by substantial margins. Their delegations to the Democratic Presidential convention in Miami Beach should fully reflect those margins, but they won't do anything of the sort. Most unfairly, neither one will be more than nominally a Wallace delegation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 18 -- Despite four years of Vietnamization, American and South Vietnamese military commanders here have relied less on the Government's ground troops to stem the current North Vietnamese offensive than on an instrument of massive bombing that only the Americans have -- the B-52.

A California medical research team reported yesterday that it had developed a quick, inexpensive and simple test to determine before birth whether a baby was likely to fall victim to a respiratory disease that takes the lives of 25,000 newborns in this country each year.

If one had to pick superlatives and adjectives of praise for "Open Heart," one would have to say that it is the best of Frederick Buechner's novels to date; that it is funny, touching, tender and compassionate; and that reading it has the curious effect of relaxing tensions one hadn't even been aware one was feeling.
Yogi Berra said yesterday that he considered the Jerry Koosman racetrack incident "closed," but that it stood as a lesson to the rest of the New York Mets to "watch out who you associate with."

The Metropolitan Opera, with two months to go before the close of its fiscal year, is facing its largest cash deficit since its opening at Lincoln Center in 1967. George S. Moore, the company's president, said yesterday afternoon "the present reading is that we need to raise $750,000."

The riots at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men in October, 1970, were "justified," the lawyers for three prisoners said yesterday, because the inmates had "no other means" to protect themselves from "official murder, beatiings, fear, pain and general degradation."

TRENTON, May 18 -- The New Jersey Senate today gave final legislative passage to a modified "no fault" automobile insurance bill that is expected to be signed by Gov. William T. Cahill and become law Jan. 1.

Dorothy Day, co-founder of the Catholic Worker movement and 1972 recipient of the University of Notre Dame's Laet-are Medal "for comforting the afflicted . . . virtually all her life," has been served with a Federal Government claim for $296,359 in back taxes and penalties because she refuses, on principle to give funds to the Government.

BONN, May 18 -- With completion of parliamentary approval of West Germany's treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland virtually guaranteed tomorrow in the Bundesrat, or upper house, Chancellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel prepared tonight to challenge the conservative Opposition to new elections.
The slumbering stock market woke up yesterday and made its first advance in three sessions in stepped-up trading.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today legislation designed to cut through the red tape that entangles much of the nation's social service effort.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The White House denied today a New York Times report that the North Vietnamese were clearing United States mines from Haiphong and that ships were entering and leaving the port.

Anthony Eden, Earl of Avon, opened his May 5 Op-Ed essay "Getting the Free World Together" with an eminently sound proposition: a foreign policy based on reality should come to no great harm. He later named four countries which he thought could become associated with the four Western European powers in a broader "free world" organization.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, May 18 (AP) -- President Philibert Tsiranana, the uncontested ruler of Madagascar since independence from France in 1960, turned over full powers today to Gen. Gabriel Ramanantsoa, the army chief of staff, after six days of anti-Government riots, strikes and demonstrations.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Can Senator George McGovern, whose political base is a state with only 1,844 blacks, whose personal style is the very antithesis of soul, sell himself to the black electorate?
The New York Stock Exchange's board of governors proposed sweeping changes yesterday in the method whereby the exchange tries persons and firms accused of violating its constitution and rules.

Today is the first constructive day I have ever spent in the Army Reserve. Today, instead of my regular Army Reserve meeting, which is characterized by naps, card games, obsolete G.I. training films, lousy food, haircut inspections and groups of fatigue-clad G.I.'s sticking out like sore thumbs in diners and bars, I went into the slums of Asbury Park.

R. H. Hodges' contention that "the Third Reich . . . collapsed under the weight of strategic and tactical bombing'' [letter May 4] is contradicted by P. M. S. Blackett in his "Fear, War, and the Bomb". (1948).

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The National Conference of Judicial Councils, an organization that exists for the sole purpose of having lunch once a year with the members of the Supreme Court in the Supreme Court Building, proved again today that it is one of the most viable organizations of the legal profession.

Yesterday morning, Eddie Yowell, the trainer of October Farm's prominent Pass Catcher, who was scheduled to start later in the day in the $15,000 Doge at Belmont Park, made out a scratch blank for his 4-year-old colt. His request was denied by the stewards.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York endorsed yesterday legislation to authorize statewide branch banking in New Jersey. A bill that would do this is currently pending in the Legislature in Trenton.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The 1973-74 Federal budget will reflect more fiscal restraint than budgets immediately preceding. it, Caspar W. Weinberger, new director of the Federal Office of Management and Budget, said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Former Defense Secretary Clark M. Clifford charged today that President Nixon's military actions against North Vietnam were prolonging the war and raising the risk of a major confrontation with the Soviet Union

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., May 18 -- Aided by an eagle 3, Jimmy Wright scored a closing three-under-par 69 today and won the Long Island open golf championship by three strokes. The 32-year-old professional from the Inwood Country Club, with a 54-hole aggregate of 214, carried off the district honors for the third time.
ROME, May 18 -- Some 300,000 civil servants started a two-day strike today to protest against pay raises for their superiors.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP) -- Jim Malloy of Denver died today of multiple injuries suffered last Sunday in a fiery crash at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH 2, in the Atlantic, May 18 -- One of the ship's, launches had been lowered and was waiting for the bomb experts when they hit the water. You could see everything. They landed about 300 feet off the bow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 19 -- North Vietnamese troops, supported by tanks, made another series of attacks on Government positions only a mile and a half northwest of Kontum in the Central Highlands early today, but they were beaten back by a combination of American air strikes and resistance on the ground, according to allied reports.
The bond market seemed to be gathering strength yesterday to move up and out of its narrow range of recent weeks.

The agreement reached by Senate - House conferees on the so-called public school anti-busing amendment should remove the most serious obstacle to enactment of the historic higher education aid bill. It is a compromise that has already drawn fire from Southern segregationists, who wanted to ram an anti-integration rider down the conference committee's throat, and from some civil rights groups, who consider any restriction on busing unacceptable.

The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn is most engagingly crazy. It is virtually dead broke -- if anyone has any artistic money going spare this would be a good home for it -- and it cheerfully admits that: "In terms of repertoire, audience relationship and attempts at financing, we behaved as though we were in Sweden, rather than America."

HEIDELBERG, West Germany, May 15--Early in 1942 a group of newly arrived black lieutenants assembled at Fort Benning, Ga., to be addressed by a senior lieutenant colonel. The colonel's first words were a warning that the blacks were not to use the officers club.
FORT-LAMY, Chad, May 18 (Agence France - Presse) -- French troops have completed their mission in Chad and will begin pulling out of the country at the beginning of June, it was announced here today.

In the midst of a trade press controversy over the efficiency of advertising in black media, an ad agency president has pledged $5,000 seed money for "much needed, long ignored in-depth research" in the black consumer market.
PARIS, May 18 -- The price of gold weakened today in London and Zurich after the rush this week that saw the metal change hands at more than $58 an ounce. Today's closing in London was $56.90.
A broker gets an order from a small investor to buy 100 shares of International Nickel. Question: Where will he buy it?

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a major new policy step, disclosed today that it would shortly propose that Congress consider legislation designed to permit investment advisory concerns to sell their businesses at a profit under certain circumstances.

The Nixon Administration's stance against busing as a means of school integration has forced the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., to drop, or at least hold up, its plans for a broad range of lawsuits involving the quality of integrated education.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 18 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed in principle to establish a standing committee, with an equal number of members from each side, to examine any charges of violations of the proposed limitations on strategic arms, a reliable source reported today.

Anne Murray came into Paul Colby's Bitter End Wednesday night with some impressive credentials. The Canadian singer has been a regular on the Glenn Campbell television show, she is the first Canadian woman to win a gold record (for her version of "Snowbird"), and she is a virtual entertainment business institution in her native country.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Information that could alert the Federal Housing Administration to conditions that lead to foreclosures in New York City is routinely supplied to others, but not to the F.H.A., an official of a title insurance company told a Senate subcommittee here today.

TRENTON, May 18 -- For many New Jersey political leaders it didn't seem to make any sense. Here was a Republican Governor urging a Legislature controlled by Republicans to approve the most progressive, urban-oriented, socially conscious tax-reform program ever proposed in the state's history.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 18 -- The murder and conspiracy trial of a Suffolk County lawyer, John O. Hughes, got under way today, with Assistant District Attorney Patrick Henry telling the all-male jury that Mr. Hughes was the "innovator, the director and producer -- the mastermind of the murder."
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Corporate profits before taxes rose by $5.6-billion, or 6.5 per cent, in the first quarter to a record annual rate of $91.6-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
Sudden Sam McDowell's unbeaten five-game winning record was suddenly interrupted by the surging Cincinnati Reds yesterday in San Francisco's Candlestick Park.
Some 500 employes of Nathan's Famous, Inc., ended a 44-day strike yesterday with the settlement of some issues and an agreement to go to arbitration over issues still unresolved, including wages.

HARTFORD, May 18 -- Connecticut lawmakers, apparently unwilling to plunge into a politically hazardous public debate on abortion, maintained their distance from the issue today despite gathering public interest in a hearing that is to begin tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Nixon has accepted the resignation of Nathaniel Samuels of New York as the fourth-ranking official of the State Department and praised him for "distinguished service during the past three years."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- For over a quarter of a century the United States and the Soviet Union have been concentrating on the issues that divided them -- Berlin, the Middle East, Korea, Vietnam, Cuba and the organization of Western Europe -- but now, after many savage differences and pointless miseries, their leaders are getting together in Moscow to talk about limited but important areas of cooperation.

MEMPHIS, May 18 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell, one of the shortest hitters on the tour, went around the long, tough Colonial Country Club course in a three-under-par 69 today for a share of the first-round lead in the $175,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced plans today to build huge, heavily guarded steel and concrete storage vaults on or just below the earth's surface where potentially dangerous radioactive wastes of an ever-expanding nuclear industry "can be safely isolated for centuries if necessary."

Environmentalists were undoubtedly pleased last week when New Jersey's Gov. William T. Cahill disclosed his reservations about the proposed Tocks Island Reservoir and Recreation Area on the Delaware River.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 18 -- Miss Ella Dene Farnsworth was married here this afternoon to Eric Bradford Paul. Elder Marion G. Romney, a member of the Quorum of Twelve Apostles of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony in the Salt Lake Temple (Mormon).
group of boxers representing New York City prevented it from being a great night for the Irish last night in the Felt Forum by defeating the Irish Olympic team, 6 bouts to 4.
Silver futures dropped yesterday.

Your [May 12] editorial supporting the recent action by the House of Representatives in adopting the Nixon Administration's substitute proposal to increase the minimum wage to $1.80 an hour and then $2 per hour over a two-year period appears to fly in the face of your known commitment to social progress as well as historic economic fact.
To open its four-day season through tomorrow night, the Juilliard Dance Ensemble presented a concert in memory of Doris Humphrey Wednesday night at the Juilliard Theater.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Spokesmen for migrant farm workers petitioned the Justice Department today to halt the influx of illegal alien harvesters by prosecuting the growers who hire them.

The New York Philharmonic's subscription season ended last Saturday night. As usual, out went the seats on Philharmonic Hall's main floor; in went the special flooring and tables; up went the decorations, inside and out.

MEXICO CITY, May 18 -- The Mexican Government has announced the "Mexicanization" of the country's sulphur industry with the acquisition of Azufrera Panamericana, a company that is 34 per cent owned by Pan American Sulphur Company, a United States concern.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- While this Sunday's antiwar march is expected to be much like those before it here, the civil disobedience planned for Monday at the Pentagon will probably be more like the 1967 march on the Defense Department headquarters than last year's May Day.

BALTIMORE, May 18 -- Arthur Herman Bremer, the 21-year-old former Milwaukee busboy who is accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace, was portrayed today as tired, hungry and down to his last $2 by the time he reached the Maryland shopping center where the Governor was struck down Monday afternoon.

The world of bridge lost one of its most colorful and dynamic citizens when Al Sobel died in Memorial Hospital here yesterday after a long illness. He was a man of many talents, and he played many roles in the course of a long and full life.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The last two Soviet freighters reported approaching Haiphong have been diverted to other ports, Administration officials said today.

SILVER SPRING, Md., May 18 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama still paralyzed from his hips down, began a program of physical therapy today but there was no decision when and where a bullet in his spinal canal would be removed.

A coalition of black community organizations announced yesterday that it had reached agreements with two of the three network-owned New York stations for a voice in management, planning and production of black-oriented programs.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota opened what he said would be a "rugged, hard-hitting" California primary campaign by challenging his principal opponent, Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, to a series of televised debates.

With its abrupt changes of mood and jarring imagery, Walter Hadler's "Mutilation" is very much in the Theater Genesis tradition. MONTREAL, May 18 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins, New York Rangers, Chicago Black Hawks and Montreal Canadiens filled all 12 berths on the 1971-72 National Hockey League's first and second All-Star teams announced today by the league.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House of Representatives, ignoring last-minute appeals by the White House and State Department, voted today to cut United States payments to the United Nations and eight of its agencies by $28.8-million.

Barbara Harris, Hal Holbrook, Bob Dishy, Stephen Elliot and Barry Primus have been signed to co-star in Arthur Miller's latest work, "The Creation of the World and Other Business," which Robert Whitehead will bring to Broadway Nov. 16.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) -- The Justice Department sued General Electric today, charging the major electrical manufacturer with violating antitrust laws since at least 1965.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Price Commission announced today new rent rules that will have the effect of lowering some rents under one-year leases signed since the beginning of the year and of keeping rent increases under new one-year leases to a maximum of 8 per cent.

Assemblyman Stephen S. Gottlieb said yesterday that he had withdrawn his challenge to Joseph Zaretzki, the State Senate minority leader, for the Democratic State Senate nomination in the June 20 primary.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Jerry W. Friedheim, the Pentagon spokesman, said today that Russian diplomats in various cities had been apparently boasting of a continued flow of material to North Vietnam, "and we have nothing new to say about it."
Amid the ceaseless rattle of 162 pairs of dice, the world's largest backgammon tournament, at the Pierre Hotel, sped last night toward its finish.
Monetary expansion, which earlier in the year had quickened at a rate that some economists regarded as excessive, has subsided somewhat in recent weeks, Federal Reserve figures indicated yesterday.

The New York Mets fielded a "second-string" line-up yesterday to give their front-runners a rest but lost absolutely no momentum as they completed a four-game sweep of the Montreal Expos for their seventh straight victory.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 18--Two robbers stole four paintings valued at more than $1-million from the Worcester Art Museum yesterday and fled after shooting a guard who tried to question them.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The Xerox Corporation plans to introduce its long-awaited color copier next year.

Walter A. Fallon was yesterday named president and chief executive officer of the Eastman Kodak Company and Gerald B. Zornow was elected chairman as Dr. Louis K. Eilers stepped down as chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Friday, May 19 -- An explosion occurred early today in a section of the Pentagon, Government officials said. There was no explanation, nor a report of damages.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 18 (Reuters) -- Communist troops have overrun Khong Sedone, a provincial capital in southern Laos, American sources said today.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 -- The booing for Freddie Lewis, the often maligned Indiana Pacer guard, turned to cheers tonight. The little guard scored two free throws with nine seconds to play and gave the Pacers a 100-99 comeback victory over the New York Nets before a sellout crowd of 10,079 at the Indiana State Fairgrounds Coliseum.

PARIS -- The Queen of England's unprecedented second state visit here went off well, as these things always do. The French, who make the best bread and circuses, put themselves out to produce a good show including a display of English weather.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- President Nixon's talks with Soviet leaders next week are expected to touch on the situation of Soviet Jews, which has been a source of friction between the two governments in the past.

A non-registered secondary offering of 362,252 common shares of the Fluor Corporation was priced yesterday by Salomon Brothers at $19.75 a share. The company's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed at that price, up 1/8 for the day.
DENVILLE, N.J., May 18 -- Don Massengale of Elmwood, N.Y., a former touring pro, finished strongly today and won the $25,000 Dodge open golf tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club.
The 23d annual Armed Forces Day Parade, which had been scheduled to start Saturday at 2:30 P.M. on upper Fifth Avenue, was canceled yesterday because of the possibility of violence.

The International Harvester Company reported yesterday that its net income in the quarter ended April 30 was 45 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year, when operations were affected by a strike. Sales of the producer of trucks, farm equipment and construction equipment rose 14 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Nixon and Soviet leaders are expected to announce in Moscow next week the formation of a Soviet-American commission to coordinate trade and economic policies, Administration sources said today.

NEWARK, May 18 -- John V. Kenny, the so-called "little leader" of Hudson County Democratic politics for more than two decades, pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today to six counts of income tax evasion.
Owners of rent-controlled apartment houses in the Bronx announced yesterday a move to halt employe wage increases despite the warning of a strike by Local 82E of the Building Service Employes Union.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- In a case of potentially major importance to Japanese-United States trade and to American consumers, the Treasury announced today it was investigating whether a whole series of Japanese Government tax and other incentives to exports of consumer electronic products, such as television sets, constituted an illegal subsidy.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 18 -- The former coordinator of research contracts at the State University of New York at Stony Brook was indicted today on 59 charges of forgery and grand larceny in connection with thefts of research funds from the university and bilking the predominantly black Wyandanch School District out of funds in connection with an alleged college-level research project.

A reputed gambler, loan shark and organized-crime figure in Brooklyn and Long Island -- Paul Vario of Island Park, L. I. -- was arrested yesterday on charges of conspiring to evade Federal income taxes on money pocketed from his gambling enterprises.

The City Club of New York, which has been calling attention to the city's design quality or lack of it for the last decade -- in particular by withholding the awards of its Bard Awards program -- has announced two prize-winning buildings this year.

PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 18 -- A night at the opera in Pyongyang is a revolutionizing experience. At least that is the intention of the Korean People's Army Art Troupe, whose production of "A True Daughter of the Party" was seen here.
Offtrack betting on the Preakness began here yesterday, and Riva Ridge's admirers immediately made the Kentucky Derby winner an early 1-10 favorite.
Confidence in President Nixon's handling of Vietnam has sagged notably in recent weeks among those who voted in Michigan's Democratic primary this week, according to a New York Times survey.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- With President Nixon's departure for Moscow less than two days away, Washington seems relatively unexcited about his summit session, which may prove the most fruitful of all the postwar Soviet-American meetings.
BALTIMORE, May 18 -- The draw for post positions for Saturday's 97th running of the Preakness took place today at Pimlico Race Course with the expected nine names entered.

LONDON, May 18 -- William Whitelaw, the British official who administers Northern Ireland, charged here today that the Irish Republican Army was seeking to provoke a Protestant backlash that could plunge the province into new sectarian strife.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Three national organizations petitioned the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs today to "decriminalize marijuana," reducing penalties for use or sale of the drug from felonies to misdemeanors.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 18 -- Senator John L. McClellan at the age of 76 is in the toughest re-election fight of his 35-year Congressional career.

HOUSTON, May 18 -- The "weight of power" is in the hands of the Middle East oil-producing countries in their efforts to join the international oil companies in the operation of concessions, J. K. Jamieson, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reported to shareholders today at their annual meeting.

MANGUM, Okla., May 16 -- It rained here last Thursday night. That event, probably even more than last weekend's 63d annual high school reunion, was the most celebrated happening in Greer County. Mangum is the center of the Dust Bowl of the nineteen-thirties, the place the Okies left for California when a prolonged drought and a scorching sun turned the sandy plains into a plaything for the winds.

CRUGERS, N, Y., May 18 (AP) -- The chairman of an Atomic Energy Commission panel blamed Consolidated Edison today for delays in the licensing process involving the utility's second nuclear power plant.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 18 -- Senator George McGovern was scheduled to check his Democratic Presidential campaign into the Benson Hotel here tonight, but he wound up instead in the Sheraton Motor Inn. The shift was occasioned by the discovery, to the dismay of campaign aides, that the Benson, unlike the Sheraton, had nonunion help.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Center for Auto Safety, calling Chrysler Corporation's "My Man in Detroit" program "a hoax on the public," has asked the Federal Trade Commission to lodge charges of unfair and deceptive trade practices against the company.

The Inmont Corporation yesterday announced plans to increase prices of many printing inks by 5 to 10 per cent soon. Inmont is the world's largest producer of inks for the printing, publishing and packaging markets.

DACCA, Bangladesh, May 19 -- Officials of the United States Agency for International Development are negotiating an economic aid agreement with Bangladesh on terms described by an American spokesman as "the most generous and flexible ever offered by the United States to any country."

ENGENE, Ore., May 24 (AP) -- Representative Patsy T. Mink of Hawaii, citing her poor showing in the Oregon primary yesterday, has withdrawn as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, an aide said today.

Carl Morton of the Expos, who gave up more runs than any other pitcher in the National League last season and hadn't been doing much better this season, tossed a one-hitter last night and defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-1, in Montreal.

Ralph Nader contended yesterday that the private pension system represented one of the "most comprehensive consumer frauds" that many Americans ever encounter. At the same time, the consumer advocate outlined details of a plan for restructuring the system so as to provide vesting for an individual from the first day and also give every employe greater control over his share of pension funds.

EDGARTOWN, Mass. -- A sharp northeast wind was shredding the tops of the combers. Despite the bright sunlight, the morning was raw, but we had the west-running tide we wanted, the tide that had been producing striped bass the previous several days off Wasque Point on Martha's Vineyard's south shore.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A major study by the Brookings Institution concludes that the Federal Government has already "overcommitted" for the next two years all the revenues it can expect from a growing economy and cannot spend more on solving social or other problems without a big tax increase.
At $200,000 a minute, five potential National Hockey League franchise holders made their pitch to the league yesterday to field one of two clubs that will be added in 1974.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 24 (AP) -- A European team seeking to climb Mount Everest has turned back short of its goal for the second consecutive year, leaving unconquered the treacherous southwest face of the world's highest mountain.

Dr. Richard Burack's May 13 letter concerning generic versus brand-name drugs is fraught with half-truths and unwarranted slurs both on the medical profession and the pharmaceutical industry. In addition, it is tragic that Dr. Burack misinforms the public on so vital a matter as prescription drugs.

Ever since "My Michael" appeared in Hebrew in 1968, Amos Oz has been considered one of Israel's best young novelists. Now 33, he has published two novels, two novellas, short stories and various political, social and literary essays. But advance rumors hardly prepare one for this first translation of his major work.

In the April 30 column of his weekly advertisement in the Times' Week in Review, Albert Shanker gave a distorted impression of the contents of my article on full state funding of schools in the March 31 Wall Street Journal, attacked what he called my "dangerous" views and held them up to ridicule ("shoddy reasoning").
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Pentagon reported today that additional B-52 bombers were being sent to Southeast Asia for use in the Vietnam war.
HANOI, North Vietnam, May 24 -- The mood in Hanoi's small diplomatic community this week is strange: it is a little like being in the quiet of a storm center.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Conflicting pleas for more liberal methadone treatment for heroin addicts and warnings that methadone will compound existing addiction problems were aired today before the Senate Subcommittee on Alcoholism and Narcotics.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Brookings Institution outlined today a way to increase Federal tax collections by $13.5-billion with a tax-reform program that would concentrate on reducing present tax preferences, rather than eliminating them.

Your rather murky May 16 editorial on the city budget suggests, if we understand it, that (1) there is something questionable about the process of reducing the budget gap as new revenues are supplied by the competent legislative authorities and (2) the executive management of city government has suffered from an insufficient "mayoral mandate" for productivity improvement.
Bond prices continued to forge ahead yesterday, though not with quite as much enthusiasm as earlier in the week.

PALMDALE, Calif., May 24 -- The choice for Californians, as Senator Hubert H. Humphrey explains it, is between a "jobs man" like himself and a Democratic opponent who he said would put thousands of aerospace workers on unemployment and saddle the rest with a $72-billion welfare program.
After declining for two days, prices of soybeans and grains futures bounded back yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as bargain hunters entered the market.

A research group, including leading American biologists, lawyers and theologians, has raised questions about the psychological and social impact of mass screening for such genetic characteristics as sickle cell and Tay-Sachs disease.
The Fire Department will go before the Board of Estimate today to argue for the first stage of citywide implementation of its new two-wag oral communications system for reporting fires.

The Franklin New York Corporation announced yesterday the election of Paul Luftig, 42 years old, as president and chief administrative officer of both the company and its principal subsidiary, the Franklin National Bank.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- Union postal workers picketed post offices across the nation today, demanding settlement of local bargaining disputes and the right to strike.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 -- Senator George McGovern has accumulated more than one-third of the 1,509 delegate votes needed to win the Democratic Presidential nomination and has the second one-third clearly within sight.
A secret 1970 report by the New Jersey Health Department contends that up to 82 per cent of New Jersey's restaurants are unsanitary.

ALBANY, May 24 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today a bill creating a state board to oversee the siting of electric power generating plants to assure that they will be compatible with their environment.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 -- Opposition to the proliferation of automobiles and policemen is not normally the route to political success in the American city, but -- among other things -- it worked for Neil Goldschmidt. Yesterday, aided by a McGovern-like army of volunteers, he became at 31 this city's Mayor -- the youngest and maybe the most provocative big-city mayor in the country.

"Nineteen feet is definitely within reach." Bob Seagren said yesterday, after the 1968 Olympic champion had conquered five years of frustration with his first 18-foot pole vault in a record-tying duel in the sun with Kjell Isaksson of Sweden.

An increasingly affluent Japan offers a market for all kinds of American products from golf clubs to lipsticks, members of a Japanese trade mission said here yesterday. The mission seeks to encourage exports from the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A Federal district judge today stripped the leadership of the United Mine Workers of America of its trusteeship rights in seven districts, a decision that had been sought for eight years by union reformers.

The first two American fliers to shoot down five North Vietnamese MIG's are being treated here to two days on the town for what Navy spokesmen describe variously as "a little exposure and a little reward," an information tour and a move to get them home before their luck ran out.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- The trend of record 1971 sales and earnings is continuing, stockholders of The Times-Mirror Company were told at their annual meeting here today. The cash dividend "shall certainly increase" when government economic controls are eased, Franklin D. Murphy, chairman, said.

The Supreme Court decisions permitting criminal convictions by less than unanimous juries and narrowing witnesses' immunity against self-incrimination are disquieting in their practical effects but, even more, as portents of things to come.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 25 -- American Air Force and Navy jet aircraft heavily attacked North Vietnamese power plants and oil storage tanks in the Hanoi Haiphong area Tuesday and yesterday, the United States command reported.

A band of high school boys, many of them armed with knives, went on a subway rampage in midtown around noon yesterday, robbing, beating people up and generally terrorizing those aboard a BMT train bound for Astoria, Queens.

Witnesses testifying before the City Commission on Human Rights agreed yesterday that society must provide former convicts with meaningful, well paying jobs as soon as they leave prison. But there was no agreement on how this goal should be achieved.
Two steel industry leaders called for governmental action here yesterday to help their industry compete in foreign markets.

A city budget slashed by $35-million through the elimination of a proposed rise in water rates was approved last night by the Board of Estimate at 11:43 P.M., just 17 minutes before a midnight deadline under the City Charter and over vehement objections from Mayor Lindsay.

In 1968, the city's Democratic county leaders opposed Eugene J. McCarthy and Paul O'Dwyer in the New York Presidential and senatorial primary. Nevertheless, Mr. McCarthy and Mr. O'Dwyer scored decisive victories.

Chicago, the rock group, is in Carnegie Hall this week for what has become an annual weekly engagement. It is one of the rare super-groups that continue to make bookings, wherever possible, to appear before relatively small audiences, rather than the huge crowds of stadium-type concerts.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The United States Government has chartered the largest American merchant ship, the tanker Manhattan, to serve as a floating grain silo off the coast of Bangladesh to bypass damaged and congested port facilities and to speed up distribution of food to the country's interior.

A gathering of 3-year-olds pointing for the Belmont Stakes and the Withers and older horses competing in the $28,225 Edgemere Handicap combined to keep stakes-minded followers of form interested at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- The House Administration Committee reached tentative agreement today on revisions in disclosure provisions of the new Federal campaign spending law.

The local branches of 10 trade unions gave their support yesterday to former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein in his primary contest with Representative John J. Rooney for the Democratic nomination in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- With the signing today of the Soviet-United States agreement on a joint space mission in 1975, yet another space scientist of the Soviet Union was publicly identified for the first time.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Following is a table from the Brookings Institution study, "Setting National Priorities: The 1973 Budget," showing the changing composition of Federal expenditures in the 10 years starting with the fiscal year 1963:
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Legislation to set up a national no-fault automobile insurance system was approved today by the Senate Commerce Committee, 13 to 4.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (Reuters) -- Total reserve assets of the United States increased by $15-million in April to $12,285,000,000 while the gold stock remained unchanged, the Treasury reported today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24 -- Kentucky Republicans began their usual uphill battle for a United States Senate seat today after giving their nomination for the post to former Gov. Louie B. Nunn in the primary yesterday.

If you have to start from scratch on a fall wardrobe, buy a sweater. It's the safest road to fashion. Add a pair of pants with cuffs, a high waistband and pleats and you're on your way. Your coat can be a flaring topper or a jacket with a belt that wraps like a bathrobe, either one about fingertip length.
In recent years, Wall Street has had a love affair with the hot shot research analyst who searched the land for that concept stock -- the company with a story that would take it to the moon.

By the will of whatever gods control. East Coast film distribution, no fewer than three possession - by - evil - spirits movies have come to New York in the past seven days. And of these three, in some aspects the scariest and in all respects the worst in Waris Hussein's "The Possession of Joel Delaney," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and R.K.O. 59th Street East Twin 2 theaters.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 24 -- Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority, anxious about growing Protestant militancy and uncertain about the terror tactics of the Irish Republican army, has made tentative steps toward supporting William Whitelaw, the British administrator in Ulster.

BALTIMORE, May 24 -- With a nervous smile flickering across his face, Arthur Herman Bremer stood before a Federal judge here today and pleaded not guilty to charges arising from the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.
A teacher's right to express political views that do not disrupt school work was vigorously supported here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

The Bread and Puppet Theater offers innocence, spirituality and extraordinary theatrical ingenuity -- three qualities that are greatly in evidence in the troupe's "The Stations of the Cross," its Easter play having an unseasonal but welcome New York premiere engagement at St. Clement's Church.
BRUSSELS, May 24 -- Defense ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were briefed today on plans for the largest military exercise in the alliance's 23-year history.

The Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship reached its semi-final stage as a result of three matches played this week. The semi-final draw matches a team headed by Sam Stayman against one led by Jeff Rubens, and a John Solodar-captained team against one led by George Lewis.

PORTLAND, May 24 -- Senator George McGovern swept past a field of 10 other Presidential possibilities yesterday to win the Oregon primary with 50 per cent of the vote. He captured all of the state's 34 votes at the Democratic National Convention.

W. Glenn Gordon has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Turbodyne Corporation, effective June 30. He replaces Arthur P. Burris, who is retiring but will continue as vice chairman of the board of directors.
In an effort to stress winning of the games rather than merely qualifying for the playoffs, the National Football League's owners yesterday agreed to a change in figuring the standing of the teams.

MIAMI, May 24 (AP) -- When Joseph Armstrong pleaded guilty to armed robbery last month, Criminal Court Judge Al Sepe called it an "environmentally motivated crime." The same judge found him a job and freed him from jail when he discovered Armstrong's family living in a rat-infested house.

John Jay Iselin, vice president and general manager of WNET/13 here, was named yesterday to the additional post of station managing director. This will place him in charge of all broadcasting activities, including the planning and production of programs for national distribution by the Public Broadcasting Service.

From an unpromising beginning, Senator George McGovern continues to move forward in his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination. His victories in Oregon and Rhode Island bring his delegate total to above 500. His capture of most of New York's delegates now seems a runaway certainty. If he adds California's 271 delegates in that state's winner-take-all primary June 6, he will have amassed approximately 1,000 votes and will be far ahead of his rivals.
SAN JOSE, Calif., May 24 -- The defense in the murder, kidnapping and conspiracy trial of Angela Davis rested today without calling the defendant.
A chartreuse is a fancy dish disguised as a plain dish. The name is attributed to the monks of Chartreuse who are supposed to have invented it to dodge fast days.

It is a chess maxim that no one ever won a game by resigning. This means, obviously, that if one plays on in a lost position there is always the chance, however remote, that one's opponent may make a mistake and throw away his advantage.
Theodore W. Kheel called on the Federal Government yesterday to end all capital grants to the Port of New York Authority for mass-transportation projects.

For some years now, the music of many of the world's oldest cultures has been flowing toward a confluence with our own Western varieties, and the results have been unquestionably vitalizing, if sometimes confusing.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A novel lawsuit by Consumers Union charged today that the recent agreement negotiated by the State Department and foreign steel producers to limit steel imports into the United States for the next three years violates the antitrust laws.

Many of the antique pins and necklaces sold yesterday at an improvised boutique to raise funds for the Association Residence for Women were owned by residents of the home who had worn the ornaments as girls and young women.

The City Stores Company, whose retail chain includes Franklin Simon, W. Sloane and Hearn's in the New York metropolitan area, had slightly increased sales but a wider loss in the 13 weeks ended April 29, shareholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., expects that with the "improved economic conditions" the current fiscal year will bring a turnaround in the company's results, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, said at the annual meeting here yesterday.

HARTFORD, May 24 -- In the aftermath of the signing of Connecticut's tough new abortion bill, a number of legislators attributed the measure's quick and decisive passage to pressure from the Roman Catholic Church and Gov. Thomas J. Meskill at a time when many members of the General Assembly had been caught off guard by the suddenness of the issue.

Britain's Royal Ballet is never exactly full of surprises, but its repertory program at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday and Tuesday had its own modicum of shock. The company, led by Rudolf Nureyev, no less, performed an American modern dance work to electronic music by Karlheinz Stockhausen.
Homeowners need to keep good financial records. That has been proven by a recent case tried in the United States Tax Court, Cenedella v. the Internal Revenue Service.

The American Academy of Arts and Sciences governing council has denied a recommended award to Ezra Pound, the poet, on the alleged grounds it found his political and racial views obnoxious. A four-man literary committee recommended Mr. Pound, who lives in Italy, for the $2,000 Emerson - Thoreau Medal, but the council voted down the award, 13 to 9.

WASHINGTON -- In 1912 Senator Robert LaFollette wrote, "I have become more and more impressed with the deep underlying singleness of the issue. It is not the tariff or conservation or the currency. It is not the trusts. The supreme issue, involving all the others, is the encroachment of the powerful few upon the rights of the many."

HEIDELBERG, Germany, May 24 (AP) -- Bombs went off tonight in two cars parked inside the United States Army's European command headquarters compound, killing three American servicemen and injuring five other persons.

TORONTO, May 24 -- Arthur Herman Bremer, the man accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama in Laurel, Md., nine days, was in Ottawa during President Nixon's visit to Canada last month, The Toronto Star reported tonight.
In Idaho, the P.T.A. has sued Government officials for "misusing" school funds.
Some notes on television ventures in news and public affairs:

ROME, May 24 -- Pope Paul VI, in an address today to the first group of pilgrims from Hungary to Rome since the end of World War II, expressed his good wishes for the church in their country, "and also for the state."

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner ordered an audit yesterday of some of the administrative and employment practices of Community School Board 23, in the Oceanhill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn, to determine the truth of charges of political favoritism brought against the board by a parents' group.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- Historically the United States has been a stanch supporters of the United Nations, not only financially, but morally.

Walter Seeley of Sayville, L. I., a 28-year-old Irish-American who doubles as a roofer when he's not boxing, beat Azael Curet of New York on a unanimous decision in their 10-round featherweight bout at the Felt Forum last night.
The Monmouth County Kennel Club, organized in 1908, never has tried to have a large membership.
A 22-year-old wounded Vietnam veteran who the police said had been AWOL from Fort Dix, N. J., for the last year, surrendered to the City Fire Marshal's office yesterday morning on an arson charge.

Two members of the Association for a Better New York went to a training session yesterday for policemen intending to talk about the problems of the business community and what the police should do about them.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Half the horses racing in New England are owned by front-men for the mob, Joe (The Baron) Barboza testified today before a Congressional committee investigating underworld influence in sports.

The most recent assassination attempt against a public figure should come as no surprise. When the entire social and legal structure accepts, condones and even encourages violence to solve problems (e.g. war, electric chairs), can we really expect that individuals will not consider similar methods as viable means to settle differences?

CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, told Illinois Democrats tonight that the "cruelest single irony" of the Nixon Administration was the President's failure to get gun controls.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had approved a rule allowing specialist firms to become publicly owned. Two years ago, brokerage firms gained permission from the Big Board to go public.

"They're at a real impasse," Councilman Bertram L. Gelfand, Bronx Democrat, said early yesterday afternoon. "I will predict that there will be some Criminal Court judges made between now and midnight."

Pro football has been attacked again on the vulnerable question of its immunity from the antitrust laws and once more the attack came from within. Thirty-two players filed a class action suit late Tuesday in Minneapolis against the National Football League.

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 25 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and President Nixon signed an agreement on space cooperation yesterday, proclaiming a commitment to carry out a joint flight with linked Soviet and American spacecraft in 1975.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- The Transportation Department announced today that two major tire manufacturers would recall 100,000 tires that failed to meet Government safety standards. It said continued use of the tires "could be dangerous under certain circumstances."

LONDON, May 24 -- In the biggest and most bitterly fought take-over battle ever seen here, Watney Mann, Ltd., the huge beer, whisky and pub group, today offered its stockholders a free share for every four they own if they would turn down a billion-dollar merger bid from Grand Metropolitan Hotels, Ltd.

OMAHA, May 24 -- In what amounts to another physical exam for him, Joe Frazier will defend his world heavyweight boxing title tomorrow night against Ron Stander, an obscure challenger whose local popularity is his dominant attribute.
ATLANTA, May 24 (UPI) -- The Atlanta metropolitan area may some day be patterned after London -- the central city surrounded by a "green belt" with a ring of satellite cities or "new towns."

Like any large and complex subject, American cooking can be interpreted from many points of view, all different, each true to its way. This is the case with three American cookbooks that have just been published.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- Peking was an adventure; Moscow is a meeting of merchants. In China, the President was Marco Polo, marveling at the novelty of it all on a journey of discovery. Here he is the traveling salesman, hopeful but cagey about opening some new accounts in a familiar territory.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- Republicans, fearful of losing Ohio's 25 electoral votes in the November Presidential balloting because of party in-fighting, marshaled their forces today "to show that Ohio has united support behind President Nixon."

More than space research or scientific progress is involved in the agreement on space cooperation signed by President Nixon and Premier Kosygin in Moscow yesterday. The decision to have American and Soviet astronauts work together intimately so that space ships from the two nations can rendezvous and dock in the summer of 1975 has, above all, immense political significance.

American Motors, which named the New York office of Cunningham Walsh to handle its national advertising account on March 24, announced yesterday that the San Francisco office would handle its dealer advertising.
Glamour issues and some blue-chip stocks set the pace yesterday as the stock market registered a modest advance in stepped-up trading.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- Senator George McGovern's forces, who have stung Democratic party regulars this spring with a string of surprising victories in nonprimary states, fell a little short of their expectations in Missouri yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the Minister of Culture, used a news conference for visiting journalists today to deliver an attack on the author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- "I'd rather negotiate with Brezhnev than Kosygin," a senior Western Ambassador confided. "Kosygin is the toughest negotiator of the whole damn bunch. When he has instructions from the Politburo, he doesn't budge an inch.

DETROIT, May 24 (UPI) -- The Ford Motor Company hopes to complete retesting of its automobile engines to meet 1973 emission standards and still meet scheduled Sept. 22 introductions of its new models, a top company executive said today.
CHICAGO, May 24 -- Willie Mays finally saw the New York Mets lose a game today.

Three months ago President Nixon signed a bill theoretically forbidding the hunting of animals from airplanes. The law, greeted by wildlife enthusiasts with more pleasure than was warranted, now turns out to be full of holes. As a result, so are hundreds of Alaskan wolves, blasted by shotguns from the windows of low-flying planes.
BOSTON, May 24 (UPI) -- A bill granting the rights of children to fetuses from the moment of conception has won initial approval by the Massachusetts House on an overwhelming vote.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24 -- "We're here on a morale boosting mission," the Cabinet Minister said to foreign newsmen in Hue.

A 32-year-old Long Island man, formerly a partner in a Wall Street firm, has been arrested on a 12-count indictment involving the theft of $1.68-million, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Price Commission ordered Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc., today to roll back its prices, asserting that the big New York retail grocery chain had illegally raised prices and exceeded its permissible profit margin.
GOYA, Argentina, May 15 -- Nothing has brought home the problem of political torture to Argentines more forcibly than the experiences of Norma Morello.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- "Don't just do something," reads the poster in the poverty worker's office. "Stand there." It is a wry symbol of the harsh disillusionment with Federal social programs that has increasingly infused Washington.

The New York Aquarium at Coney Island was closed by a strike yesterday and plans were made by management and labor to meet at 1 P.M. today with the State Mediation Board at 270 Broadway. Supervisors are caring for the fishes and mammals.

PARIS, May 24 -- President Nixon called today for a "free and fair system of trade" as the United States and France tried to patch up differences that could hold up reform of the world monetary and trading order.

Earnings of the General Foods Corporation in the quarter ended April 1 continued below year-earlier levels, resulting in a decline in fiscal-year earnings for the first time in 20 years, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In their agreement today on a docking of spacecraft in 1975, the United States and the Soviet Union took an important step toward a means of handling an emergency rescue in space, something both nations have always lacked.

Louis Beck, 70-year-old former confidential secretary to Surrogate Samuel DiFalco, was freed yesterday after pleading guilty to taking part in a conspiracy seeking to influence a Supreme Court justice in imposing sentence on a convicted extortionist.

DENVER, May 24 -- The administrative head of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. delivered a stinging rebuke to the denomination's General Assembly at its closing session today for its decision last Friday to withdraw from the Consultation on Church Union.

DETROIT, May 24 -- New-car sales in mid-May surged to 277,993, up 14 per cent from 243,075 a year ago and a mid-May record for the American industry. All four com panies reported gains in the sale of domestic-type cars. Here are the May 11-20 figures:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Three years before the Communist take-over in China, President Harry S. Truman warned President Chiang Kaishek that "selfish interests of extremist elements," equally in the Chinese Nationalist and Communist parties were threatening civil war.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 -- Yonkers Raceway ended its first-half, 73-program meeting tonight with deficits of 16 per cent in attendance and 7.3 per cent in mutual handle, as harness racing shifts tomorrow night to Roosevelt Raceway here fr the first of 51 cards running through July 22.
HANOI, North Vietnam, May 24 -- A leading member of North Vietnam's Communist party Politburo, Truong Chinh, was reported today to have said the war was "reaching the crucial stage."
The Gulf Oil Corporation confirmed yesterday that it would buy "very important quantities of Algerian crude oil starting in 1972 and until 1980."

NEWARK, May 24 -- John V. Kenny, the Hudson County political leader who has spent 14 months in a Jersey City hospital contending he was too ill to stand trial on three Federal indictments. was committed today to a Federal medical center to determine whether he was well enough to go to prison.

Modest man that he is, Bob Lilly of the Dallas Cowboys downgrades the incident as having no significance. But there is no escaping the fact that he once hit the supposedly indestructible Jim Brown with such jarring force that the stunned fullback wandered groggily in the direction of the Dallas defensive huddle instead of heading for the Cleveland Browns' offensive huddle.

KILN, Miss., May 24 (UPI) -- Explosions and fire swept a military munitions plant near this small south Mississippi community today, sending incendiary flares hurtling into a smoke-filled sky and killing six persons.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Independent Democrats attempting to challenge Mayor Richard J. Daley and 58 other uncommitted Democratic National Convention delegates failed today to obtain a Federal court order preventing any interference with a Credentials Committee hearing to be held next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A former member of the Pay Board said today that it appeared "highly doubtful" that President Nixon's goal of reducing inflation to an annual rate of 2 to 3 per cent by the end of the year could be met.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- About 100 antiwar protesters, many of them prominent in the arts and sciences, were arrested today when they refused to leave the Capitol.
The police of the Missing Persons Bureau identified the bodies yesterday of the couple killed in a crash of a sightseeing helicopter April 17 in the East River near the Wall Street Heliport.

A mere seven weeks after having left Florida, Manager Ralph Houk finally found the opportunity last night to use that New York Yankee "depth" he had talked about so much during spring training, and it produced a 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians at the Stadium.

Miss Virginia Victoria Graham Menzies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Menzies of New York, Upper Brookville, L. I., London and Johannesburg, South Africa, was married in London yesterday afternoon to Claus G. Labes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Labes of Cologne, West Germany.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange recovered their slight loss on Tuesday and snapped back yesterday to 27.88, up 0.05, as measured by the index.

Repeating the threat of a hospital strike, Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers Union, charged yesterday that the League of Voluntary Hospitals had refused to bargain on a new contract and had broken off negotiations.

ROME, May 24 -- The police raided the offices of Corriere Della Sera of Milan, the newspaper with the largest circulation in Italy, and the home of one of its reporters early this morning in a broadening inquiry into terrorism.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 24 -- The symbol of Senator George McGovern's quest for another Democratic Presidential primary victory, in California on June 6, is the quotation that he carried in his suit coat pocket when he arrived here today.

Under threats of fines and suspensions, members of the National Basketball Association all-star squad will play a similar group of stars representing the American Basketball Association tonight at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I.
In the wake of the attack on Governor Wallace, the country asks itself: What can be done to stop these assaults on our leaders?
The $2.5-million pilot boat New York, the first newly constructed vessel of her type to make a debut here in 75 years, arrived yesterday after a 2,500-mile "maiden" voyage from Wisconsin.
PRAGUE, May 24 (Reuters) -- An internationally known Prague theater company said today it would give its last performance here June 10.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 24 -- Rhode Island's first Presidential primary, won yesterday by Senator George McGovern, attracted the lowest voter turn-out yet recorded in the long string of primaries this year.
WALPOLE, Mass., May 24 (UPI) -- Stanley R. Bond, who was awaiting trial for allegedly materminding a bank robbery in which a policeman was killed died today in Walpole State Prison in an explosion.
Dr. Perry Mandel, a Garden City radiologist who has been active in cancer prevention and detection programs, was elected president of the Nassau County Medical Society last night.
Mayor Lindsay told those attending a celebration of the centennial of the Brooklyn Bar Association last night that lawyers ought to help restore faith in government.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- McGeorge Bundy, adviser on national security to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, predicted today that the risk of large-scale war would be much less in the coming decade than at any time since World War II.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., May 24 -- A conspiracy to blow up the residence of the Soviet mission to the United Nations at Glen Cove was reported broken up here last night with the arrest of four reputed members of the Jewish Defense League.

In a May 3 news story, Joseph Novitzki refers to "sumptuous clubs that have been granted the officers" of the armed forces of Peru. Mr. Novitzki has either been misinformed or has only told a half-truth.
A number of major New York City banks, led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, have reduced the minimum rates they charge on loans to stockbrokers to 4 3/4 per cent from 5 per cent.

SILVER SPRING, Md., May 24 (UPI) -- Cheered by his showing in the Oregon primary, Gov. George C. Wallace visited today with a group of reporters for the first time since he was wounded and told them, "They say I'm doing fine."

ATLANTA, May 24 -- Golf's Westchester Classic, which has raised $1.5-million for six Westchester hospitals during the last five years, will be without Lee Trevino as a contestant this year because of the barring of touring caddies.
A Soviet space official spoke recently of a forthcoming meeting with American space engineers. Asked who would be on the American team, he replied without hesitation: "I hope Glynn Lunney."

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the staff of his Senate sub-committee on refugees estimated today that the renewed fighting in South Vietnam had resulted in 40,000 to 50,000 civilian war casualties, including about 15,000 dead, by the first week in May.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate gave its final approval today, 63 to 15, to legislation that would postpone the implementation of the orders of lower courts that require busing to desegregate schools.

A short-circuit in a major electrical transmission line in northern New Jersey yesterday knocked out service briefly for 133,000 customers in parts of three states and forced the Consolidated Edison Company to reduce its voltage output by 3 per cent in parts of New York City.
In the year's widest-ranging move against narcotics dealers, the police in 15 metropolitan-area counties arrested 128 alleged narcotics peddlers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The kids, the kids! Remember the kids? Of course. Who could forget? They were the hit of the sixties, the agony and the glory. Already we begin to miss them. The music is tired. Everybody is getting older, duller. The country feels knee-deep in lint.
Can a mother and father wearing blue and white arm bands make the East Side safe for private school children?

LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- British medical and legal experts have called on the Government to allow scientists to use human fetuses obtained in abortions for such projects as the search for a cancer cure.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

United Air Lines, Inc., a unit of UAL, Inc., announced yesterday that it has elected to exercise options to purchase seven more DC-10 trijet aircraft from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation at a cost of $130-million.

Joseph Papp, the theatrical producer who was one of 100 antiwar protesters arrested in Washington on Wednesday, was one of eight recipients yesterday of the 1972 New York State Awards for cultural contributions.

A letter handwritten by John Fitzgerald Kennedy in 1954, in which the then Senator explained why he had to miss one of the most controversial and politically significent votes of his Senate career -- the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy -- was sold at auction here last night.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced yesterday that it had approved two loans to Mexico totaling $110-million.

A fictitious marl-order university with a mythical faculty and administration bilked hundreds of aspiring students out of more than $200,000 in the last seven years, the United States Postal Service charged yesterday.
ROME, May 25 -- A parliamentary commission that has been investigating the Mafia for more than eight years today depicted the Sicilian criminal organization as a cancer spreading throughout Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said in a Senate speech today that "the Pentagon has artificially made it appear that the Soviet navy is a massive, modern force that directly threatens the United States" while "in fact, the United States leads the Soviet Union in almost every major naval category and current building programs will keep us on top."

A Federal grand jury that spent the last 18 months investigating pro football on alleged charges of monopoly and the boycotting of players has exonerated the National Football League, according to Pete Rozelle, its commissioner.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 25 -- As the harness racing scene shifted tonight from Yonkers Raceway to Roosevelt Raceway, an overwhelming majority of the 16,538 opening-night fans voiced their objection to the new exotic form of betting -- the "scramble."

Thanks to the influence and insistence of Tony Bennett, who is currently appearing in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the Waldorf's Peacock Alley has been opened up to jazz for the first time.
The arbitrator in the Bronx rent dispute recommended yesterday that the city issue an interim order by Wednesday granting all landlords in rent-controlled apartments a 7 1/2 per cent rent increase.
The unmanned Pioneer 10 spacecraft crossed the orbital path of Mars yesterday entering hitherto unexplored space on its way toward a planned rendezvous with the giant planet Jupiter.

In a major breakthrough for Senator George McGovern, Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, will endorse the South Dakota Senator's Presidential candidacy within the next week, sources close to Mr. McGovern and Mr. Esposito reported yesterday.
PARIS, May 25 (Reuters) -- Bomb blasts shook two American guildings here early today and two United States airline offices were evacuated after bomb threats.
Bob Gibson's five-game losing streak and the Pittsburgh Pirates' nine-game winning streak ended yesterday in St. Louis.
OROVILLE, Calif., May 25 (AP) -- A spray of gunfire in a courtroom today killed a lawyer and wounded a judge and a witness.

The Health Insurance Plan, the metropolitan area's only prepaid group practice medical plan, has received the approval of the State Insurance Department to increase subscriber rates an average of 29 per cent starting Aug. 1.

UNIONDALE, L.I., May 25 -Amid the usual abundance of spectacular individual plays and with plenty of running in both directions, the National Basketball Association's all-star team defeated the American Basketball Association's stars, 106-104, tonight before a crowd of 14,086 and a national television audience.

"I'm the only man in Yugoslavia who can't lie about his age," said President Tito as he celebrated his 80th birthday. His country welcomed his entry into the ranks of the octogenarians with a mass youth rally in Partizan Stadium in Belgrade. Mr. Tito joined hundreds of children from all over the country in a snack of juice and sweets.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The White House declared today that President Nixon and his Administration were opposed to any increase in Federal taxes "for the foreseeable future."

ELMIRA, N. Y., May 25 -- Charles James, the Quaker teacher who was discharged two and a half years ago from Addison Central High School near Elmira for wearing a black armband to class in protest against the war in Vietnam, today savored his vindication by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Every now and then performers arrive who somehow seem a little out of joint with time, their message appropriate for another day and place, but not in synchronization with this one.

TRENTON, May 25 -- Dr. James R. Cowan, New Jersey Commissioner of Health, said today that restaurants in the state were "very safe" despite a 1970 departmental report contending that 82 per cent of them were unsanitary.

EAST LOS ANGELES, May 25 -- Senator George McGovern devoted the first speech of his California campaign yesterday to an "eight-point program" for Mexican-Americans. Last Saturday, he interrupted his schedule to fly to Phoenix and accept the endorsement of Cesar Chavez, leader of the farm workers union.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A bill designed to strip the President of his power to keep Government information from Congress and the public was introduced today by Representative William S. Moorhead, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- "Substantial evidence" has been uncovered in recent days that Arthur Herman Bremer, who is accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, was also tracking President Nixon and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Federal sources said today.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- Willie Mays struck another blow for the aging today when he singled home the winning run in the 14th inning as the New York Mets defeated the Chicago Cubs, 3-2.

MOSCOW, May 25 -- Pyotr Y. Shelest, a reputedly conservative member of the Soviet Union's ruling Politburo, was dismissed today from the Communist party leadership of the Ukraine, which he had headed since 1963.

An apparent breach in horse-identification security will soon be plugged by a master list of registration numbers, a spokesman for The Jockey Club said yesterday.

Adrian M. Butash, director of marketing services for Hoechst Fibers, leafed through a portfolio of current fashion advertising yesterday afternoon. He didn't like what he saw and said so. He could afford to, none of them were his.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The five-year arms limitation agreement that President Nixon is expected to sign in Moscow would reportedly permit the Russians to replace all 288 of their largest land-based nuclear missiles with the much larger ones they are developing, each capable of carrying up to 20 warheads.

PARIS, May 25 (UPI) Injuries and defections plagued the French open tennis championships today as Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter, Lew Hoad and Marty Mulligan scratched from the singles.
The New York Raiders lived up to their World Hockey Association nickname yesterday, when they announced the signing of five players, three of whom jumped from the National Hockey League.

LONDON, May 25 -- William Whitelaw, who has administered Northern Ireland since Britain imposed direct rule two months ago, announced today the appointment of an advisory commission of seven Protestants and four Roman Catholics.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -The Government's composite index of leading economic indicators rose at near-boom proportions in March and April, the Commerce Department reported today.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 25 -- An 8-year-old girl suffering from a rare disease of the connective tissues was rushed to the intensive care unit of Long Island Jewish Hospital here this morning.
