WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, made a $10-billion mistake in calculating his proposed reduction in Pentagon spending, the Controller of the Defense Department told Congress today.

Well, yesterday the Interpublic Group of Companies and the Campbell-Ewald Company were doing a lot more than talking merger -their chiefs were signing an agreement under which Interpublic, the international communications complex, could acquire Detroit's No. 1 agency in the biggest deal of its kind in agency history.

CLOSTER, N. J. -- Growing up in an elegant restaurant in northern Italy is no way to prepare the palate for the southern Italian food served in most New York and New Jersey restaurants. And after 18 years away from her family's restaurant, Teresa Candler has turned into a missionary for the food of her native Turin.
It took Hank Aaron 18-plus seasons to catch Willie Mays in home runs. His next target is Babe Ruth's record.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A Florida schoolgirl, in plaid, bangs and green knee socks, told Congress today that she thought Saturday morning television commercials for children were deceptive and dangerous.

The decision of the Official wing of the Irish Republican Army to call off terrorist activities in Northern Ireland is as welcome as it is overdue. Though its operations were always on a lesser scale than those of the I.R.A. Provisionals, its withdrawal from violence will increase Roman Catholic pressures on its ultra-militant rivals to do likewise.

A rights offering of common shares of the Long Island Lighting Company became effective yesterday whereby holders of record at the close of business yesterday may subscribe for 2,021,806 shares at the rate of one share for each ten shares held as of May 31, 1972.
A siren sounded, and then another, and Detective Edwin Bailey Jr. smiled a woeful smile.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Nixon Administration said today that it would inform Congress fully of all private understandings reached with the Soviet Union about the arms limitation agreements signed in Moscow last Friday by President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader.
BUENOS AIRES, May 31 -- The Argentine military Government reportedly plans to issue a decree on Saturday curbing the operations of private petroleum companies in the country.

SANDWICH, England, May 31 (UPI) -- Dick Siderowf, the top American challenger, and Mike Bonallack of Britain, favored to win for the sixth time, made it to the round of 32 today in the British Amateur golf championship, but it was the end of the road for the boy wonder, Davey Robertson, the 14-year-old Scottish schoolboy champion.

The Consolidated Edison Company asked the State Public Health Service Commission yesterday to approve a proposed increase in gas rates averaging 17.2 per cent for about 1.2 million customers in the metropolitan area.

Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday placing on the November ballot a $1.15-billion environmental bond issue designed to pay for air, water and land conservation and antipollution projects in the state for the next five years.

EAST LOS ANGELES, May 31 -- The McGovern Presidential campaign has taken the television news release, an old idea that never worked very well before, and perfected it into a major political weapon here in California.

Francis Keppel, former United States Commissioner of Education, told the 1,460 students in the graduating class of Bernard M. Baruch College yesterday that they were "far better qualified" than "those of us who wandered innocent -as I did -into both business and government in the course of our lives."

LAIKHE, South Vietnam, May 31 -- Sgt. 1st. Cl. Jesse Yearta and a dozen other American advisers living in bunkers under the surrounded town of Anloc formed a betting pool weeks ago on when a Government relief column would push through to break the siege, now 55 days old, and enable the thousands of wounded Vietnamese soldiers there to get out. No one has won.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam, will be nominated as the Army's new Chief of Staff "within a few days" of President Nixon's return from his European summit trip tomorrow night, well-placed Army sources said today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a comprehensive new rule designed to safeguard customers' cash and securities that are in the hands of stockbrokers.
The City Planning Commission yesterday approved the creation of a Special South Street seaport District within the Manhattan Landing development along the East River.
Threads of New York University's troubled financial condition wove themselves into the fabric of the institution's 140th commencement yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden.

Last week, Elizabeth Drew of the public television network opened an interview with Senator George McGovern by asking him if it were not true that his program "seems to add up to quite a substantial and important change in the way this country works, economically and socially."

EUGENE, Ore., May 31 -- To West Coast sports fans who have enjoyed the first-name intimacy of such easily identifiable heroes as Wilt and O. J., Steve Prefontaine is "Pre," as in "Hey, wasn't Pre something out there today?"

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 31 (Reuters) -- John Paul Vann, the senior United States adviser to Military Region II, told newsmen here that a group of 100 North Vietnamese made contact by radio today with Government positions in Kontum and said they wanted to defect.

Howard C. Miller has been elected president and chief operating officer of the ITT Canteen Corporation, Chicago. He succeeds Patrick L. O'Malley, who has been elected chairman of the board and continues as chief executive officer. Mr. Miller formerly was a vice president of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, parent company of ITT Canteen.

Now you see it; now you don't. The right to vote recently extended to young Americans between the ages of 18 and 21 by Federal court decree and by amendment to the Federal Constitution is a right which youths residing in New York State will not be able to exercise in this month's primary elections. The Supreme Court that giveth has now become the Supreme Court that taketh away.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The director of the New Orleans Crime Commission told a Congressional committee today that the owner of New Orleans Saints football team, John Mecom Jr., was associated in a business deal with a convicted gambler and with a developer who had ties with an alleged organized crime kingpin, Carlos Marcello.

ROME, May 31 -- The governor of the Bank of Italy, Guido Carli, said today that the recovery of the Italian economy was slowing. He also suggested that gold and Special Drawing Rights would be essential in correcting exchange rate fluctuations.

On Monday, most of the Protestants of a tiny Puerto Rican barrio 20 miles outside San Juan gathered for a gay send-off for their pastor and seven friends who left for an 18-day pilgrimage to the Holy Land, and, later, some sight-seeing in Switzerland and Italy.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that Democratic and Republican leaders should consider uniting behind a one-term fusion candidate for Mayor of New York City next year.

MILWAUKEE, May 31 -- Sparky Lyle, the relief pitcher who has nearly as many saves this year as the entire Yankee relief corps compiled last year, came close to needing saving himself tonight, but he and the Yankees held on and struggled to a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger, reporting that a sampling indicated 37 per cent of January's new relief cases in one center were ineligible, called yesterday for "revision of the acceptance process."

Representative Richard H. Poff of Virginia, one of the Southern conservatives President Nixon considered nominating for the United States Supreme Court, was nominated to the Supreme Court of his home state by Republican Gov. Linwood Holton.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to cut off Federal welfare payments to drug addicts and alcoholics who are not undergoing treatment.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 31 -- Mrs. Austin Straub of Huntington Country Club shot 39, 36 -- 75, the best round today, to increase her lead to four shots with a 155 total in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole Medal Play Championship at the Piping Rock Club.

John Browning and the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto in B flat minor have been going together for years, and that familiarity showed in his performance with the New York Philharmonic at Tuesday night's "Promenades" concert.

A measure of the ever-increasing pressure to which our public and private hunting lands are subjected is indicated by the half-million increase in hunting license sales in 1971. Total sales in that year were 15,977,588, and perhaps a million or more individuals who do not require licenses because of age or military status were also afield.

GENEVA, May 31 -- Gold hit a new high of just under $60 an ounce and the dollar weakened against most major currencies today as nervousness continued over the state of United States balance-of-payments recovery.
Key to the Mint opened the way to pre-eminent consideration for the remainder of the 3-year-old campaign by the manner in which he won the Withers at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has approved an increase in annual subsidies for the local service airlines.

Among those killed in the Tel Aviv airport shooting yesterday was Dr. Aharon Katzir-Katchalsky, one of Israel's leading scientists, who had served since 1948 as head of the department of polymer research at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovoth.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- This is the final examination in American studies. Each correct answer is worth ten points. Grade your own paper. Students scoring less than seventy points should leave the country immediately.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday what is believed to be a major breakthrough in underground transmission of electricity at cryogenic -- extremely low -- temperatures. The work was part of a $1.05-million experimental project financed by the Edison Electric Institute, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the American Public Power Association under operation of the Electric Research Council.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating damage to three Air Force Reserve cargo planes at the Willow Grove Naval Air Station near Philadelphia.
Why hasn't the New York Stock Exchange permitted the shares of Levitz Furniture to trade for a week?

SILVER SPRING, Md., May 31 (AP) -- An aide to Gov. George C. Wallace said today that he did not expect that the operation to remove a bullet from Mr. Wallace's spinal column would be performed at Holy Cross Hospital here.
Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., producer of cosmetics, toiletries, proprietary drugs and specialty foods, is planning to go into the art-materials field through a proposed acquisition of Binney Smith, Inc.
ROME, May 31 -- The Vatican said today that Pope Paul had approved new gmdelines for annulling marriages between Roman Catholics that had not been consummated.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- American farms are increasingly becoming places where people either live or work, but not both, a new report from the Census Bureau shows.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- A challenge by insurgent Democrats against 59 Illinois delegates to the National Convention finally got under way today as the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a passionate political foe of Mayor Richard J. Daley, testified at a party fact-finding hearing.
NAPLES, May 31 -- The outgoing Commander in Chief of Allied Forces, South, warned today that the Soviet Navy was deploying 22 submarines, a record number, in the Mediterranean Sea.

On Memorial Day Harvey Glenn McLeod walked into Thorne's Hardware and Sporting Goods Store in Raleigh, N. C., selected a .22-caliber automatic rifle and the necessary ammunition, and paid $54. From there he went straight away to a crowded shopping center where he used the weapon to kill three persons, wound eight others and put a last fatal bullet through his own head.

Charles Hetherington, president of Panarctic Oils, Ltd., declined to comment yesterday on reports that the company had discovered considerable quantities of gas at its step-out well near Drake Point on Melville Island in the Canadian Arctic.
PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 28 -- There are two demons in North Korean life, "United States imperialists" and "Japanese militarists," and it is hard to tell which is worse.

The Egyptian belly dancer was an Armenian-American who had never been to Egypt and the Indian Hindu dancer was a Barnard graduate from Manhattan, but still the crowd that gathered yesterday for a preview of summer offerings seemed to enjoy the wigglings and the shimmyings.

HARTFORD, May 31 -- Connecticut is being taken to Federal Court by its capital city in a suit that charges that its constitutional rights are being violated by school districting laws that give Hartford increasingly segregated and deteriorating schools.

Prof. Oscar Handlin, the Harvard historian, skipped the traditional praise and congratulations for the graduating seniors at Brooklyn College yesterday, telling them instead that they and the rest of the classes of '72 across the country were taking too much time to grow up.

William Lucy, a relaxed and gregarious 38-year-old black man who was elected Tuesday night as secretary-treasurer of the 550,000-member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, takes his achievement modestly.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 31 -- Terrorists exploded three bombs here today, one of them near the tomb of the Shah's father, Riza Shah, an hour before President Nixon was sched uled to lay a wreath there. A second went off under a car carrying an American adviser to the Iranian Air Force.

Tom Seaver, unable to finish a starting assignment since April 26, didn't finish another for the New York Mets at Shea Stadium last night, but it wasn't the Philadelphia Phillies who interrupted his work; it was rain.

For three weeks in June the United States has a rare opportunity to demonstrate a real concern for a common problem we share with the rest of the world -- how to prevent the virtual extinction of human life on earth.

The New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association yesterday signed a smallish minor-leaguer named Alton White, who probably will bring the club as much recognition as all its previous signing combined.

The board of directors of Union Theological Seminary voted yesterday to require that blacks and representatives of other minority groups make up one-third and that women comprise one-half of all students, faculty, staff and directors.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, introduced today legislation that would gradually repeal 54 special provisions of the tax law, including most of those that opponents consider to be major "loopholes."

"The 19th century regarded the Renaissance as a movement of liberation from the monkish dogmatism of the Middle Ages, expressing its new-found enjoyment of sensuous pleasure in the artistic celebration of physical beauty. SAN JOSE, Calif., May 31 -- The jurors in the trial of Angela Davis were asked today to convict the 28-year-old black activist of murder in the first degree.

BONN, May 31 -- Fourteen members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization -- all the member but France -- agreed today to explore with the Soviet Union and its allies reductions of air and ground forces in Central Europe.

CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI) -- Joe Pepitone said today he would end his brief retirement from baseball and return to the Chicago Cubs as soon as possible because the club has a chance to win the pennant and he'd like to help them do it.

WARSAW, May 31 -- President Nixon arrived in Warsaw today and succeeded in reaching the Polish people despite official attempts to avoid a repetition of the emotional welcome he received here in 1959, when he was Vice President.
DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- Chumbo, a 9-year-old brown stallion, ridden by Barney Ward, made his comeback official tonight by winning the Gambler's Choice stake at the Devon horse show.
SYDNEY, Australia May 31 (AP) -- Tony Mundine, the British, Commonwealth and Australian middleweight champion, scored a knockout at the end of seven rounds tonight over Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Senate reaffirmed its support today for the continued importation into the United States of chrome ore from Rhodesia in defiance of a United Nations trade embargo against the former British colony.

Hotel and motel employes are scheduled to leave their jobs at about 2 P.M. today to attend a strike authorization meeting in Madison Square Garden, Skeleton crews will remain on duty at the 140 New York hostelries involved in the deadlocked contract talks.

This is a collection of stories currently being told around town. Unlike many events described in stories New Yorkers hear and tell, these actually happened. In each case they were traced to either a participant or first-hand observer.

Yields on high-grade utility bonds dipped yesterday to their lowest level since mid-January, and investors were not enthusiastic.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Black Republicans have invited 2,000 Negroes from across the country to a two-day strategy meeting on the re-election of President Nixon.

BONN, May 31 -- A last-minute problem developed today on the signing of the four-power Berlin agreement this weekend because of differences between West Germany and the Soviet Union over final ratification of their 1970 friendship treaty.

PARIS, May 31 -- Harold Solomon doesn't have a big service and can't hit overheads too well. His volleys are weak, he has a two-fisted backhand and his ground strokes can get lost in the sun. But the little man made his presence felt again today in the $100,000 French open tennis tournament.

Pressmen at The New York Times delayed the start of the first-edition press run of yesterday's issue for nearly 15 minutes to protest the contents of a paid advertisement seeking the impeachment of President Nixon.

From the garbage heap at the Plaza Hotel has grown something of a new art form. A move by Mayor Lindsay to rid the city of the growing burden of welfare costs was rejected yesterday in Federal Court here.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 31 (UPI) -- The late Sarah Bernhardt is starring in a modern mystery -- the disappearance last weekend from Cornell University's art museum of a 19th-century lithograph announcing a performance by the actress.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., May 31 -- There are two political main events next Tuesday -- California's primary, in which 271 Democratic convention delegates will be elected, and New Jersey's, in which 109 delegates will be elected.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -Henry Ford 2d announced yesterday that the Ford Motor Company would build rapidtransit systems based on its driverless, rubber-tired people mover system being demonstrated at the Transpo '72 exhibition here.

Moe Berg had such manifold talents that he had to be as unusual and remarkable a character as the world of baseball ever produced. It's a sadder world today because Moe died suddenly on Monday at the age of 70, and those who knew him best will grieve deeply. He was such a delightful companion and just to be with him was not only a pleasure but often an educational experience.

JERUSALEM, May 31 -- Israeli leaders called today for a boycott of Beirut by international airlines, charging that terrorist attacks on air travelers such as the shooting at the Tel Aviv airport last night are planned by Arab guerrillas on Lebanese soil.

MOSCOW, May 31 (AP) -- One of the Soviet Union's leading male ballet dancers has been sentenced to jail on charge of petty hooliganism which, his friends say, was brought against him because he asked for papers to go to Israel.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 31 -- Pablo Casals canceled his opening appearance at the 16th San Juan Music Festival tonight and sources said the 95-year-old musician was suffering from a mild case of bronchitis:

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- A recovery in prices for beef cattle and hogs helped produce a 3 per cent increase in the average price of raw farm products in mid-May, the agriculture department reported today.

William (Smokey) Robinson, whose soft, high-pitched oo-oo-oohs and do-wahs with strings created a new sound and set a special mood in "soul" music for young, primarily black audiences throughout the sixties, has oohed his last do-wah with, his group, The Miracles at the Apollo.

Your May 8 report of a day-long discussion by a group of Kremlinologists on the origins of the cold war is interesting but disappointing. It seems to indicate that the question as to when the cold war began was not seriously discussed. Indeed, it is not clear that those present were agreed as to what the term really means.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 31 -To the surprise of few, Roosevelt Raceway will drop the scramble tomorrow night and reinstate the individual $2 place and $2 show wagering.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- To attract more volunteers, the Army and Marine Corps will begin tomorrow to offer a cash enlistment bonus of $1,500 to men who sign up for combat arms units -- infantry, artillery and armor.

Two young Broadway performers were chosen yesterday as winners of the 28th annual Clarence Derwent Awards, given to an actor and actress for best individual supporting roles in plays presented here during the last season.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States strongly opposed a plea by Peru today for normalization of relations with Cuba, including a lifting of sanctions imposed by the Organization of American States in 1964.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 31 -- Lee Trevino disclosed his recipe today in preparation for the forthcoming United States Open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of a California banker, Jeffrey M. Bucher, to a 14-year term on the Federal Reserve Board over the opposition of Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, who called him "an inexperienced amateur."

WEST BERLIN, May 31 (Reuters) -- West Germany is increasing its minimum reserve requirements on domestic liabilities by 8 per cent effective July 1, Bundesbank President Karl Klasen said today.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 -- The brown loose-leaf binder that Senator George McGovern is using to bone up on Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's record in advance of their final debate Sunday in the Democratic Presidential primary campaign in California has Mr. McGovern's name neatly affixed to its front.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House voted today to continue Federal financing of noncommercial television and radio for two more years.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (AP) -- A flock of about 100 swans, geese and ducks in the lagoon at the Palace of Fine Arts will be captured and killed to prevent spread of a rare and deadly duck disease.
Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, was elected vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority yesterday.

DUBLIN, June 1 -- Beside the gray concrete walls outside a Dublin police station last night, 40 members of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army marched to protest the arrest of two of their leaders by the Government of Prime Minister John Lynch.

Clarifying the United States Supreme Court ruling on 18to 20-year-old youths' eligibility to vote in the state's primary June 20, state election officials said yesterday that any youth who is at least 18 and registered and enrolled in a party before May 20 is eligible to vote in the primary of his respective party.

The chairman of the Rank Organisation, Ltd., came to Wall Street yesterday to discuss the biggest take-over bid ever made in Britain. At a late afternoon meeting of security analysts, Sir John Davis described Rank's efforts to acquire Watney Mann, Ltd., the big British brewery with interests in pubs, distilleries, hotels, restaurants and other businesses in Britain and elsewhere.

SAN JOSE, Calif., June 1 -Final arguments in the trial of Angela Davis were concluded today with the defense, in its summation, labeling the case against her "a sorry chapter in the history of justice in this country."

WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reuters) -- Total new construction spending rose $800-million in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $122.6-billion, following a $600-million March increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

While appreciating your concern, may I point out that there is no evidence of "indiscriminate mob violence" against the Biharis which could warrant such a conclusion.

MILWAUKEE, June 1 -- Jim Roland walked Rick Auerbach with two out and the bases loaded in the 12th inning today, giving Milwaukee a 9-8 victory and triggering the Yankees' angriest postgame reaction of this frustrating season.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission warned all companies subject to its regulation today that there are specific rules that must be followed when they make pro rata distributions of stock to shareholders.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Justice Department today charged the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants with eliminating price competition among its members' sales of accounting services.

The Battery Park City Authority has announced the proposed issuance of $200 million of debt. This authority contemplates the construction of five million square feet of commercial office space on landfill in the East River. The pattern of the World Trade Center is therefore to be repeated; a governmental authority will undertake the construction of a private office building.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- A class action suit seeking more than $1-billion in damages from The New York Times, Time magazine and four advertising agencies for alleged antitrust violations was filed today in Federal District Court here.
Prices of chemicals, metals and replacement tires moved upward yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A high Treasury official has suggested that the Nixon Administration at least consider a reform in the tax laws that would cut the top tax rate to 35 per cent from 70 per cent and eliminate all favored tax treatment of capital gains.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education recommended today that the Federal Government spend from $100-million to $300-million a year over the next seven years to promote the development and spread of the "new technology" of instruction, a technology based on electronics.

A Federal judge declared yesterday that he would appoint a new Board of Elections unless the city acted promptly under his decision of last September in which he declared the present board unconstitutional.
Governor Rockefeller has signed without comment a bill granting New York City authorization to Issue $100-million in budget notes during the city's 1972-73 fiscal year, beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Nixon returned to Washington tonight from his two-week tour of four nations and told a joint session of Congress that his trip to Moscow had laid the basis for "a new relationship between the two most powerful nations on earth."

WIESBADEN, West Germany, May 17 -- Soviet forces in Central Europe have been provided with special vehicles and decontamination equipment for operations in a nuclear battlefield that are unmatched in any Western army, according to qualified sources.

Mayor Lindsay has continually reaffirmed his determination to build the Forest Hills housing project even after a court order. Simeon Golar stated to two Congressmen that the project will not be scaled down because the city lacks the authority.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -President Nixon's report on his summit talks was greeted with general Congressional support tonight, but it appeared he faced more difficulty than originally expected in getting Congressional approval of the arms agreements with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in the stock of the Levitz Furniture Corporation and announced that it would have a further announcement involving the company tomorrow.

A casual mention of American art of the thirties generally brings to mind notions of social realism. We think of, say, the W.P.A. murals celebrating various aspects of the American way of life, the political paintings of Ben Shahn or the Thomas Hart Benton renderings of a Mid-western farm.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 2 -The Opposition Christian Democrats have scored surprising victories in elections for the leadership of a number of national unions this week, including the Chilean Central Union, a political mainstay of the leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

CONRAD, Mont., June 2 -- Considering all that happened, it didn't seem right that Chester Ferris should have a smile on his face. But he did. It was like the old joke about the man with the spear through his chest who said it only hurt when he laughed.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- On the right and on the left, two men President Nixon would like to see eliminated from the roster of the next Congress are fighting to retain their House seats Tuesday in tough Republican primary contests in California.

TOKYO, June 2 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation has suspended a plan to buy an additional 25 per cent interest in the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation, Chrysler and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. announced today in a joint statement.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -Leading strategists for Gov. George C. Wallace pressed a late-hour effort today for a large write-in vote for the wounded Alabamian in the California Presidential primary Tuesday.

I would like to notify your readers of an innocent-appearing hazard that most have in their homes. That disposable glass bottle filled with carbonated beverages has the potential for destroying an eye or some other part of the human body.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The schizophrenic Chicago White Sox, playing at home where the positive half of their split personality surfaces, slugged their way to a 6-1 victory tonight over the confused New York Yankees.

Robert Shogan, who covers the Supreme Court for Newsweek, has written a model book. He has taken a sensational case, the resignation under fire of Justice Abe Fortas from the Supreme Court, stripped it of its extravagances and excesses, and made it into a tense, resilient and affecting narrative.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 1 -- One of the things that Flemming Flindt has achieved during his sevenyear tenure as director of the Royal Danish Ballet has been to increase its American accent.
LONDON, June 2 -- Britain's prototype of the Concorde took off into a wild blue yonder of uncertainty today as it began a 40,000-mile, 10-nation sales promotion tour.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 2 -- Bill Brew and Fred Kask, from Wethersfield, Conn., overcame a shaky start to finish with a par round of 71 today to lead a field of 16 qualifiers into the 72-hole match-play sequence of the Anderson Memorial best-ball team tournament.
A number of times your newspaper has commented that it would be an asset to the City of New York if there were a number of additional small parks scattered throughout the city.

EUGENE, Ore., June 2 -United States hammer throwing, at the mercy of European minds and muscle during the last decade, brightened considerably today when Al Schoterman uncorked the finest toss by an American collegian this year, 231 feet 3 inches, during the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championshhips.
SAN JOSE, Calif., June 2 -- A jury of seven women and five men began its deliberations late this morning in the trial of Angela Davis and after six hours recessed for the night.

New York University's task force has labored mightly to come up with one of the most socially irresponsible recommendations ever to emanate from an academic body. The fiscal hangups of the university, instead of being shared equally by all facets of university activity, now are to be resolved partly by elimination of the Graduate School of Social Work.

Jack Dolph, the 44-yearold former television network executive who helped raise the American Basketball Association to a position of respectability, resigned yesterday as commissioner of the league, effective in October, the final month of his three-year contract.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Government released two bullish reports on the state of the nation's economy today, including one that reflected continued strong consumer spending.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -Charges against the Boston school system of maintaining racial segregation were ordered today to be heard by a Federal examiner, the first noncompliance action filed against a major Northern school district.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, i iSaturday, June 3 (AP)--A huge United States Air Force rescue armada plucked a downed airman from deep behind enemy lines northwest of Hanoi yesterday, spokesmen disclosed today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 2 (AP) -- About 25 Japanese employes of a color-television manufacturing company and their families have left Puerto Rico in fear of possible reprisals for the slaying of Puerto Rican pilgrims in Israel Tuesday by three Japanese terrorists.
The head of New York State's medical regulatory body said yesterday that acupuncture to deaden the pain of surgery could be generally accepted in this country in two to five years.

JERUSALEM, June 2 -- A senior Israeli Cabinet Minister promised today that the massacre at Tel Aviv's international airport Tuesday would be fully avenged, but not by any rash or impatient Israeli action.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 2 -C. L. (Gibby) Gilbert Jr., who has recovered from an airplane accident that kept him from the pro tour for five weeks earlier in the year, led the $175,000 Kemper open today with a 36-hole total of 135.
DEVON, Pa., June 2 -- Peyote finished fourth in the stake and the single point he picked up enabled him to win the intermediate jumper championship today at the Devon horse show.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 (AP) -- Miss Davis was visibly shaken when told of the report that she was part of the hijacker's demands.
A new dispute over pay parity and differentials brought a charge of "double cross" yesterday from the city's fire officers and a threat to exert unspecified pressures on the city.

A major clash is developing between the Legal Aid Society and Community Action for Legal Services over the philosophy of legal services to the poor and control of a neighborhood legal services office in the South Bronx.

The reason the Donald Davies shirt dress has inspired something of a cult is quite simple. If a woman likes it she can obtain it in about 500 different colors and patterns. At least that is the variety being offered at the Donald Davies shop at 19 East 57th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against the Levitz Furniture Corporation, charging that the warehouse furniture dealer did not tell prospective stockholders about a pending labor contract with the teamsters' union.
OXFORD, Ohio -- May I offer a suggestion that will horrify many of your readers? This is it: One of the greatest needs of American education is a commitment and a program to develop character.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -Democrats sent their bestknown noncandidate, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, to preside here today over platform hearings on what they consider the chief issue in the elections this year -- the state of the economy.
About 300 representatives of companies that sell to the Federal Government wound up a two-day conference yesterday on equal opportunity for women in business.
Is the East Coast ready for the all-night supermarket? Will the 4 A.M. shopper, long considered a hallmark of California kookiness, become a regular feature of life in the less flamboyant East?
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Price Commission ordered McDonald's restaurants today to lower the prices of some hamburgers and cheesburgers.
PEKING, June 2 -- Dinner at Mrs. Sun Yat-sen's home, a palace that once housed a Manchu prince on the banks of the Imperial Lakes in the northern quarter, is a rare event.

Epic Journey became the late favorite with the crowd of 19,057 at Belmont Park yesterday, and he proved that the confidence in him was justified. Competing against six others in a mile contest for older horses, Epic Journey responded to a splendidly judged ride by Chuck Baltazar to carry the colors of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs to score by two lengths over John Marsh's Eager Exchange.

A problem involving potential conflicts of interest has resulted from Wall Street's public-ownership spree. It boils down to this question: Can you get an objective appraisal of the investment merits of a brokerage company?
Across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, past the neon-lighted shopping centers, beyond the neighborhood of booming home construction on Staten Island is a pocket of poverty.

The Great Southwest Corporation, following completion of an audit for 1971, announced yesterday higher revenues and a reduced loss for the year. The company also reported that its financial statement for the three preceding years had been restated to reflect a settlement reached earlier this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to accounting for three major transactions in 1968 and 1969.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- The seizure of Western oil interests by Iraq and Syria was hailed in the official Soviet press today as a "great victory for the Arab peoples."

The city-state dispute over welfare fraud statistics grew angrier yesterday, with each side charging misrepresentation and deceit. City Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman, seeking to discredit a charge by State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger that 20 to 30 per cent of the cases on the city's welfare rolls were ineligible for assistance, accused the state official of distorting the statistics for political purposes.

A Federal judge gave a oneyear prison sentence Thursday to a Brooklyn man who had admitted scheming to embezzle $1,183,000 worth of securities from the Bankers Trust Company when he worked there last summer.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 -President Suleiman Franjieh said today that the country was taking steps to halt the publicity activities of the Arab commando group that claimed responsibility for the Tel Aviv airport massacre.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -An engineer for the New York Transit Authority has invented an emergency gangway to evacuate passengers from stalled subway or rail road trains. Patent 3,666,045 was granted this week to Martin F. Olsen for the device, which is a modification of the usual cab or compartment door.

Norman V. Wechsler, vice president and general merchandise manager for fashion apparel and soft lines at the J. W. Robinson company, a Los Angeles department store, has been named president of Saks Fifth Avenue, effective Aug. 1.

SANDWICH, England, June 2 (AP) -- Kemp Richardson, the last American in the British Amateur golf championship, bowed out in the quarterfinals today when Alan Thirlwell, 43year-old Briton who was the runner-up in 1958, beat him at the 20th hole on the Royal St. George course.

All eight consumer members of the 17-member St. Vincent's Hospital advisory board resigned yesterday, charging that the hospital's management had deliberately withheld information they needed to perform their duties.

HOLLYWOOD, June 2 (UPI) -Representative Barry Goldwater Jr., Republican of California, whose constituency includes scores of movie and television personalities, has taken showbusiness problems to the State Department for better treatment abroad.

GENEVA, June 2 -- The United States and Switzerland are reported to be near agreement on a treaty under which Swiss banks would be subject to requirements by Swiss courts to provide information on money deposited by American criminals.
BUKAVU, Zaire, May 30 -Thousands of refugees are arriving here from neighboring Burundi in what diplomats call one of the worst ethnic wars in modern African history.

The first public offering of stock in the Empire Fire and Marine Insurance Company sparked an otherwise quiet new issue market this week, with the specialty company's shares advancing from an offering price of 16 a share on Wednesday to 19 1/2 yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would permit the Ford Motor Company to ship its 1973 models provided they can meet preliminary pollution tests.

LONDON, June 2 -- In the opinion of well-informed diplomats in the Far East, the Premier of North Vietnam, Pham Van Dong, was out of his country for at least four days during the Moscow summit meeting: May 23 through 26. The general guess is that he was in China, but it is only a guess.
Weakness in certain international oil stocks and profit taking in the high-flying airline issues featured a stock market yesterday that displayed small changes over-all for the second day in a row.

ALBANY, June 2--In an effort to determine "what's really going on in the prisons," the Corrections Department today appointed a career civil servant to the agency's newly created position of inspector general.
BOGOTA, Colombia -Women's liberation, a budding movement in South American countries, has at least one or two blooms here.
HOLYOKE, Mass. -- Anna looked at George across the breakfast table knowing she was supposed to be understanding and wondering why she felt only anger.

ALBANY, June 2--Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill that would have divided the state into three wholesale beer-marketing zones, terming the measure "contrary to the public interest."

LONDON, June 2 -- The British Government today asked its allies in the Central Treaty Organization to put pressure on Iraq to give fair compensation for the seized assets of the Iraq Petroleum Company.

The amazing thing about N.R.B.Q. -- a rock band that is shaking the pillars of the Village Gate this week -- is that it's been around for years but has never quite broken through to major public consciousness. With luck, the Gate appearance should start to change all that.

NEW ORLEANS June 2 -H. Rap Brown was resentenced here today to five years in prison and a fine of $2,000 for violation of the Federal Gun Control Act.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A study of the first one-third of the delegates chosen for the Democratic National Convention shows that the proportion of women is running at three times the level set in 1968, that the proportion of blacks is nearly double and that of other minorities is higher.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 2 -A Levitz spokesman here said today that the S.E.C. actions "relate solely to the alleged, material non-disclosures in the company's registration statement and preliminary prospectuses and certain pending labor matters as referred to by the S.E.C."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -Last Wednesday evening, guests milled about the spacious stone house and lawn of Raymond Lamontagne, a Washington businessman, just north of the Washington Zoo, paying $25 a person and sipping wine to raise money for a Democratic primary fight in Brooklyn.

Everything considered, New York City must be the best place in the world to see African sculpture. WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Attacking marriage is the big new thing in publishing this year, and why not? The evil of marriage may be a timeworn theme but at least it beats the tiresome old generation gap. So far, however, most of the writers doing the attacking seem short on qualifications.

A PROBLEM that is fairly common in most parts of the United States is the development of mildew or mold on many painted surfaces around the inside and outside of the house. Mildew is actually a fungus -- microscopic living spores that are carried through the air and that feed on organic matter when conditions are right for their growth.

THE Rolling Stones are on the West Coast this weekend, about to embark on their first American concert tour since the disastrous events at Altamont. Humphrey.

WASHINGTON, Ga. -- The bus lets you off a block from the town square. Across the street is a huge white 1804 Greek Revival plantation house with an encircling second-story veranda. NISSEQUOGUE, L. I. -- A few feet south of the Jericho Turnpike in Smithtown is a small body of water known as White's Pool, part of one of the finest trout streams in the East. Encouraged by the success of potent anticancer drugs in treating acute leukemia and Hodgkin's disease, researchers are now trying to use these chemicals to help improve the life expectancy of patients with other forms of malignant disease.

ABERDEEN, S. D., June 3 -- With Senator George McGovern assured of his state's 17 votes at the Democratic National Convention, interest in South Dakota's primary on Tuesday is focused on the contests that will produce a successor to Senator Karl E. Mundt.

ROCHESTER, Mich., June 3 -- "I bask in my husband's reflected glory. I don't have to be anything myself. His status is my status. Sometimes I feel he's living his life to the fullest and I'm living his life to the fullest."

Although divided on what black studies are, what they should be and whom they should reach, a number of black educators, social scientists and intellectuals agree that the discipline has forever changed some aspects of American higher education.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A new type of "lie detector" device that can detect psychological stress by analyzing a person's voice is gaining acceptance in some legal and investigative circles and its results have been used in a few court proceedings.

Early approval of President Nixon's historic, if limited, agreements with the Soviet Union for freezing nuclear missile deployment is the most urgent foreign-policy business before the Congress. But care must be taken not to pay a price to opponents of arms control that will undermine prospects for future progress in this vital area.

Faced with the threat of potentially bankrupt franchises in Pittsburgh and Miami, the American Baseball Association yesterday annnounced that it would seek new locations for those troubled clubs in "major cities and major television markets to stabilize the league."

STOCKHOLM, June 4 -- The United Nations environmental conference, which begins tomorrow, is the main event here but it is only part of the story. It has stimulated environmentalists and other activist groups, here and abroad, to organize complementary conferences, alternative conferences, exhibitions, teach-ins and assorted happenings and demonstrations.

BARI, Italy, June 4 (AP) -- The body of Italy's aviation hero, Air Marshal Italo Balbo, and more than 20,000 other war dead were brought home today from a military cemetery at Tripoli that Libyan authorities have ordered moved.
New York's largest baseball crowd of the season, 52,216 at Shea Stadium yesterday, didn't get too much to cheer about as the Mets lost to the Atlanta Braves, 9-3.
PARIS -- Referring to the scandal about cubism in the Salon d'Automne of 1912, the Socialist Deputy Marcel Sembat advised "Don't call the police."
Interest rates last week dropped to their lowest levels since mid-January, and then the credit markets sputtered to a halt.
There are few hiding places left for people who want to keep their finances secret from the Internal Revenue Service.
The city's welfare rolls decreased by 3,404 persons in April, the first decline in 11 months and the largest in six years, Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman announced yesterday.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 4 -- Dapper Doug Sanders, with the short back swing, the wide stance and a penchant for socializing, returned to the winning column today with a birdie putt that clinched the Kemper open tourney.

Two pilots of the city's police aviation unit, practicing emergency procedures for engine failure were suddenly confronted with the real thing yesterday morning when a connecting rod punctured the crankcase of their helicopter engine.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- Using a shot two ounces too heavy, George Woods became the third man in track and field history to break the 70-foot barrier today.

The Algerian Government Government has "pretty much given assurance" it will return to Western Airlines the $500,000 extorted by the man who hijacked one of the airline's jets from California to Algiers last Friday and Saturday, according to well-placed Washington sources.

Barcelona of Ecuador was no match for the Aberdeen soccer team of Scotland at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday as the Scottish players triumphed, 5-1, before 1,300 fans, 200 of whom were standing in the pedestrian aisle of the Triborough Bridge.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 4 -- Sir Frank Packer, the Sydney publisher and sportsman, has sold his two Sydney newspapers to a fellow Australian, Rupert Murdoch, for $17.48-million.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 4 -- T. Vincent Learson's 58-foot sloop, Nepenthe, was awarded the Solution Trophy today as the New York Yacht Club's 118th annual cruising-boat regatta wound up with a record 75-boat fleet on Long Island Sound.
ROME, June 4 -- Italy ended a four-day vacation today with a nearly nationwide traffic jam.

"Probably in no city in the civilized world is life so fearfully insecure," wrote one Englishwoman about New York in the eighteen-fifties. "Terrible outrages and murderous assaults are matters of such nightly occurrence as to be thought hardly worthy of notice."

SAN DIEGO, June 4 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation placed a guard today on an apartment in suburban Linda Vista, believed to have been occupied for two weeks by the young couple who were involved in the hijacking of a Western Airlines plane from San Francisco to Algiers.
New York took its publicity as a summer festival quite literally yesterday before a cloudburst soon after 6 P.M. dampened festivities in several languages.
Ground was broken on the East Side yesterday for a $3.5-million cultural center and day school designed to meet the needs of suburbanites returning to city life.

The progression of thought in your very interesting May 26 editorial "Church and State" flows with irresistible logic up to a point. But at that point, I am afraid, the logic breaks down and rhetoric takes its place.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- An Air Force Thunderbird-jet pilot was killed today during a precision flying exhibition at Transpo '72 after parachuting from his plane just before it crashed and exploded.

For a decade or more, perfumes have been growing stronger and heavier, so that being in an elevator with some women has been as staggering as an LSD trip. Now, there are signs that they are turning back to sweetness and light, with perfumers talking about "sports" perfumes, early morning brews and scents as wholesome as an organically-grown carrot.

SAN DIEGO, June 4 -- Only prompt Congressional action in removing court-imposed restraints on the building and operation of new generating plants can eliminate the threat of serious power shortages this summer, the nation's electric utilities said today.

MIAMI, June 4 (UPI) -- The authorities in Honduras and Miami were trying today to find out what became of a $303,000 hijacking ransom, although the man accused of taking the money a month ago has said, "You'll never see it again."

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers today proposed a drastic new rule aimed at making sure that only investors of means -- and, presumably, of sophistication -- are permitted to buy tax-sheltered equities.

Strong headwinds that slowed Stanley Dancer on his 150-mile air trip from Westbury, L.I., to Wilmington, Del., on Saturday night prevented the famed harness-racing driver from scoring an unusual "double."

Oakland at Baltimore--The A's kept their lead in the Western Division in winning two games by 2-0 scores. Jim Hunter pitched a two-hitter for his 100th major league triumph in the opener as Sal Bando secured the victory with a two-run homer .in the first off Mike Cuellar.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 4 -- With four holes to play today in the final round of the Anderson Memorial best-ball team golf tournament at the Winged Foot Club, George Marucci put his arm around his University of Maryland teammate, Rick Bendall, and hugged him.

MIAMI, June 4 -- In a carefree mood reminiscent of pre-Castro Cuba more than a decade ago, several hundred wealthy Cubans and other Spanish-speaking residents of Miami, ate, drank and danced into the small hours of the dawn today at a lavish party to raise funds for the re-election of their neighbor, Richard M. Nixon.
Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, has disclosed the names of 26 additional food-processing establishments cited for "serious violations" of the Health Code.

HOUSTON, June 4 -- Dolph Briscoe, who won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Texas yesterday, said that he would insist that all factions of the State Democratic party be fairly represented at the Democratic state convention on June 13 in San Antonio.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Enforcement of wage and price controls, spotty in the early months of Phase Two, is gradually being tightened, according to Government officials in charge of the economic stabilization program.

Massachusetts Medical Society officials, in a move made rarely during the organization's 101-year history, are expected this week to censure Dr. John H. Knowles, who is due to become president of the Rockefeller Foundation here July 1.
The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has accused Weber Heilbroner and Broad-street's, the clothing chain, of running fraudulent "going-out-of-business" sales this spring.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 5 -- North Vietnamese troops attacked a district capital in populous Binhdinh Province on the central coast yesterday, according to reports from the field.

LONDON, June 4 -- The success of the Moscow summit is a particular triumph for Henry Kissinger's world view. He has argued that great powers can balance their mutual interests on a planetary scale, transcending local or ideological differences. In Moscow, as in Peking, President Nixon boldly followed that approach.

MARLBORO, Mass., June 4 -- Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, a stylish little silver-buff cocker spaniel, rang up her third best-in-show triumph in a week today. She was chosen best of 1,683 dogs at the Framingham District Kennel Club fixture on the Marlboro High School grounds.

Your editorial of May 23 strongly implies that policies of Mayor Lindsay are responsible for the steep rise in the number of welfare cases in New York City in recent years. If you had made a more thorough examination of available data, you would have found that your assumptions and conclusions are both mistaken.

This year the company, made up of children and a few adults, is presenting Miss Neubert's choreographic adaptation of Mark Twain's "The Prince and the Pauper."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 4 -- Parliament will hold a debate tomorrow on the latest clash between South African students and the police, the most serious during a recent series of student protests.

We have instead a series of naive assumptions. If the message of this book were common knowledge, much of the sound and fury that currently caricatures our politics and our national image could be averted.

Supertankers (six times bigger than at present) using Long Island Sound and Montauk for unloading are going to require a lot of dredging. Constant emptying of passing ships' ballast tanks off Long Island is going to put a lot of oil on our beaches. Drilling rigs in offshore waters are going to adversely affect the marine life.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 4 -- Cesar Chavez, director of the United Farm Workers, ended his 24-day fast today with a bite of sacramental bread at a memorial mass for Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

LUTHERVILLE, Md., June 4 (AP) -- Carol Mann, playing before nearly 8,000 fans from her home city, tied the Pine Ridge course record with a six-under-par 67 today and won the Lady Carling open by two strokes. She finished with a nine-under-par 54-hole score of 210.

Archbishop Molloy won five events and scored in nine of the 19 events yesterday to take the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association outdoor track and field team title for the second year in a row.

Antiwar protest expresses itself in urgent but nonviolent pleading, with students joined in their appeal by powerful voices among university presidents. Symbolic of the new mood was the polite arrest during a protest demonstration last month of John William Ward, president of Amherst College.
A "borrow now -- pay later" plan on police pay raises would wind up costing real estate taxpayers $9-million more, Controller Abraham D. Beame warned yesterday.

A spray of bullets hit a white Cadillac carrying two sons of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader, as the car pulled up to the elder Colombo's home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, early this morning, the police reported.

YONKERS, June 4 -- The Department of Development here plans to submit an application tomorrow for an $11.4-million urban renewal project to upgrade four areas and keep the Otis Elevator Company, the largest local Industry, from leaving.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Army's official secret report on the Mylai massacre has revealed that a second massacre, involving the killing of as many as 90 civilians, "did in fact" take place less than two miles from the hamlet of Mylai 4 on the same morning -- March 16, 1968.

The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, outspoken opponent of the Vietnam war, walked out of a mass for peace yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral and held his own prayer service on the church steps. He charged that he had been denied the opportunity to preach.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 3 -- The Government of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, which came to power in December with a credo of "Socialism is our economy," is slowly but steadily leading Pakistan down the familiar capitalist road.
ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, June 4 -- Ed Good 3d of Manhasset High School won the Canadian secondary schools rowing championship today by three lengths from Tony Novotny of Toronto.

SAN JOSE, Calif., June 4 -- After just 13 hours of deliberations, an all-white jury found Angela Davis not guilty today of murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy charges.

HOUSTON, June 4 -- An effort by Southern Democratic Governors to try to block the nomination of Senator George McGovern as the party's Presidential candidate fell apart here today before anyone could put it together.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- April imports of steel were the lowest in two years. The April intake of less than 930,000 tons was down 15 per cent from 1.09 million tons in March and was off more than 31 per cent from 1.36 million tons in April of 1971.

RENO, Nev., June 4 (UPI) -- With a confessed hijacker in jail on air piracy charges, the authorities searched again today around Washoe Lake near here for a canvas bag containing $155,000 in ransom money.

TEL AVIV, June 4 -- The Puerto Rican survivors watched in silence, their faces taut. The wife of the Japanese Ambassador put her handkerchief to her eyes over and over again. Israeli policemen snapped to stiff salute before each of the aluminum coffins.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- After Chicago defeated the Yankees, 6-1, on Tom Bradlye's six-hitter in the first game of today's double-header, Manager Chuck Tanner decided to keep Dick Allen, the White Sox star, on the bench for the second game.

RALEIGH, N. C., June 4 -- The "new politics" of the young, the black and the anti-establishment appears to have been a major factor in the stunning defeat of an aging incumbent, Senator B. Everett Jordan, in yesterday's Democratic run-off for the Senate.

There is, in a manner of speaking, a three - cornered Democratic primary contest in the 13th Congressional District in Brooklyn this year. Both the incumbent, Representative Bertram L. Podell, and his challenger, Assemblyman Leonard M. Simon, are running against President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.
Two tiny bone fragments, believed to be 2,500-year-old relics of the founder of Buddhism, have been presented to a Budhist temple in the Bronx.
STOCKHOLM, June 4 -- Representatives of most of the world's people gathered here today on the eve of the first global attack on environmental problems.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- In their debate in California over the cost of a radical new income-supplement plan for all Americans, both Senator George McGovern of South Dakota and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota are using figures that neither their staffs nor political and tax experts here have been able to support.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today that he would refuse the Democratic nomination as Vice President, regardless of whom the party nominates for President.

PARIS, June 4 -- She was tired and coughing and she wasn't going to play the tournament in the first place, but Mrs. Billie Jean King won the French open tennis tournament today to finally complete her career grand slam.

NIVELLES, Belgium, June 4 (UPI) -- Favored Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil lengthened his lead in the world driver's championships when he won the 30th Grand Prix of Belgium today by leading virtually from start to finish.
Pro-New York advertising is really coming into vogue, with the latest contributor being the city's No. 1 employer, the New York Telephone Company.
MEXICO CITY, June 4 -- Almost any evening on Mexican television these days, there is a public service message showing people washing their hands and advising the viewer to do the same.

LONDON, June 4 (UPI) -- Queen Elizabeth raised what had been a private funeral for the Duke of Windsor to royal heights today by asking the Archbishops of Canterbury and York and the Moderator of the Church of Scotland to take part.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse, bowing at the last minute to entreaties by the Government's treasury and central bank officials, has post-posed decreeing Argentina's new hydrocarbons law, according to well-placed Government House sources.
STOCKHOLM, June 4 -- The winds and ocean currents recognize no national boundaries and the inhabitants of the earth are woven into a fragile web of interdependence.

TOKYO, June 4 -- Yasuo Okamoto, the 62-year-old father of Kozo Okamoto, who participated with two other Japanese in last week's massacre at the Tel Aviv airport, said today he had sent a letter to the Israeli Embassy here asking that his son be executed.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- Senator George McGovern accumulated 41 more delegate votes in five states over the weekend. But the same states also chose 85 uncommitted delegates, many of whom lean toward Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Mr. McGovern's main rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
DACCA, Bangladesh -- The new state of Bangladesh is hampered by shortages of everything but people in its struggle to build a viable economy in the ashes of war.

NEWARK, June 4 -- New Jersey's Democratic primary Tuesday will focus on the northern part of the state, on the counties of Hudson and Essex, and on this city, where a variety of political strategies and alliances will be tested.

Teams captained by Steve Goldstein of New York and David Mason of Maplewood, N. J., clashed at the New York Hilton yesterday afternoon in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team championships.

CHANTILLY, France, June 4 -- The 90-year-old Japanese textile magnate, Junzo Kashiyama, bought himself a thoroughbred last week for $1-million, and today the colt, Hard to Beat, picked up $251,000 in winning the 131st running of the Prix du Jockey-Club.

MOSCOW, June 5 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia, often the target of sharp attacks from Moscow because of his historic independence, today received a warm welcome and one of the highest Soviet awards, the Order of Lenin, on his first state visit to the Soviet Union in seven years.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 5 -- State Supreme Court Justice Sol Wachtler dismissed today a suit by the "real" former Federal narcotics agent in the film "The French Connection," who contended that he and not Eddie (Popeye) Egan had, in fact, broken up the heroin smuggling ring and that the movie and book portraying him as a bumbling incompetent had defamed him.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 5 -- From a start full of hope two years ago, Cambodia has sunk into a deep malaise, without confidence in her leadership, institutions, or ability to decide her own future, in the assessment of a wide range of Cambodians and foreign diplomats.

The schedule takes on a sterner character for the New York Mets tonight as they open a three-game series with the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium. Of the next 15 games the Mets play, 12 will be against Cincinnati and Houston, two Western Division teams that have been winning regularly.

Mills of Arkansas is probably the best choice, Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, who is campaigning for the Democratic nomination for President, said yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., June 5 (AP) -- The aircraft carrier America sailed today for Vietnam after the Coast Guard cleared the way of antiwar protesters so the big ship could move from her Norfolk Naval Station pier to an ammunition - loading anchorage.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 5 -- The long-stalemated Red Cross talks between North Korea and South Korea achieved a breakthrough today when "working level" delegates agreed on a draft agenda for a full-dress conference aimed at reuniting members of families separated in the two Koreas.
WASHINGTON. June 5 (Reuters) -- Sales of Series E and H Savings Bonds increased in May and exceeded redemptions for the 20th month in a row, the Treasury Department reported today.

J., won by 13 international match points after trailing at the halfway mark by 55 points.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey is telling close friends that he cannot win the California Democratic Presidential primary tomorrow and is concentrating on minimizing the loss.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 5 (AP) -- Senator George McGovern gained another three committed Democratic National Convention delegates as a result of the official canvass today of Nebraska's May 9 primary election returns.

Many small investors apparently discovered the shares of American Israeli Paper Mills, Ltd., yesterday. Trading in the shares, which was halted last week because of an influx of buy orders, was resumed yesterday and then halted again about 15 minutes later.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., June 5 -- Hank Greenberg, 61-year-old former slugger of the Detroit Tigers, and Bob Boyd, University of Southern California basketball coach, defeated O. J. Simpson, Buffalo Bills' running back, and Gail Goodrich, Los Angeles Lakers' guard, today, 5-0, to win the second annual Dewar's sports celebrities tennis tournament.

ST. PAUL, June 5 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota has campaign debts totaling $1,149,967 on the eve of the California primary, according to a report filed today in the office of the Minnesota Secretary of State.

The New York Philharmonic has named Michael Tilson Thomas director and conductor of its Young People's Concerts for the next two seasons. He succeeds Leonard Bernstein, who is giving up this position after 15 seasons because of heavy commitments elsewhere.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5--Lebanon today denied that the terrorists who carried out the attack at the Tel Aviv airport had been trained on Lebanese soil.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -Mrs. Aristotle Onassis still evokes that old magic for the people of Washington.
Grain and soybean futures dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, chiefly as a result of favorable weather in the growing areas.

Vincent A. Catoggio, a United States Magistrate, issued a warrant here yesterday for the arrest of 22-year-old Willie Roger Holder and Catherine Kerkow, 20, on charges of aircraft piracy for the hijacking of a Western Airlines plane from California to Algiers last Friday and Saturday.

Dino Anagnost has proved his choral conducting skills on a number of previous occasions here, so it was no surprise to find his Metropolitan Greek Choir a well-trained, smartly efficient ensemble. At Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night, the 50voice group offered a generous program, mostly of Greek liturgical, folk and popular material.

WASHINGTON, June 5, (AP)--The Aviation Consumer Action Project an arm of Ralph Nader's operation petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board today to require two holding companies and the Chase Manhattan Bank to quit ownership or control of stock in 11 airlines.

The bare bones of Roger Angell's "The Summer Game" do not seem promising. Ten years' worth of reports on baseball that have already appeared in The New Yorker, where Mr. Angell is chief resident buff? Twenty-one installments on our great national pastime written during a period when -- thanks to expanding teams and schedules, carpet-bagging owners and Charles O. Finley -- baseball has threatened to become our great national bore?

TOKYO, June 5 -- The United States, in a move intended to de-escalate continuing trade warfare with Japan, has shelved plans to file a formal complaint with world-trade officials in Geneva, a qualified American source disclosed today.

Members of the United Teachers of New York and the New York State Teachers Association have voted overwhelmingly to merge their organizations and thereby create the largest statewide union of educational employes in the nation.
WINDSOR, England, June 5 -- The Duke of Windsor was buried here today at Frogmore, the Royal Burial Ground close to Windsor Castle.

More than 500 "older women" (definition: females over the age of 30) met here over the weekend to reassure each other that wrinkles, gray hair and the menopause do not automatically relegate a woman to the scrap heap.
BALTIMORE, June 5 (UPI) -- Bobby Darwin's sixth-inning double sent the Baltimore Orioles down to their fourth straight defeat tonight as the Minnesota Twins rallied for a 3-2 victory.

ALGIERS, June 5 (UPI) -- Algeria will return the $500,000 ransome of two Western Airlines hijackers but will give the couple political shelter in the local Black Panther colony, Government officials said today.
Two prominent race horses belonging to Ralph C. Wilson Jr., owner of the Buffalo Bills, were impounded at Belmont Park yesterday in a legal wrangle.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 5 -- President Nixon is sending Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally on a month-long mission to some 15 nations on four continents, starting tomorrow, the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee tentatively adopted a new plan of Federal financing of welfare programs today and said the plan would save the states $2.6-billion in 1974 when it would be fully effective.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 5 -The police of this Union County city and of the Borough of Lodi in Bergen County, 15 miles north of here, widened their search today for the gunman or gunmen who shot and killed one person on a street corner here early yesterday and wounded five others at separate points in an unexplained shooting spree.

The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday that Amtrak the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, had agreed to pay the carrier an extra $17.1-million for the avoidable costs of operating intercity passenger trains until June 30, 1973.
A $10-million student-aid program to increase the number of doctors who would practice in "medically underserved" locations was announced yesterday by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 5 -- When George L. Franke arrived here in June, 1916, he found 35 fellow members of the first class of the new State Agricultural Institute, a large area of plowed land, a small herd of cattle, one barn and two temporary classroom buildings.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 5 -- When Rutgers dropped Delaware from its football schedule it was felt that Scarlet officials were unwilling to continue playing against one of the powerful teams of the region.
Cities around the nation have begun a rush to impose $1 and $2 airport "departure taxes" on air travelers in the wake of a Supreme Court decision upholding the constitutionality of such taxes.
LONDON, June 5 (AP) -- A number of European newspapers today hailed the acquittal of Miss Davis as a demonstration of the impartiality of American justice.

The Bronx Realty Advisory Board announced yesterday that it had advised its member landlords to continue to pay a wage increase to service employes until it was determined whether the city was implementing a court order on maximum base rents in rentcontrolled apartments.

The sculptor Roy Gussow, noted for his abstract works in stainless steel, has won the $87,500 commission in a sculpture competition sponsored by the city. The Seven-Up Company has agreed in principle to acquire the Mountain Valley Spring Company of Hot Springs, Ark., the nation's largest independent spring water company, for an undisclosed amount of common stock, it was announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 (UPI) States Army won the final event, the 1,500 meters, in 4 minutes 8.9 seconds to capture the national Amateur Athletic Union decathlon with 7,910 points today.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 -Lawyers for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo, who are accused of stealing the Pentagon papers, argued in a Federal court today that the court should permit a pretrial hearing of witnesses that would show that leaks of classified Government documents were a routine practice of Washington officials.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5 (UPI) -- The United States military command said today that American troop strength in Vietnam dropped to 63,700 last week, the lowest level in seven years, but still short of President Nixon's goal of 49,000 by the end of the month.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 5 -- The Conservatory of Puerto Rico, founded by Pablo Casals 13 years ago, conferred honorary doctorates last night on Nancy Hanks, President Nixon's cultural adviser, and Alexander Schneider, the New York violinist, who organized the Casals Festivals, first in Prades and since 1957 here in San Juan.

Net income of Carter-Wallace, Inc., in the fiscal year ended March 31 rose to a record high despite a 26 per cent decline in fourth-quarter profits, the producer of drugs and toiletries reported yesterday.

The area in front of the accident was, of course, devoid of traffic -- at least in the lane in which the accident occurred. Very often such a tie-up covers both lanes -- depending on who jumped what rail.

RENO, June 5 (UPI) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday recovered ed the remaining $155,000 of $200,000 given to a hooded hijacker who parachuted from a United Air Lines 727 jetliner into the sagebrush near Reno Friday night.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 5 -- Every day shortly before noon, the telephone operator of the Union Bank of Switzerland puts through a call to the gold-trading room from the Reserve Bank of South Africa in Pretoria.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told Congress today that the expanded military activity in Vietnam could add $3-billion to $5-billion to the defense budget in the coming fiscal year, virtually doubling the projected annual cost of the war.

Bond rates, which last week reversed course and began to move upward, continued to climb yesterday in quiet trading. Money rates were mixed, but with an upward bias. There were no major economic or market developments during the day to affect sentiment, but analysts noted a growing belief that credit policy was being tightened up a notch and new skepticism about the efficacy of the bat tle against inflation.

Commissioner Walter Kennedy of the National Basketball Association reacted to queries about the rival American Basketball Association yesterday with the attitude that the A.B.A. was running its own business.

Shares of the Levitz Furniture Corporation plunged sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the first market reaction to the disclosure of charges against the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Voters -particularly California voters -- should never he taken for granted, but on the eve of the Democratic primary in that state, all signs point to another victory for Senator George McGovern. SRINAGAR, Kashmir June 5 -- The government of the state of Kashmir today permitted the return of Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, its former Prime Minister, from exile in India.

WASHINGTON June 5 (AP) -- Operating details of a new plan for dairy-import quotas were announced today by the Agriculture Department, The plan is expected to increase the amount of cheese imported next year by 5 to 10 per cent, according to Government projections.

Five transit policemen received their department's highest award, the Medal of Honor, yesterday for "performing acts of outstanding bravery at immediate personal risk to life." They were among 118 transit policemen receiving awards for valor in the department's fifth annual presentation ceremony.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 5 -- Lieut. Gov. Jere L. Beasley became Acting Governor of Alabama today and promised to make "no major decisions" without the approval of Gov. George C. Wallace, who is hospitalized in Maryland as a result of an assassination attempt three weeks ago.

Policemen in a launch fired two 12-gauge shotgun shells at a 15-foot gray shark at 12:45 P.M. yesterday about 300 yards off Beach 120th Street, the Rockaways. The shark, which was seven feet from the launch, submerged and was not seen again.

HELENA, Mont., June 6 (AP) -- Senator Lee Metcalf, a Democrat, won nomination to a third term by an overwhelming margin in today's primary elec tion, and Henry Hibbard, a Helena rancher, apparently will be his Republican opponent in the November election.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 6 -- A coal mine explosion trapped 464 Rhodesian miners underground today, and hopes for their survival dimmed after 10 hours of rescue efforts flailed to establish contact with them.
