Louis L. Levine, State Industrial Commissioner, yesterday commended Local 28 of the Sheetmetal Workers International Association on its minority group representation in a class of apprentices graduating to journeymen status.

The National Broadcasting Company television network announced it will enter the Leonardo sweepstakes June 20. That night at 9:30 it will broadcast, without commercial interruptions, an hour-long documentary titled "Leonardo: To Know How to See."
The body of a 26-year-old handyman with the Chinese mission to the United Nations who died Feb. 7 was removed from the city morgue Friday by mission representatives.
MOSCOW, June 6 -- The Soviet Union has conceded the existence of a nationalist movement in the Ukraine having close ties with anti-Communist emigre organizations abroad.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (Reuters) -- The Treasury said today it was beginning an investigation to see if imports of Japanese permanent magnets and zippers were being "dumped," or sold in the United States at less than fair value.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 6 -- It is remarkable how quickly the unknown can become the established, and the established can become the Establishment. The Stratford Festival opened its 20th season last night.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 6 (Reuters) -- A court here acquitted a former doctor today of a charge of helping in the killing of thousands of the mentally ill during the Hitler era. It said his contention that he acted from humane considerations had not been disproved.

Platinum futures prices reached a high in early trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange but fell sharply later in the day on reports that Russia was selling platinum in the world market.

HAWORTH, N. J., June 6 -- Paul Samanchik of North Jersey, a former Metropolitan junior champion, shot a par 72 today to win the northern section qualifying medal for the 71st annual New Jersey State Golf Association amateur championship.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Many Republican leaders appear to have all but conceded the Democratic Presidential nomination to Senator George McGovern and are already mounting the general-election campaign against him.

Marilyn Bender of The New York Times financial-business news department will be honored as an "outstanding woman in journalism" at the annual achievement awards dinner of the New York Theta Sigma Phi at the Biltmore Hotel on June 15.

Pablo Picasso, who 16 months ago made a gift of his unique 1912 cubist sculpture called "Guitar" to the Museum of Modern Art, has now made it possible for the museum to acquire another rare example of his constructed metal sculpture.
Long-term interest rates extended yesterday the increases that have characterized the bond market since a number of high-priced new issues failed to attract investors a week ago.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A study made for the Department of Defense concludes that the Nixon Administration's plan to extend the tour of military service of drug addicts for 30 days of compulsory treatment in Veterans Administration hospitals is unlikely to work.
Paul O'Dwyer, the maverick politician and liberal activist, was honored last night in song, poetry, dramatic recitation and speeches at a testimonial dinner in the Tavern-On-The-Green.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Once again the Supreme Court is on the spot regarding school desegregation. For 18 years it has spoken with a unanimous voice on this highly emotional subject, but now the political pressures for a change in direction are enormous.

ABOARD U.S.S. NEWPORT NEWS, off North Vietnam, June 2 -- Seaman Walter Olivier is embarrassed that his shipmates call him Killer. A slight boyish sailor with a shock of blond hair that falls in his eyes, Seaman Olivier pulls the small brass trigger that fires this ship's huge, computer-aimed 8-inch guns, the heaviest afloat in any navy.
A Suffolk County State Supreme Court justice went on trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges related to allegations that he bought his nomination for the post for $50,000.

PYONGYANG, North Korea -- To visit North Korea is like entering some remote kingdom of ancient times, possibly that hermitlike Chosen from which the present country evolved. In the 19th century the Kingdom of Chosen fought fiercely against all Westerners who sought to open it to trade and commerce, sank and burned ships, including those of Americans, and massacred missionaries in an effort to preserve an independent life and culture.

The city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Bess Myerson, and Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell charged yesterday that consumers played "Russian roulette" when they used washing-machine repairmen.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Family members and about a hundred invited guests attended memorial services for Senator Robert F. Kennedy under gray skies at Arlington National Cemetery early today on the fourth anniversary of his death.

Five oarsmen from the University of Pennsylvania's national champion crew were added yesterday to the group assembling this week at the Olympic training camp in Hanover, N.H. The additional invitations thus mitigated an embarrassment that arose last Saturday when the Penn eight won the national title impressively at Syracuse.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 6 -- Howard Holder, a former Brooklyn school principal, and his girl friend, Mrs. Lynnor Gershenson, were sentenced today to up to 12 years in prison for conspiring to murder Mrs. Joan Holder nearly two years ago.

At one end of the radio dial there is WMCA. At the other end, there is WWRL. WMCA aims its programming at a general audience. WWRL is beamed at a black community. On Monday evening, from 8 to 10, the stations came together to present a simulcast called "Black and White."
Once again American Israeli Paper Mills held center stage in an otherwise dull show at the American Stock Exchange. It was the most active issue with 564,500 shares traded.

Union officials contended yesterday that the Lindsay administration's consideration of possible job layoffs in the Highway Department was related more to pressure from private contractors and bad publicity man to a drive for efficiency.
Seventeen members of the Philadelphia - Baltimore Washington Stock Exchange have announced their opposition to the exchange's stance on institutional membership and have demanded a vote on the issue.

RYE, N.Y., June 6 -- Jim Knowles, 56 years old and the young member of a good father-son golfing team, took a big step toward retaining his United States Seniors Golf Association title by gaining a two-stroke lead in the first round of the association's 68th annual tournament today.
TOKYO, June 6 -- Japan achieved a gross national product in real terms equivalent to $180.8-billion in the fiscal year ending in March, up 5.7 per cent from the previous year.
Gold-mining issues glittered yesterday as Wall Street's favorite group, while airline stocks continued to tumble in a generally weak market.
LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota won California's Democratic Presidential primary today and with it 271 delegate votes at the Democratic National Convention.
Justice Jacob Markowitz confirmed yesterday a referee's report on the settlements of two suits brought as a result of the famous 1963 salad-oil scandal.
PEKING, June 6 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian leader, said in an interview here today that he was unalterably opposed to any Geneva-style conference to end the Indochina war.

A single fingerprint has been discovered on a .38-caliber derringer pistol recovered Monday after a reported early-morning ambush attempt outside the Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, home of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia boss.

PARIS, June 6 (Reuters) -- France believes it is premature to hold an international meeting in London on Thursday to discuss problems arising from the nationalization of the Iraq Petroleum Company, official sources said today. They added that French officials would not be able to attend such a meeting.

Inca Queen contributed a regal performance in winning the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. C. V. Whitney's 4-year-old moved up gradually through the running of the 1 1-16-mile turf contest for older fillies and mares to score by five lengths over the runner-up, Fresh Start, in the field of six.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, veteran of three decades of political battles, entered into a new kind of contest today, that of an author seeking public recognition -- and sales -- for his book.

Interstate Stores, Inc., yesterday reported a net loss of $2,763,000 for the first fiscal quarter, ended April 30. This compared with a year-earlier $1,737,000 loss from operations and a net loss of $842,000 after a nonrecurring gain from the sale of an investment.
Asemblyman Hulan E. Jack was sentenced yesterday to three months in prison on conflict-of-interest charges of promoting food products in Harlem grocery stores.

SAN DIEGO, June 6 -- The electric light and power industry urged President Nixon today to create a National Energy Council that would establish a "reasonable balance" between the nation's environmental goals and its growing energy needs.

The Festival of Women's Films, which will be playing at the Fifth Avenue Cinema through June 21, is a program of shorts and features, documentaries and fiction films, all made by women over the last several decades of movie history.
LONDON, June 6 (UPI) -- A new gold rush prompted by a commercial shortage of the metal shot its price to new peaks today in Europe's free markets.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Meyer Lansky and one of his reputed long-time associates were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to avoid paying taxes on money allegedly received from gamblers on junkets to George Raft's Colony Sporting Club in London, England.
LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- The defense won a partial victory in Federal District Court here today in pretrial arguments over the Pentagon papers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A library of living cells for the study of genetic diseases is being set up under a contract from the National Institutes of Health to help medical research ers in their work against maladies that affect about 15 million Americans.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced reapproval today of two controversial welfare demonstration projects for New York State.
The line of supplicants in Fifth Avenue apartment that serves as headquarters for the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit was seven deep the other day.
DETROIT, June 6 -- Detroit's School Board adopted a budget plan today that would reduce the academic year by 35 per cent for Detroit's 291,000 public schoolchildren.
Dr. George Krsek has been promoted to executive vice president-technical operations, of the USV Pharmaceutical Corporation.

The Can-Am script is the same as it has been for the last five years, but the giant-killer, role has been recast for the opening of the 1972 series on Sunday in Mosport Park at Bowmanville, Ontario. This year the man assigned to challenge the dominance of the Gulf McLaren team is Mark Donohue, whose last regular season of Can-Am racing was 1968.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- The guest of honor came to the picnic here today wagging his tail and wearing a pacemaker to stimulate his ailing heart.

Representative James J. Delaney, a hardy perennial in Queens, and his insurgent opponent, City Councilman Thomas J. Manton, accused each other yesterday of unfair campaign tactics in their contest for the Democratic nomination.
ARLINGTON, Tex, June 6 -- The New York Yankees' debut on Texas soil in a major-league game developed into a crushing reception tonight as they were outslugged by the Texas Rangers, 6-3.
The vice chancellor for administration at New York University, Dr. Lester Brookner, has been appointed president of Long Island University's financially troubled Brooklyn Center.

I get restless in my chair when people start talking about death and rebirth as therapeutic techniques. Mr. Harrington includes. "fragmentation" too, assuming that all us uptight types need to be exploded and strung back together more loosely. His book takes off from the idea of the psychopath and what we can borrow from him.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Occupational Safety and Health Administration ordered today a continuation of asbestos dust exposure limits for four more years despite the recommendations by a scientific panel that they be cut by more than half.

Mayor Lindsay's proposed tax on disposable containers should be revised and levied against those who have profited from using this kind of packaging: soft drink venders, breweries and container manufacturers.

The Federal Government will provide up to $300,000 to the city for a preliminary study of an area in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn that may pave the way for a series of national experiments, it was announced yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla. -- For nine months now, the 110,000 students and teachers in the Hillsborough County school system have lived at peace with one of the country's most volatile socio-political issues -- the use of busing to achieve racial balance.

SAIGON, Wednesday, June 7 (AP) -- United States officials said yesterday that the North Vietnamese, with their harbors mined, their two railways to China cut and much of their highway system severed, were turning more to small craft and barges to move supplies.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Congress was urged today not to give the Nixon Administration the $15-billion in crease in borrowing power it seeks without tying to it provisions for review and reform of the income tax system.

The Princeton Institute for Defense Analyses has become the object of political action by a number of persons for a number of reasons, which, as reported by you, are centered on their opposition to President Nixon's conduct of the Vietnam war.

PARIS -- The world view of the United States would seem to have been decidedly refurbished by recent events: President Nixon's China trip, the successful riposte to the Vietnam Communists' offensive including Moscow's acceptance of the American blockade, and the Nixon-Brezhnev dialogue with its move toward halting the arms race.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- The State Department has laid down a stringent new policy aimed at reducing the share of the United States contributions to international organizations.

Leon J. Levitz resigned yesterday as president of the Levitz Furniture Corporation, which is currently facing charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has violated securities laws. A new five-man executive committee was named to help administer the affairs of the retail furniture company.
Joseph E. Ruggiero, a former New York County Republican official, went on trial in Federal Court here yesterday on charges that he had lied to a grand jury investigating corruption in March, 1971.

Chancellor Willy Brandt has taken a generous and highly unusual way of reminding the United States and the entire world of "the ties that link America inseparably" with Western Europe. It was especially fitting that he should do so at a Harvard convocation commemorating the 25th anniversary of Secretary of State George C. Marshall's proposal of the European recovery program.

The staff of The Harvard Lampoon, which in the recent past has parodied Playboy, Time and Life, was faced with the difficult decision of what to take on next -- Sports Illustrated or Cosmopolitan. They opted for Cosmo. How else could they use a male nude centerfold?

The Barbara Gardner Construction Company presented a tantalizingly allusive but ultimately elusive dance-drama Monday evening at the Theater for the New City. The work blended texts by Kafka and William Burroughs, constructions by Tom Gardner and choreography by Miss Gardner in a non-linear, fantasy production.

I read with amusement your recent news story which quoted Mayor Lindsay as being "deeply distressed" over the conditions in the streets and parks after what he had seen during the past weekend. His politically expedient remark stems from the vantage point of a sound truck from which he was expediently addressing the marchers in the latest Fifth Avenue parade.

RICHMOND, June 6 -- A United States court of appeals here struck down today a Federal judge's order to merge the schools of Richmond with those of two adjoining counties. It ruled that the order went beyond the judicial authority of the courts.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Pay Board declined today to restore the 15 cents an hour it sliced last month from a negotiated wage increase in the East and Gulf Coast long-shore industry.

TOKYO, June 6 -- On the eve of the eagerly awaited arrival in Tokyo of Presidential adviser Henry A. Kissinger, the Japanese Government and business community are just beginning to get their bearings after the Nixon shock of last July 15 and Aug. 15 -- the starting dates of the President's new China policy and new economic policy that ultimately led to the steep revaluation of the Japanese yen.

Elegant, chic, cool, daring or demure, little girl or siren, whatever her image, she's always garbed in fashion that's not one millimeter off the moment. She's the Revlon girl -- the one who models in the advertisements for the newest lipstick, eye shadow or gel.
ALBANY, June 6 -- Governor Rockefeller's office announced today he had signed into law a bill raising to $6,000 the maximum income eligibility level for property-tax relief for elderly persons.

Dave Roberts, a 21-year-old shortstop from the University of Oregon, became the No. 1 selection in the nation yesterday as the major leagues held their eighth annual summer draft of amateur baseball talent.

The Metropolitan Opera's Verdi Festival began auspiciously Monday night with what is arguably the composer's finest work, "Otello," and with singing of a quality to make that argument stick. James McCracken's conception of the title role seemed far more subtly conveyed in the voice than it was only a few weeks ago when the Franco Zeffirelli production was introduced at the Metropolitan.

Members of the United Federation of Teachers have voted to walk out of their classrooms if community school boards or principals allow groups of parents to come in to observe and evaluate their performance.
The Air Line Pilots Association declared a boycott of airline service yesterday to any nation giving sanctuary to hijackers.

PHILADELPHIA -- On May 4, I visited Mylai 2, the camp where most of the survivors of the 1968 massacre have been coralled for the past few years. I was accompanied by several Vietnamese-speaking American staff members from the Quaker Rehabilitation Center, which is located in Quangngai City four miles away.

MONTREAL, June 6 -- In an expansion draft punctuated with shouts of "Who's that?" Long Island and Atlanta were admitted today to the National Hockey League, forming new clubs and swelling the league to 16 teams.

HOUSTON, June 6 -- Senator George McGovern flew back to California today, completing a 2,750-mile political pilgrimage that eased some tensions with critical Democratic Governors here but failed to produce any instant converts to his candidacy.

It is with considerable dismay that I read the account in The Times of May 10 on the report of the General Accounting Office concerning the in-sanitary conditions in food plants throughout the nation. No mention was made anywhere in the article of the action already taken to deal with this problem.

Your emotional plea for more laws to harass law-abiding gun owners [editorial May 18] has no logical basis. The fact that Britain has strict laws and low crime rates does not mean at all that these led to low crime.

Representatives Peter W. Rodino Jr. of Newark and Dominick V. Daniels of Union City won renomination yesterday, withstanding primary challenges brought about by the reapportionment of New Jersey's Congressional Districts.
The Oakland Athletics are still waiting for Vida Blue's first victory, but they're doing nicely without his help.

HAMBURG, Germany, June 6 (UPI) -- Istvan Gulyas, the 41-year-old Hungarian, ousted Jim Osborn of Honolulu at the start of the German open tennis championships today, 6 -- 1, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2. Osborne ranks 12th in the United States.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 7 -- The South Vietnamese command said today that its forces had driven out all but a handful of the remaining enemy troops in the city of Kontum in the Central Highlands and that 200 enemy troops were killed in six clashes in the area yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- Senator George McGovern's sweep of today's four Presidential primary elections moved him to the brink of a first-ballot nomination at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach next month.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 6 (AP) -- Senator George McGov ern captured his home state's 17 delegates to the Democratic National Convention without opposition in today's South Dakota primary.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -- Andre Lacroix, a Chicago Black Hawks center, jumped from the National Hockey League to the Philadelphia Blazers of the new World Hockey Association today for a five-year contract worth more than $300,000.
WARSAW, June 6 (AP) -- Polish Government sources said tonight that Fidel Castro was showing signs of heart trouble after the Cuban premier arrived in Poland for a stop on a nine-nation tour.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 6 -- Senator George McGovern won the New Mexico Presidential primary today, getting about one third of the vote in a field of six candidates.

JACKSON, Miss., June 6 -- Senator James O. Eastland, a conservative Democrat, easily defeated two rivals for the Democratic nomination, and James H. Meredith, the nationally known black civil rights activist, failed to win the Republican nomination for the Senate in the Mississippi primaries today.

I much regret the decision of the Council of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences to deny Ezra Pound a literary award (Notes on People, May 25). The academy did not divorce merit from political stance and "correct" weltanschauung. It effectively defined correctness as what pleases the powers that be -- the Staatsrat or the Council -- and it dragged the concept of correctness from the heights of philosophy to the gutters of sociology.

TOKYO, June 6 (UPI) -- A three-day merchant seamen's strike left hundreds of oceangoing freighters idle in Japanese ports today while cargo piled up high on the docks.
WOODBURY, L. I., June 6 -- The chief of Grumman's F-14 program said today that the first fighter squadrons of the controversial new Navy jet would be formed "sometime this fall" in California.

Valenti, reputed leader of organized crime in the Rochester area, and three other men were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on conspiracy and other charges connected with an alleged extortion case involving a Buffalo-area contractor and a street-paving job in Batavia.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 6 -- A wealthy young cotton farmer whose stepmother narrowly missed winning the Democratic gubernatorial primary Saturday was found slain early this morning off a fishing port near here. A cinder block was chained to his neck.

Goheen, his opportunity to close the two-hour ceremony until he had been awarded and accepted an honorary Doctor of Laws degree with "maximum respect."

SILVER SPRING, Md., June 6 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was moved out of the intensive care unit today and into a private room at Holy Cross Hospital.

TORONTO, June 7 -- Canada's dollar has jumped to $1.02 (United States), the highest since 1960, as a result of new foreign investor confidence in the Canadian economy.

The outgoing Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally, flew into Bogota, Colombia, and tried to clarify what he said in Venezuela and why he isn't going to Chile. On the second stop of the 15-nation around-theworld tour he is making at the bidding of President Nixon, Mr. Connally also conferred with President Misael Pastrana Borrero at the Presidential Palace in Bogota.

STOCKHOLM, June 7 -- In the first harsh exchange of the United Nations environmental conference, the United States rebuked Sweden tonight for injecting a denunication of "ecocide" into the conference proceedings.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 7 -- It is perhaps inevitable that any festival held in a place called Stratford runs the risk of being identified with Shakespeare. Yet I notice that most of the Stratford festivals around the world are wary of too close a connection.

John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, chided the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday, suggesting that the police union stand on its own feet rather than on the shoulders of the sanitationmen.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to the President today'a bill authorizing appropriations of $2.6-billion to finance operations of the Atomic Energy Commission in tile 12 months starting July i. The ro!l-cali vote was 367 to 2.

PEKING, June 4 -- On April 22, 1968, Red Guard students at Tsinghua University opened fire from the roof of the 10-story administration building on another faction barricaded in the science building, and for three months open warfare raged, with occasional interludes.

HELENA, Mont., June 7 (AP) -- Montana voters have approved by fewer than 3,000 votes a new state constitution -- the first in 83 years. In a primary election yesterday they also authorized the state legislature to legalize gambling.

ALDEBURGH, England -- On the sea front late the other night there were fireworks to celebrate 25 years of the Aldeburgh Festival. Representative Lester L. Wolff, chairman of a House foreign affairs subcommittee investigating international drug traffic, challenged yesterday an Administration assertion that it had made "real progress" in suppressing the flow of narcotics out of South Vietnam, Laos and Thailand.

Representative William F. Ryan's progressive record in the area of health care deserves and has gotten continued support from those of us who are health workers. He has successfully pioneered the development, enactment and implementation of programs for childhood lead poisoning, Medicaid and Medicare, neighborhood health and mental-health centers, child health programs, school breakfasts, dental health, sickle-cell anemia, insecticide and noise pollution, etc.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 (AP) -- Jim Ryun added luster to a curious comeback tonight by defeating an excellent field of milers in the Vons track meet at the Coliseum, running under 4 minutes for the third time this season.

The search for the perfect program is something continually occupying the minds of ballet administrators -- or if it isn't, it certainly should be. On Thursday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet came up with a program that could well serve as a candidate for that impossible achievement.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine prolonged the competition for the Democratic Presidential nomination -- and added a bit of suspense about the outcome -- by refusing today to endorse Senator George McGovern of South Dakota.

The elderly man on the bench in Poe Park on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx looked at Representative James H. Scheuer yesterday and asked: "Why can't we vote one-half for you and one-half for the other guy?"
Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, inserted this material in the Congressional Record of May 22, 1972. It is excerpted here.
KANSAS CITY, June 9 -- The New York Yankees did things a little differently tonight. They suffered their latest defeat -- their eighth in 11 current road games -- quicker than usual.

Senator George McGovern, apparently concerned over his standing in the Jewish community, opened his New York Presidential primary campaign yesterday by accusing Sen ator Hubert H. Humphrey of "unscrupulous, underhanded" distortions of his record on Israel.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 9 (AP) -- For the first time in five years, a passenger train from Montreal pulled into Springfield's Union Station last night. It was one hour and 10 minutes late.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- This headquarters on the East River projects a warmth not conveyed by the Palais des Nations in Geneva, where the old League of Nations had its headquarters. There is a richness of woods and draperies and carpeting here, a blend of browns and reds and blues that creates a feeling of solidity and permanence and strength.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A "cold camera" suitable for photographing the stars was patented this week by two young men, one of whom was only 17 years old when the invention was made.

BRASILIA, June 9 (UPI)--John B. Connally, President Nixon's special representative, ended a discussion of international monetary problems with Brazilian experts and flew to Sao Paulo today. The former Treasury Secretary, who is on a 15-nation tour, arrived here yesterday from Colombia.
From the asphalt runway, Norman Tate waved at a husky man beyond the landing pit.

TRENTON, June 9 (AP) -- The State Department of Labor and Industry reported today that the New Jersey unemployment rate in May stood at 7.3 per cent after seasonal adjustment, a rise of three-tenths of a point over April.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 7 -- Countless little candles flickered in rows on every battered window sill in the oldest quarters of Srinagar this week, casting restless yellow light on decrepit brick buildings that seemed about to collapse from did age.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A member of the Canadian Parliament told a Congressional committee today that Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton had shown no interest in studies being conducted by Canada on a duel pipline system to transport oil and gas from Alaska's North Slope and the Canadian Arctic.

CHICAGO, June 9 (UPI) -- Backers of Mayor Richard J. Daley and 58 other Chicago delegates to the Democratic National Convention have contended that party election reforms "worked better here than anywhere else in the country."

A string of 13 box cars, idle since May 30 on a siding in the Brooklyn Army Terminal, will be loaded on Monday with 3,600 bales of rubber. It will mark the restoration of service important to the Brooklyn waterfront -- rail service instead of lighterage.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- Rolls-Royce Motors, Ltd., the automotive section of the once-mighty auto and aerospace enterprise, is to be turned into a public corporation, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- A Washington lawyer was indicted today on charges of running a call girl ring whose clientele allegedly included prominent members of the Washington legal community.
THURMOND, Md., June 9 (AP) -- President Nixon, leaving his wife behind, made a sudden trip back to the White House from nearby Camp David tonight. A spokesman said there was "no crisis."

Two gunmen burst into a basement construction shanty in an uncompleted building at 41st Street and the Avenue of the Americas yesterday and stole $17,533.46 in 71 pay envelopes minutes before the money was to be distributed to sheet-metal workers on the site.

SUTTON, Mass., June 9 (AP) -- Sharon Miller, seeking her first victory on the women's professional golf tour, posted a 72 today for a 36-hole total of 146 and a two-stroke lead in the $50,000 Eve Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

When Jimmy Raney was playing with Stan Getz and Red Norvo in the early nineteen-fifties, he was one of the very few jazz guitarists of that period who managed to project any individuality of expression amid the tinny clatter of bopbred guitarists who were then running through endless successions of uniform phrases.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he could not support in its present form the $1.15-billion environmental bond issue proposed by the state because there were not enough guarantees on where the money would go.

The expected shuffling of the line-up for the 104th running of the Belmont Stakes came to pass at the entry box yesterday morning, but Riva Ridge is still the probable favorite in the classic 1 1/2-mile test.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to delay until June 22 a decision on whether to rescind its approval of the controversial Harbour Village middle-income housing development in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn. The decision touched off a wild demonstration by some 50 residents of the community who oppose the project.

Rusty Staub, the newest sports hero in town, is a tall 28-year-old bachelor from New Orleans with wavy red hair, a soft voice, the good looks of Rhett Butler, a batting average of .300 and a baseball salary of $100,000 a year. Now, if only he could cook.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- United States military leaders are being permitted to wage the air war as they want in Indochina -- sealing off North Vietnam's coast and harbors with mines, followed by the systematic and relatively unrestricted destruction of military and industrial targets throughout the country.

ALBANY, June 9 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed into law a bill requiring a two-candidate runoff election in New York City when no candidate for Mayor, City Council President or Controller receives more than 40 per cent of the vote cast in his party's primary, the Governor's office announced today.
Rain in crop-growing areas sent prices of soybean and most grain futures lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

In mink and in denim, in bleached blond bouffant and in shoulder-length shags, the fans of 37-year-old Elvis Presley flocked to Madison Square Garden last night to see the first live concert ever given in New York by the King of Rock 'n' Roll.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Attorneys for both sides in the trial of Judge Otto Kerner and four other persons have signed an agreement not to release any information to the news media.
Samuel Z. Arkoff, chairman of the American International Pictures, Inc., has been named to the additional post of president.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 9 -- Sixty yachts took off in a mid-Sound spinnaker start today on the first leg of a racing series that includes the Astor, Onion Patch and duPont Trophies and the Bermuda Race. For some skippers, the fun won't be over until they reach Bayona, Spain, a month from now.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced today that it was opposed to the revenue-sharing bill in its present form.

The Barnum Bailey Circus posters dating from 1894 to 1916, now on exhibition set the Kennedy Galleries, 20 East 56th Street, are evidence of the popular approach to poster design that is too often ignored by collectors.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- House investigators accused the Food and Drug Administration today of risking Americans' health by letting most imported foods enter the country without any kind of examination.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Four California Democrats challenged today Senator George McGovern's right to the 271 delegates he won in Tuesday's "winner take all" California primary.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Retail sales boomed to a record in May, up 2.5 per cent from April, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary estimates.

The McGraw-Hill Publishing Corporation was granted a claim of $776,000 against Clifford Irving, the writer whose "autobiography" of Howard R. Hughes turned out to be a hoax. The action, by Supreme Court Justice Arnold Fraiman in Manhattan, also named Mr. Irving's wife, Edith.

A State Supreme Court Justice rejected yesterday an attempt to bar Civil Court Judge Louis Fusco Jr. from running in the June 20 primary for the Democratic nomination for Bronx Surrogate on the ground that he was not a legal resident of the county.

The top management of the Levitz Furniture Corporation took the unusual step yesterday of telling its shareholders that "a lack of communication" among top management was responsible for some of its recent troubles.
Batting .500 for the first two parts of the Triple Crown, Mayor Lindsay switched horses yesterday and put a $2 offtrack bet on Key to the Mint to win today's Belmont Stakes.

Serious questions involving diplomatic protocol and international communication have arisen as a result of the signatures appended by the General Secretary of the Communist party of the U.S.S.R. and the First Secretary of the Polish Communist party to the accords concluded between these countries and the United States of America.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 9 -- Moderate westerly winds provided a good start for the 35th Off Soundings Club 220-boat, two-day race series in seven classes today. Later in the day, however, strong southwest winds brought out spinnakers.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday it has been selected by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and the United Illuminating Company, New Haven, Conn., to supply two nuclear reactors and fuel for an electric generating station to be built in Seabrook, N. H. Westinghouse declined to estimate the value of the proposed contract.
PEMBROKE, N. C., -- A visitor to this Lumbee Indian town cannot miss the "Save Old Main" signs and placards.

Private school graduations are over and the round of June debutante parties has begun. Last night six young women were presented at the 10th annual Debutante Cotillion of the Junior League of the North, Shore on Long Island, 10 debutantes from Westchester and Fairfield counties curtsied to Terence Cardinal Cooke at the St. Vincent Debutante Ball, and Miss Robin Lynn Russell was honored at a supper dance at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

SHIMODA, Japan, June 8 -- A group of leading Americans told a similar group of Japanese at a meeting today that Japan had not come to grips with the many-centered world of the nineteen-seventies but continued to think in terms of the nineteen-sixties' special relationships between Washington and Tokyo.

Presidential adviser Henry Kissinger has repeatedly predicted that serious negotiations with Hanoi will resume when the current Communist offensive in South Vietnam comes to an end. The offensive, after some spectacular gains, now appears to be slowing down with the beginning of heavy monsoon rains. The season for negotiations appears to be approaching again.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller, who have not conducted many joint ventures lately, are industriously lobbying New York representatives these days with a common goal -- to win House approval of Federal revenue sharing next week.

The Board of Education approved 3 to 2 yesterday the provisional appointment of a black educator, who was once accused of harassing union teachers, to membership on the school system's Board of Examiners.
STOCKHOLM, June 9 (AP) -- The United States and China clashed tonight over the Vietnam war in a meeting held to discuss a draft declaration on environmental principles.

PARIS, June 9 -- Six months after tile currency realignment that ended the gravest monetary crisis since the great Depression, the Western world, at least in crudest economic terms, is a better place in which to live.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 9 -- The fourth World Bridge Team Olympiad began here this afternoon amid some organizational confusion. Amid other minor problems, the Vu-Graph was out of commission and the players had to wait long periods for boards.

The Film Forum, that small but enterprising uptown showcase, is ending its current season with colors flying. Two of the three films -- the two long ones -- of a batch labeled anthropological are real beauties.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., gained the final of the John Player round-robin tennis tournament today, but Clark Graebner of New York was forced to default in the middle of his final-round match when his wife became ill.

WESTERN GAILES, Scotland, June 9 (AP) -- The United States, after trailing, 1-2, in the morning foursomes, rallied in the afternoon singles today to lead Britain, 5 1/2-3 1/2, at the end of the first day of the Curtis Cup women's golf competition.
Talk of the Wankel engine, which sparked a sharp rise during the week in American Israeli Paper Mills shares, had an impact on another American Stock Exchange issue yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 10 -- John Paul Vann, a senior American adviser and one of the most experienced United States officials ever stationed in South Vietnam, was killed in a helicopter crash last night.

Six House members were erroneously listed in some editions of The New York Times yesterday as having voted against the omnibus education measure. Because this is an Olympic year, there was special interest in the 16th annual National Wheelchair Games that began three days of competition in six sports yesterday in Queens.

A retired policeman returned to police work Thursday night to try to end a series of burglaries of the catering establishment he owns in the Little Neck section of Queens. SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 (AP) -- Federal grand jury indicted a man and woman loday on charges stemming from the hijaeling of a Western Airlines jet to Algeria on June 1. Willie R. Drexel Firestone., Inc. the investment banking and brokerage concern, announced yesterday that Archie E. Albright had been named chairman, president and chief executive in what appeared to be a major management restructuring.

VENICE, Italy, June 9 -- As a cultural event, the Venice Biennale claims a double interest, It is, first of all, a mammoth international survey of contemporary art, reflecting what official spokesmen in the advanced industrial nations regard as their most prestigious accomplishments of the moment.

And here he was, in films, striving all too successfully to become nobody.

Summer in southern Alberta is an interval of blistering heat between winter seasons which seem to last most of the year and which, as one of Herbert Harker's characters says, make even Manitoba seem like heaven. Covering three summer months in the lives of half a dozen people, "Goldenrod" does for southern Alberta what has never quite been done before by a novel.

Angela Davis walked out of the court in San Jose, Calif., a free woman last Sunday afternoon. After 13 weeks of testimony, the all-white jury deliberated for 13 hours over three days before finding the 28-year-old black militant Communist not guilty on all charges of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy growing out of a Marin County courthouse shooting in which four persons, including a judge, died in August, 1970.

The World of Birds, being officially unveiled this week, is the second spectacularly specialized exhibit building to be constructed by the New York Zoological Society in three years following the highly successful World of Darkness, for nocturnal animals, in 1969.
Daniel Droz and Bruce Inglis are going around with a "well, we made it" look on their faces this month.

Shane Stevens' vivid "Junk City" Op-Ed article on Memorial Day is yet another futile case history of a mugging. Fine reporting, but where is the therapeutic plan to eliminate this plague? Or shall we abandon and flee the city?

A Verdi festival without "Aida" would have been a pleasant novelty, but the Metropolitan Opera thought otherwise about its current tribute to the composer. It even went to the trouble of reviving the work, although it had not been in last season's repertory.

J. Ray McDermott Co., Inc., reported yesterday that its net income in the quarter ended March 31 rose to $2,159,000, or 32 cents a share, from $162,000, or 2 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.
A mural 102 feet long and 40 feet high will be put up on a billboard in Times Square to publicize the flavor of city parks.
The recent wave of skyjacking makes one wonder: Where, in the name of heaven, is the Civil Aeronautics Board? What are they waiting for? Aren't they supposed to look out for safety in flying?

BALTIMORE, June 13 (AP) -A trial date of July 17 for Arthur H. Bremer on charges of shooting Governor George C. Wallace of Alabama, and a Secret Service agent was set today by United States District Judge Edward S. Northrop.
LONDON, June 13 -- Britain's May trade balance continued in substantial deficit, with imports exceeding exports by $11.8-million.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -Total business inventories rose $550-million in April, a little more than in March but still below what the vigorously expanding pace of the economy would normally imply, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -The United States assured the Chinese today that its bombing of North Vietnam close to their border was in no way intended to threaten their security.

MIAMI BEACH, June 13 -The United States team scored well yesterday in the World Bridge Olympiad, winning 56 victory points out of a possible 60. This included victories over India and Sweden, both of which started strongly in the tournament here.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -Patent Management, Inc., of Washington filed today what it described as the first legal action brought in this country for infringement of a United States patent granted on a Russian invention.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 13 -- The spiritual leader of the Conservative branch of American Judaism told Reform rabbis today that talk of merger between the Rabbinical Assembly (Conservative) and the Central Conference of American Rabbis (Reform) was premature, but the time had come to "work together."

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- Rejecting the Foreign Relations Committee's recommendations, the Senate voted today to provide the full $100-milllon for economic aid to Bangladesh that the Administration requested.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -The House Foreign Affairs Committee, by a one-vote margin, today rejected end-the-war legislation proposed by Democrats and instead adopted a Republican-sponsored resolution endorsing President Nixon's policy in Vietnam.

LYNDHURST, N. J., June 13 -- More than 100 law enforcement officers, staging early morning raids in 10 New Jersey communities in three counties, arrested 88 persons today on charges of trafficking in hashish, marijuana, cocaine, LSD, methadone, amphetamines and barbiturates.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13 -- "The system is totally dependent on people being honest," a colonel at the military headquarters here said today in reaction to Gen. John D. Lavelle's testimony in Washington that he ordered unauthorized strikes against North Vietnam last winter.

The United California Bank of Los Angeles disclosed yesterday that an insurance claim against the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York, arising out of the failure of the bank's Swiss subsidiary, has been settled.

PARIS, June 13 -- A dispute between the United States and France over the role of trade in monetary reform negotiations appeared today to be close to settlement. Conference sources at a meeting of the deputies of the Group of 10 disclosed today that France had bowed to American pressure.

The guests were jammed Scotch to Scotch under the caribou heads and rows of beer steins in the Hunt Room of the 21 Club last night waiting for the tardy guest of honor, and John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, was complaining.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The annual pension for the widows of six Supreme Court Justices would be increased from $5,000 to $10,000 under a bill approved today by the House Judiciary Committee.

The man and the legend meet in Howard Teichmann's life of George S. Kaufman and they are one. Everything we thought we knew about the playwright turns out to be true. The lover, the wit, the passionate (and profitable) card player, the croquet demon and the curmudgeon are just where we expect to find them.
Representative John J. Rooney yesterday announced a $1.35million Federal grant to help develop a "vertical industrial park" that he said would create 500 to 600 jobs in Brooklyn.

RAPID CITY, S. D., June 13 -- Funerals were held today in this city's churches for many of the men, women and children drowned in last Friday's flash flood as search teams continued to look for additional victims.
During the past week, your news and editorial columns have carried prominent mention of the tragedy now occurring in the small nation of Burundi, in the heart of Africa.

DETROIT, June 13 (UPI) -The explosion that crippled a DC-10 jetliner and sent it back to an emergency landing at Detroit's Metropolitan Airport last night was caused by a cargo door's blowing open and not by a bomb, officials of American Airlines said today.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 13 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, searching for support in the non-primary states, had lunch at the Governor's mansion today with South Carolina's delegation to the Democratic National Convention.
The generally flat stock market offered a study in contrasts yesterday, as the DowJones industrial average gained a token 1.58 points to finish at 938.29.
The State Power Authority reported yesterday that studies had begun on the load patterns, current facilities and projected power needs of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- The Justice Department's outgoing antitrust chief today delivered a major defense of the Nixon Administration's "tough enforcement" of antitrust laws during the Senate's long fight over confirming Richard G. Kleindienst as Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -The National Institutes of Health awarded grants today for the establishment of research centers in genetics at seven medical institutions, including two in New York City.
The Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday that it had placed orders worth more than $120-million with three suppliers for seven turbine generators to be installed in two new power stations.

" Heritage '76," a program for celebrating the nation's bicentennial through New York State owned historic sites, was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller at a meeting of the New York State Historic Trust at the Museum of Modern Art.

Tucker Frederickson announced his retirement from football yesterday. The 29-yearold fullback, one of college football's biggest star at Auburn in 1964, informed the New York Giants that he would not continue his injury-plagued career "because I can't play the way I want to any more."
WASHINGTON, June 13 -President Nixon is expected to receive a Soviet-made hydrofoil boat soon as a gift from Leonid I Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief a White House spokesman said today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 13 -- The convention was big, of course -- 7,782 delegates and alternates, far bigger than the Democratic National Convention next month. It was noisy, of course. The hall filled with smoke and crumpled paper cups and newspapers as the day wore on.

WASHINGTON, June 13--In the first such order ever issued, a Federal judge is requiring the Government to publicize widely the terms of settlement of an antitrust case before the settlement becomes final.

BRUSSELS, June 13 (Reuters) -- The Common Market today published its position in its trade disputes with the United States, criticizing in particular the way America's trading partners are being asked to assume responsibility for eliminating the United States balanceof-payments deficit.

PARIS, June 13 -- Paul Touvier, an officer of the Vichy militia in Lyons during World War II, has received a presidential pardon, an action that has brought distress to the families of his victims and embarassment to the Elysee Palace and the Roman Catholic Church.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 13 -- They've done some trimming for the United States Open golf championship. The rough has been cut and is no longer a foot high, but it is still sturdy and substantial. And some of the greens have been cut so short at this majestic Pebble Beach course along the Pacific Ocean that officials are concerned about the future growth of the grass on the putting surfaces.

The pace of labor negotiations designed to reach new agreements with deck, engineer and radio officers before the deadline at 12:01 A.M. Friday quickened yesterday.

RASHEIYA FAKHAR, Lebanon, June 12 -- The Palestinian commandos remaining in this section of southern Lebanon, known until recently as Fatahland, scowl angrily at Lebanese soldiers and outsiders, pass unmolested through army checkpoints in Land Rovers or on foot and openly carry automatic weapons.

A front-running performance under the skillful handling of Mike Venezia enabled John Bell's Aglimmer to score a decisive victory in the main event at Belmont Park yesterday. The contest, on the Widener turf course, was at seven-eighths of a mile and attracted nine fillies and mares.

We are a nation of nutritional illiterates. Despite a wealth of scientific knowledge of nutrition, too many of us do not know what a balanced diet is, and are ignorant of the essential nutrients we need and the foods that contain them. We have an abundant food supply, yet our eating habits are deteriorating.

PARIS, June 13 -- Iraq has assured France of continued supplies of Iraqi petroleum in the hectic diplomacy now under way over nationalization of the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company, informants said today.

The best grade of percale sheets, lettered with complaints to the landlord, flapped from balconies at 210 Central Park South yesterday as tenants of the 24-story luxury building borrowed a tactic from tenement rent protests.

MOSCOW, June 13 -- A second youth in two months has burned himself to death and about 200 young people are in jail awaiting trials in the aftermath of two days of rioting in Soviet Lithuania last month, Lithuanian sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -James R. Hoffa was applauded today in the Senate caucus room as an expert witness on prison conditions and reform. His expertise was the result of a 58-month jail term whose origins could be traced to hearings conducted 15 years ago in that same lofty marble chamber.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -Legislation to create an independent Federal agency with authority to advocate and defend consumer interests won the unanimous approval of a Senate subcommittee today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 13 -- John L. McClellan, a 30-year Senate veteran, defeated David H. Pryor, a three-term member of the House of Representatives, for the Democratic nomination for the Senate in a close runoff primary today.

UNIONDALE, L. I., June 13 -- The Nassau Coliseum today filled a post essential to the workings of a big-time arena when Murray Goodman, a longtime figure in boxing, was named the new building's boxing promoter.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a new rule today that would require many stockbrokers to add significantly to the capital they keep available for use in their business.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 13 -Forty-seven cruising yachts went out on the 24-mile America's Cup course in Rhode Island Sound today for some warm-up competition for the 635-mile Bermuda ocean race starting Friday.

State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh yesterday denied a defense motion to allow a lie detector test taken by William R. Phillips, a suspended patrolman and a Knapp Commission witness, to be used in his forthcoming trial on charges of murdering a procurer and an 18-year-old girl in 1968.

RICHMOND, June 13 (AP) -- Robert F. Horan Jr., a Democrat, and Stanford E. Parris, a Republican, won their parties' nominations in the state's only Congressional primary today. Both men are seeking the House seat for the Eighth District.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The country's small claims courts are either unavailable, unusable or invisible to most consumers, a study group reported today.

Your May 22 editorial "Not By Bread Alone" reflects a philosophy of education which is basically humanistic. Few would disagree with your position that the goals of education should encompass cultural and ethical as well as pragmatic values. However, the new emphasis given to career education by United States Commissioner Sidney P. Marland Jr. does not restrict academic studies in favor of vocational training.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The sergeant whose letter led to the dismissal of the top Air Force general in Vietnam charged that members of an American photo-reconnaissance team had been ordered to falsify classified documents concerning air strikes over North Vietnam.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 13 -For a driver suffering through a 37-race losing streak, Real (Coco) Cormier went into tonight's harness-racing program at Roosevelt Raceway with a refreshing outlook.
The city yesterday dedicated a refurbished cargo shed at Northeast Terminal, the first of several pier projects planned for the Brooklyn waterfront.
Voters in various communities in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties went to the polls yesterday to vote on school budgets and related matters.

The Newark City Council overrode Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's veto of its 50 per cent pay raises yesterday by a vote of 6 to 2. The six votes were the minimum necesary to override the veto. The measure increases the Councilmen's salary from $10,000 to $15,000 a year. It was their first pay raise in six years.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Attorney General Richard G. The Queen Elizabeth 2 will dock here tomorrow morning after a trans-Atlantic trip from Southampton and Cherbourg, and Federal authorities said the bomb hoax involving the liner several weeks ago was "still under investigation."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The dumping of sewage and sludge from dredging into the New York Bight -- east of Sandy Hook -- appears to be harming marine life, according to a report by the National Marine Fisheries Service.

HONG KONG, June 14 -- Diplomats stationed in Peking and Hong Kong have alerted their governments to a new flurry of rumors about the health of Mao Tse-tung, with the caution that they should not be entirely discounted.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, who seven weeks ago abandoned the Democratic Presidential primary batle, opened a new campaign today, one intended to make him "a viable alternative" if a deadlock developed at the Democratic convention.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- A 27-city survey indicated today that black youngsters might be more susceptible to lead poisoning from paint in old slums than white children.
I would like to comment on The Times editorial [June 2] entitled "Hospital Crisis."

MUNICH, West Germany, June 14 -- This booming city of 1.4 million has become Europe's main gateway for hard drugs emanating from Turkey and the Middle East, according to narcotics experts, taking the lead as a transfer point from Marseilles in the last year.
Despite a disheartening lack of cooperation from its membership, the American Management Association has completed a research report on "Truth in Advertising."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 14 -- After a 17-hour convention session, almost 4,000 Texas Democrats approved shortly before dawn today a makeshift agreement giving Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama 42 delegates to the Democratic National Convention and Senator George McGovern of South Dakota 34.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission submitted legislation to Congress today that would bring under regulation the sale of interests in oil-drilling programs.
American Ballet Theater will present two world premieres, three company premieres and three revivals during its six-week season at the State Theater from July 4 through Aug. 13.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) -- Attorneys for Anthony J. Russo, co-defendant in the Pentagon papers case, filed a motion today to stay his trial and sever his case from that of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

Three subsidiaries of the Sheffield Watch Corporation filed a petition yesterday for a reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Air Force has discovered a structural defect that may affect up to 40 per cent of its fleet of B-52 strategic bombers and curtail their usefulness, according to Congressional testimony released today.
EAGLE NEST, N. M. -- The little chapel with its curving, gull wings, rising on a hill in northern Mexico, makes some visitors uneasy. They do not seem to know how to behave inside it.

ATLANTA, June 14 (UPI) -- The Ladies Professional Golf Association said today observers hiding in woods and stationed on television towers with binoculars had seen Jane Blalock illegally move her ball during tournament play.

PARIS, June 14 -- Western financial experts established today that money has been flowing back to the United States over the last three months and that this has been the fundamental reason for relative calm in the foreign-exchange markets despite gyrations in the price of gold.
BECKENHAM, England, June 14 (AP) -- Pancho Gonzales used his head to save his legs today and the top-seeded American moved smoothly into the quarterfinals of the Kent tennis tournament.
ATLANTA, June 14 -- With Tommie Agee and Willie Mays's glove residing safely on the bench, the Mets survived the eighth ining tonight and finally defeated Atlanta, 8-3.

RAPID CITY, S. D., June 14 -- The list of persons still missing in this flood-stricken city dropped markedly today as duplications were eliminated, new reports of survivors were received and more bodies were recovered.

DETROIT, June 14 -- A Federal judge in Detroit issued today the most sweeping school busing order in the nation's history, calling for the integration of 780,000 schoolchildren in Detroit and 53 suburban school districts.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 2 -- Attacks by the Tupamaro revolutionary guerrilla movement, counterviolence by the right wing and a combination of inflation and stagnation are fraying the durable fabric of Uruguayan democracy.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- A bill to ban Irish potato trading for future delivery on commodity markets was approved by the House Agriculture Committee today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House Armed Services Committee approved today the $1.3-billion increase in the strategic weapons program that the Administration said was necessary to maintain technological superiority over the Soviet Union.

A psychiatrist who runs a licensed private methadonemaintenance clinic in the Bronx was arrested yesterday and charged with selling methadone to six persons who reportedly said they were not heroin addicts, but wanted the drug for reasons unrelated to maintenance therapy.

RABAT, Morocco, June 15 -Representatives of 40 African nations -- including 23 heads of state -- ended 11 days of meetings here today after agreeing to strongly worded resolutions criticizing Israel's role in the Middle-Eastern conflict and the United States role in Rhodesia and in Portugal's African territories.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -The House of Representatives passed legislation today that would increase appropriations for Federal health and education programs in the next fiscal year $1.3-billion above the sum requested in President Nixon's budget.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy urged yesterday that the Federal Highway Trust Fund no longer be used exclusively to finance highway construction. Sidney Stein, 46 years old, who is fighting a two-year prison sentence for stock manipulation, was jailed yesterday on a Federal court order for contempt in refusing to file reports of his stock transactions.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 15 -- United States Air Force officers here said today that their planes stopped bombing the Hanoi area yesterday, beginning a four-day pause that would last as long as President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union was there.

MONTREAT, N. C., June 15 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) voted today to remain in the Consultation on Church Union, which seeks a merger of Protestant denominations.

DUBLIN, June 20 -- Joe Cahill, the 52-year-old leader of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, was acquitted here today by a special criminal court on a charge of inciting people to join the I.R.A.
Strength in select glamour issues and the volatile airline group carried the stock market upward yesterday as prices finished at their best level of the session.
Mementos of President Nixon's trip to China, presented as a formal exhibition by the State Department, will be open to the public today through Sunday, at the East River Savings Bank.

The head of a leading brokerage house said yesterday that no need existed for stock-exchange trading floors and that markups in securities prices might take the place of commissions paid by investors.

LONDON, June 20 -- Stan Smith celebrated his top seeding for next week's Wimbledon tennis championships by winning two matches to reach the final 16 at the Rothman's London grass championships today. But the rest of the United States Davis Cup team, groggy after a 24-hour trip from Mexico, was knocked out of the tournament.

The jolt of a 15 per cent rent increase is scheduled to hit tenants in 400,000 rent-controlled apartments at the end of next week. Painful as such a rise will be in this period of escalating food prices, the city's decision to authorize it represents a realistic accommodation not only to a court order but to a hopelessly complicated administrative snarl.

ASCOT, England, June 20 -- The wind tugged at wide-brimmed hats, the Queen wore green, the well-heeled and the high-born looked the part, the gulls eggs arrived on time and the prime social event of the sporting season was under way.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20 -Arabian oil countries decided today to lend Iraq and Syria $169-million to help them meet foreign exchange shortages arising from the nationalization of the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company.

Representative Wright Patman called yesterday for sweeping new legislation to regulate the activities of all institutional investors -bank trust departments, foundations, pension funds, insurance companies and the like -that collectively control portfolios worth hundreds of billions of dollars.

GENEVA, June 20 -- The United States and the Soviet Union said today that the agreements concluded at the May summit meeting in Moscow to limit strategic nuclear missiles should spur the conclusion of other arms accords.

TEXARKANA, Tex. -- On a gusty March night in 1971, arsonists tried to destroy every black Baptist church in this city of 54,000 people. They burned two churches to the ground and their fire bombs caused slight damage to three other churches.
ROCHESTER, June 20 -- The premature closing today of all secondary schools here brought to a stormy end the city's controversial mandatory busing program, which was already scheduled for termination.

WASHINGTON -- In a classic critique of American foreign policy, Walter Lippmann declared: "For over a century Americans have believed that the undesirability of alliances was so self-evident as to be outside the pale of discussion. Now an objection which men will not examine and debate is a prejudice." What Lippmann wrote thirty years ago of the American attitude toward alliances may with equal justice be written today of the prevailing attitude toward isolationism.
The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday the formation of three new top-level organizational groups and the election of three senior vice presidents and six corporate vice presidents.

Net earnings of the Sherwin-Williams Company for the third fiscal quarter, ended May 31, were $6,604,497, or $1.19 a share, up from $4,809,390, or 85 cents a share, in similar three months last year. Sales in the period increased 10.9 per cent to a record total of $165,090,113 from $148,809,167 a year earlier.

Arguing Curt Flood's suit before the Supreme Court, former Justice Arthur J. Goldberg reviewed the long and seamy history of buck-passing between the Court and Congress, both of whom have stalled for half a century over baseball's privileged position with regard to antitrust law. Borrowing from Harry S Truman, he told the justices: "The buck stops here."

Shopping centers and malls continue to grow in importance as components of "the American way of life." As the hub of American living moves from the cities to the suburbs, facilities for cultural and intellectual growth do not necessarily spring up there too.

There was a rush to buy T.W.A. warrants on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with the result that trading was halted for about two hours. The Singer Company confirmed the rumors yesterday by announcing that it is switching most of its domestic consumer advertising from J. Walter Thompson to Grey Advertising. The company puts the billings at between $12-million and $13-million.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Food and Drug Administration, initiating a new food labeling program, moved today to require disclosure of the percentage of seafood in seafood cocktails.

The New York City Ballet's Stravinsky festival this week is "something no other company could do," in the naturally biased opinion of George Balanchine, the company's artistic mentor.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A number of former Air Force photo interpreters -- the men who help pick future bombing targets and assess results from previous raids -- believe that the military has consistently exaggerated the effectiveness of bombing results in North Vietnam.

PEKING, Wednesday, June 21 (Reuters) -- Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, had about four hours of talks with Chinese leaders here yesterday on the second day of his visit.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz and leading representatives of the nation's big landgrant universities opened a counterattack today against criticism that their agricultural research favored large producers and corporations while slighting consumers and rural people.

Bruns, Nordeman Co., brokers, filed, a $15-million lawsuit here yesterday against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, alleging breach of contract because of an allegedly "defective" computer data transmission system.
In 1936, when a 12-year- old Brooklyn boy named Eugene Gold graduated from Public School 135, he summarized his life's ambition in his school yearbook in a single misspelled word: "lawer."

Rex Cowan, a British lawyer who tired of his trade and now dives for sunken treasure, saved some of his best pieces of eight to exchange for American money. Yesterday he saw a couple of the ancient coins auctioned for $1,200 each at Sotheby, Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
A special Runway Unit to cope with the large number of runaway youths here, both local and out of town, was established yesterday by the Police Department.

In the heaviest trading thus far this year, cocoa futures fell 95 to 82 points -hundredths of a cent a pound -- under pressure of speculative liquidation yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. A total of 2,952 lots were traded, compared with 2,665 lots on April 11 the previous busiest day.

STRATFORD, Conn. -- Rome and Shakespeare march onward. The American Shakespeare Festival Theater, which opened here on Monday night with "Julius Caesar," last night permitted the plot to thicken with "Antony and Cleopatra."

DENVER, June 20 Judge Hatfield Chilson of the Federal District Court ordered the El Paso Natural Gas Company today to divest itself of most of its interest in the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company and to sell its interest to the Colorado Interstate Gas Company.

The No. 1 international economic worry of the United States, said David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, in Tokyo this week, is this country's $3-billion trade deficit with Japan. To be precise, the United States trade deficit with Japan last year was $3.2-billion. The United States, however, had a surplus of $400-million with the rest of the world, thus reducing its global deficit to $2.8-billion.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Five Chicago policemen, one a sergeant, were reported today to be prime suspects in the gang-style slayings of at least six men in connection with the operations of a narcotics ring that included policemen.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -Net redemptions of mutual fund shares continued in May, though at a somewhat lesser rate than in April, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

Representative Bertram L. Podell's landslide victory over Assemblyman Leonard M. Simon leaves Mr. Simon on the November ballot as the Liberal party's nominee, but only half-heartedly.

Representative James J. Delaney was, in effect, guaranteed re-election yesterday to his 14th term in Congress by beating Councilman Thomas S. Manton in the Democratic primary in the Ninth Congressional District.

The unemployment rate in the state for May dropped from 6.3 per cent to 6.1 per cent, the lowest in the first five months of this year, but well above the average rate for the last seven years. Total unemployment in the state for May was 505,000, the State Labor Department announced yesterday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 20 -- Continuing to play fine golf, Mrs. Justine Cushing of Meadow Brook, the medalist, won two matches in the 69th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

RIO VISTA, Calif., June 21 (AP) -- Water from a broken levee virtually swamped a small recreation and farm island in the Sacramento Delta today, causing at least $10-million damage. Rescuers evacuated 1,500 persons and hunted for possible victims.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- Unless inflation is cubed, the average cost of a one-family home in the United States may skyrocket to $120,000 by the end of the century, a banker told a Congressional committee today.

CHATHAM, N. J., June 2l -Michael Zack 3d of Warrenbrook and Howard Pierson of Riverdale equaled par 72 today at the 6,579-yard Fairmount Country Club course to tie for the lead after a rain-drenched opening round of the 71st New Jersey amateur championship.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $29.5-billion bill to fund the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Department of Labor, an increase of $860-million over the House bill.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A Defense Department spokesman said today that the Air Force squadrons being moved out of South Vietnam "will still be able to carry out their effort" from Thailand.
A few weeks ago Elizabeth Holtzman turned up at a community meeting in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section and asked the chairman to introduce her.
Going its own way, the American Stock Exchange index declined a little yesterday, while the Dow-Jones average covering Big Board shares and the NASDAQ index of over-the counter shares showed gains.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A young Air Force officer, acting "because my superiors and fellow officers have failed to come forward," formally accused Gen. John D. Lavelle today of criminal misconduct in connection with unauthorized strikes on North Vietnam and the falsification of official reports.

Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz topped the list of candidates in Tuesday's Democratic primary for nomination to the State Court of Appeals. If she wins in November, she will become the first woman to sit on New York's highest bench.

I am writing because of an item in The London Daily Express about the Boy Scouts of America. I am an honorary member of the Boy Scouts of America and they are being remodeled as the British Scouts were in 1966.

An explosion and fire that Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery called "highly suspicious" destroyed the interior of a five-story apartment house at 75 West 68th Street yesterday and forced dozens of families into the streets.
MIAMI BEACH, June 21 -The last day of qualifying play in the World Team Olympiad here today became a three-way race for third and fourth positions.
Standard Kollsman Industries, Inc., and the Sun Chemical Company announced yesterday that they were holding merger discussions.
The Port of New York Authority will move more actively into mass transportation regardless of legal barriers designed to keep it out, according to Dr. William J. Ronan.
The Public Service Electric Gas Company yesterday offered its common shareholders 4,386,071 shares at a subscription price of $21.50 a share, on the basis of one share for each nine shares held.
HOUSTON, June 21 -- Although plagued by injuries and ineffective hitting, the Mets still can joke among themselves.
LOS ANGELES, June 21 -The trial of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. in the Pentagon papers case is tentatively set to begin July 5.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that during the summer policemen throughout the city would patrol school property to protect it from acts of vandalism. The inspections will be made frequently, but at irregular intervals day and night, he said.

The toothless condemnation of aerial hijacking that finally emerged from the Security Council this week after ten days of backstage maneuvering exemplifies the international impotence that drove many of the world's frustrated airline pilots to walk off their jobs Monday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 21 (AP) -- A Federal jury acquitted Bobby Wayne Wallace tonight of air piracy charges and three lesser counts in connection with a Tennessee-to-Florida hijacking of a chartered plane last October that resulted in the death of three persons.

" Dan Seymour's 'confidential' memo is the most imaginative copy we have seen from the agency in a year," was the response of the Singer company to the J. Walter Thompson house memo following the loss of the Singer domestic business.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -The defeat of Representative Emanuel Cellar of Brooklyn in yesterday's Democratic primary raised the prospect today that New York City may be without a committee chairman in the House next year for the first time since 1954, the last year the Republicans controlled the House.
Prof. Thomas H. Shaw, dean of students of New York City Community College in Brooklyn, was found slain yesterday in his apartment at 505 La Guardia Place in Greenwich Village.

Distressed because his former clients are avoiding him "like the plague," Robert Presti has filed a $1.5-million damage suit against the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau and its two principal officers.

WASHINGTON -- We are grateful for this opportunity to present our views on the impact of the proposed postal rate increases on an invaluable and indispensable channel of communication -- the second-class mail. We believe the second-class rate increases proposed by the Postal Service, averaging about 127 per cent over the next five years, pose one of the gravest threats to freedom of communication ever faced by this country.
