HONG KONG, June 21 -- At Laufaushan, a sleepy little village on the shore of Deep Bay in Hong Kong's New Territories, men, woman and young children squat near the water's edge opening oysters for the visitors who come on outings from the urban areas of this British colony.
LONDON, June 21 -- Stan Smith, the defending champion, led five Americans into the quarterfinals of the London grass-court tennis championships today and had the most trouble of them all.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 -- United States Air Force and Army oficers in Saigon are maintaining silence on the controversy about unauthorized bombing raids on North Vietnam last winter, despite the implications for Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, who has been nominated to be Army Chief of Staff.

The first day of summer began with only a modest drizzle here yesterday -- almost a relief for water-logged New York -- but the prospects were for more of the downpours and flooding that have occurred off and on since last weekend.
Tenants in 200,000 rent-stabilized apartments will have their rents cut slightly in the year that starts July 1 as a result of an order issued yeterday by the Rent Guidelines Board.

MEXICO CITY, June 10 -- Late in February President, Luis Echeverria Alvarez was asked what he thought about a Governmentsponsored program to help control Mexico's rapidly increasing population, estimated at 51 million an dgrowing some 3.4 per cent a year.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., June 21--A tall, mustachioed 33-yearold gunman later identified as an off-duty Pinkerton guard walked into an office building in this southern New Jersey suburban community today, shot six men to death and wounded six more before shooting and wounding himself.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- The Soviet security police today arrested Pyotr I. Yakir, a prominent campaigner for broader civil rights, in what may be a renewed drive against political dissent in the Soviet Union.
Ending a decline that had sent prices down 6 to 7 cents a bushel earlier this week, soybean futures staged a comeback yesterday and closed higher on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Alfred Hitchcock will be 73 on Aug. 13, but like Luis Bunuel, whom he otherwise resembles but slightly, his talent is only enriched by the advancing years that make most directors fearful and insecure.

A 48-year-old shoe store proprietor from Beacon, N.Y., was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with threatening to blow up the Queen Elizabeth 2 last month while the luxury liner was in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.
The final tallies of two hotly contested Democratic legislative primaries yesterday increased the prospects that a woman would be elected to the State Senate for the first time since 1965.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., operated in the black for the second month this year, enabling the company to reduce its deficit for the first five months by 58.5 per cent from the year-earlier period, according to the report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -Consumer prices, still not reflecting the recent increase in meat prices, rose moderately in May for the third consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -The Federal Reserve announced today the adoption, with relatively minor revisions, of the major changes in bank reserve requirements and check collection procedures proposed last March 28.
NEW ORLEANS, June 21 -In a reversal of policy, the United States Conference of Mayors voted today to support President Nixon's current strategy in Vietnam.

Following are statements by Whitney North Seymour Jr., the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York; A. M. Rosenthal, the managing editor of The New York Times, and The Daily News dealing with Mr. Seymour's complaints against the two newspapers.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- His victory in the New York primary puts Senator George McGovern on the brink of the Democratic Presidential nomination. That makes it all the more necessary that those who believe the McGovern campaign promises the right directions for the nation should insist that he himself live up to that promise.

JERUSALEM, June 21 -- Two of the political parties in Premier Golda Meir's coalition decided today to defy the leadership of the Labor party, which she heads, and press for the limited introduction of civil marriage in Israel.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 21 -- Faced with mounting opposition from the white community, the Montgomery City Commission has voted to rescind its action of two weeks ago naming a street for the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that last Monday's Supreme Court decision on wiretapping would reduce the Government's intelligence about subversive activities, "but not to an extent that will damage our national security."

Lazard Freres Co., an investment banking firm that agreed Tuesday to settle a Government suit charging a violation of the securities laws, issued on Tuesday the following statement, which was inadvertently omitted from yesteradys editions.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 22 (AP) -American jet aircraft attacked North Vietnam's air defense network just north of the demilitarized zone Tuesday for the sixth day, the United States command announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A constitutional amendment providing for a national Presidential primary to be held in early August was urged today at the start of Senate hearings on proposals to reform the present system of selecting party candidates for President.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -More than 15,000 children in New York City day care programs will have to go without breakfast in the coming school year because of a "freeze" on Federal spending, the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs was told today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- Representative Richard H. Ichord, Democrat of Missouri, chairman of the House Committee on Internal Security, said today efforts by radical groups to subvert the military "have been a total failure."

WASHINGTON, June 21 -The Price Commission decided today to recommend that raw agricultural products, now exempt from the economic stabilization regulations, be placed under controls to slow the rising price of food.

Marco Castaneda "picked up" a mount at Aueduct yesterday, and it turned out that his pickup won the feature race on the program. Riding Rafael Escudero's Saturnina as a lastminute replacement for Eddie Belmonte, Castaneda kept the 5-year-old mare in the lead most of the way to take the one-mile Bewitch Purse by 1 1/2 lengths.

UNITED NATIONS, June 21 (UPI) -- The head of the United Nations press division resigned his $40,000-a-year job today in a policy dispute with Secretary General Waldheim that involved the exclusion of two Chinese Nationalist correspondents.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The authorities are searching for four men who rented rooms at Washington's Watergate Hotel with four other men who have been accused of breaking into the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee last Saturday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Dr. C. A. Hoffman became the 127th President of the American Medical Association today and almost immediately spoke out against the growing formation of doctors' unions and national health insurance.
LANSING, Mich., June 21 (UPI) -- Democrats won a major legal and political victory yesterday when the Michigan Supreme Court declared the state's two-year voter registration law unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -Supporters of revenue sharing won a crucial vote in the House of Representatives today, making almost certain the passage tomorrow of this new form of Federal financial assistance to state and local governments.

PRESIDENTIAL: Senator George McGovern added 230 delegates to his total in the election Tuesday as he defeated opposing slates across New York State. Twelve uncommitted delegates were chosen, Representative Shirley Chisholm won four delegates and Senator Edmund S. Muskie won one or possibly two votes.

HOUMA, La., June 21 -- Dr. Earl L. Butz, the Secretary of Agriculture, and his department were severely criticized at a hearing here today for last season's 10-cent-an-hour increase in the minimum wage for sugar cane field workers.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Legislation to create an independent Federal agency with broad authority to establish mandatory safety standards for consumers, products was approved tonight by the Senate, 69 to 10.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America asked yesterday for a wage increase of 75 cents an hour and other improvements in benefits for 125,000 workers in the cotton garment industry.

TEL AVIV, June 21 -- A senior Israeli staff officer, who may not be identified, said today that the operations against Lebanon were "connected with information we had in recent weeks of preparation" for more guerrilla attacks from Lebanese territory.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21 -- An Israeli armored force, striking into southern Lebanese territory today, captured five Syrian officers within 100 yards of the border, along with a Lebanese officer and three military policemen. At the same time, Israeli jets and artillery attacked a southeastern Lebanese area where Palestinian guerrillas have long been based.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- New orders for durable goods declined slightly in May but remained higher than in any month prior to April, the Consumer Department reported today. The statistics for this important "leading indicator" of the economy have been significantly revised going back many months, based on new 'benchmarks."

The Bobby Hull guessing game continues. The Chicago Black Hawks left wing went to Winnipeg with his golf clubs and speculation continued whether his hockey sticks would follow. Hull is considering a five-year deal that reportedly would give him $1-million to sign with the Winnipeg Jets of the World Hockey Association and an additional $1.5-million over the life of the contract.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission announced today a consent order barring deceptive magazine sales practices by Cowles Communications and five subsidiaries.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange a widely watched technical barometer in the stock-market outlook, climbed 222,189 shares in the month ended June 15, the Big Board reported yesterday.

Seventy-one undergraduates in the field of journalism will have part of their college expenses paid in 1972-73 through a record number of grants announced yesterday by Matt Meyer, president of the Scripps-Howard Foundation.

It was a day of downward drift yesterday for prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market. The Amex index fell 0.06 to close at 27.42, while the NASDAQ index dwindled 0.72 to end at 140.53.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 22 -- Among the 930 horses on the grounds at Roosevelt Raceway, 18 are aged 11 years or older and all but two of those are competing in claiming races. HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 -- Aesop, a 35-foot sloop from Portland, Me., was established today as the sixth and final class winner in the Bermuda ocean race. Aesop, which finished the 635-mile race yesterday afternoon following a passage of 5 days 2 1/2 hours from Newport, R.I., took top honors in Class F, which was for the smallest boats in the fleet of 178 yachts.

HUNSTANTON, England, June 22 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire, from Colorado Springs, led a group of four Americans into the third round of the British women's amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 22--President Nixon disclosed today that he was considering a temporary suspension of the meat import quota as a means of increasing the nation's supply of meat and of slowing the rise in food prices.

A record increase of 54.8 cents in the city's basic property tax rate was approved yesterday by the City Council after an attempt at tax revolt that proved to be little more than a pro forma skirmish.

PRINCETON, N. J. -- "The whole world is crazy!" exclaims my 87-year-old great-grandmother whenever my brother and I talk with her. That line always makes its way into any conversation with her; it is her view of the world and her explanation of its ills.

So, we boast, man can split the atom or fuse it; he can rocket a crew to the moon and back; he can bomb a city off the map; he can harness the forces of nuclear destruction. He can astonish himself with his own achievements, both good and bad. But he still can't tame the weather. Wind and water, among the simplest of elemental forces, can outdo anything man has yet contrived.

TRENTON, June 22 -- Gov. William T. Cahill won a skirmish in the New Jersey Legislature today when he got Democratic opponents of his tax reform program to agree to a floor vote in the Assembly next month.

LONDON, June 22 -- Top-seeded Stan Smith, the defending champion, was eliminated from the London grass court tennis tournament by lightly regarded John Paish of Britain today, but Americans gained the other three places in the semifinals.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A former New York City Council President who sponsored rent-control laws enacted in the city 27 years ago told a Senate sub-committee here today that the laws were "ruining the city of New York."

The Grand Union Company reported yesterday a decline of 37.5 per cent in earnings for its first quarter ended May 27. Sales reached a record high but were only 2.5 per cent ahead of the year-ago volume.

CHONTHANH, South Vietnam, June 22 -- After suffering steep casualties for more than two months in an unsuccessful attempt to break through a Communist roadblock and enter Anloc, South Vietnam's 21st Division has been relieved of the responsibility for the job and fresh troops have been thrown into the battle.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had found no need to change its disclosure rules to make sure that defense contractors tell all they should about the risks and losses on those contracts.

WASHINGTON -- Once again the Administration has come before the Congress with a request -- this year for almost three-fourths of a million dollars -- and the plea that the moribund Subversive Activities Control Board be allowed to survive yet another year. Again there is a flurry of activity before June 30 to distract the Congress from the board's 22-year history of inactivity, at a price thus far of almost $7 million.

ALBANY, June 22 -- The Moscow Central Theater for Children charmed most of an audience of 4,000 adults and children at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center last night with "Fairy Tales" by Pushkin, a lavish, color-drenched musical version of the Snow White story and a golden fish who grants wishes.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Nixon criticized today a recent court decision in Detroit ordering massive busing between suburbs and the inner city as a "flagrant" violation of the neighborhood school principle. He said it dramatized what he described as the weaknesses of antibusing provisions passed by Congress.

FORT BRAGG, N. C. -- A woman is always asked to sit down in case she faints. If there are children, the mother is taken to another room so they will not learn of the death of their father from a stranger. It is expected that women will weep, often hysterically, but that men will take the news with greater calm and self-control.

A fellow came in to Ralph P. Davidson's office the other morning and dropped a copy of the June 26 Time on his desk. He'll be saving it a long time -- you can bet on that. It's the first to carry the signature of Ralph P. Davidson on "A Letter From the Publisher."

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 (AP)--National Labor Relations Board examiner Melvin Welles refused to hear testimony today from the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings during the hearing on a complaint filed against the National Football League owners.

GENEVA, June 22--Japan sharply rebuked China and France today for seeking to improve their nuclear arsenals by exploding atomic bombs in the atmosphere while refusing to participate in the efforts at the Conference of the Committee on Disarmament here to curb the arms race.
PINEHURST, N. C., June 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Paul Dye of Delray Beach, Fla., first-round leader with a 75, added a 77 today and won the 66th annual tournament of the Women's Eastern Golf Association.

An attendance record was broken at Aqueduct yesterday, but definitely not on the credit side of the ledger. To use a phrase that might have been uttered at one time or another in an earlier era of sports reporting -- probably by Ring Lardner or Bugs Baer -- "the largest crowd in local racing history stayed away."

ALBANY, June 22 -- Differences in language and culture are keeping 300,000 pupils, including 160,000 in New York City, from "meaningful participation" in school programs, according to the State Board of Regents.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The long-standing unanimity of the Supreme Court on the issue of school desegregation ended today as President Nixon's four nominees dissented against what they characterized as an effort to require racial balance rather than desegregation.

DETROIT, June 22 -- When is a world record not a world record? When it is a "historic performance," according to officials of the American Power Boat Association, who disputed today Bill Muncey's fastest-ever speed in an unlimited hydroplane during a qualification run yesterday for Sunday's Gold Cup race.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., June 22 -- Tens of thousands of union construction workers marched seven miles through pouring rain today to protest a court ruling on picketing at nonunion construction sites.
Men, beasts and machines were driven off playing fields, putting greens and tracks yesterday as heavy rains, spawned by Hurricane Agnes, disrupted sports.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 21 -- China's attempts to cut down economic relations between Japan and South Korea by boycotting Japanese companies that do business with this country is so far having little if any effect.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House of Representatives passed a revenue-sharing bill today by a vote of 274 to 122.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 22 (AP) -- A Federal judge rejected an effort today to upset Senator George McGovern's claim to all 271 California delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Efforts to curb what Representative Morris K. Udall called "the flow of power to the White House" by trimming its staff and executive privilege were rejected by the House tonight.

Because of the storm, charter and party boats did not leave their docks yesterday. Since only a few ventured out on Wednesday because of sloppy weather, reports listed below mostly are based on returns from early in the week.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 22 -- A magistrate ruled today that Ahmed Timol, an Indian whose death while in police custody last October set off nationwide protests, had committed suicide by jumping from the 10th floor of Johannesburg police headquarters.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- about 2,000 women and children encircled the Capitol today in a protest against continued funding of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The White House announced today the formation of a National Committee for Employer Support of the National Guard and Reserve Forces to improve employers' attitudes toward men in the stand-by services.

Your June 6 editorial "Baghdad's Gamble" analyzes fairly well the factors and issues involved in Iraq's nationalization of her northern oil-fields. However, it would seem to me that a critical factor was, by intent or otherwise, omitted, namely, the role of France and French oil interests.

Former Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford, testifying here before the Platform Committee of the Democratic National Convention, predicted yesterday that the Vietnam war would be "a cardinal issue" when Americans elected a President and Congress in November.
WAYNE, N.J., June 22 -- Civil Defense volunteers began evacuating residents along the rain-swollen Ramapo and Pompton Rivers today.
The sentry for the New York area's weather watch is a 12-foot-wide radar dome on the roof of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, 70 floors up.

Leo Zeferetti, head of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, said yesterday that guards in the city's prison system were refusing to eat meals at the institutions to press demands that civilian food handlers replace inmates in preparing and serving officers' meals.
The agitation for price controls on farm products is causing considerable nervousness in the commodities futures markets.

WASHINGTON, June 22--All organization made up of Cuban veterans who served in the United States Army after participating in the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 was reported by Cuban sources today to have been involved in last Saturday's raid on the Democratic National Committee headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Nixon said today that American security interests would be "very seriously jeopardized" if Congress approved the agreements limiting strategic arms without also supporting the Administration's multibillion-dollar program to modernize offensive strategic forces.

The Beth Israel Medical Center was accused in Federal District Court yesterday of having turned away more than 3,000 ill Lower East Side residents who had no Medicaid or Medicare cards and could not afford the standard clinic fee of $45.

The stock market staged a modest recovery in the final hour yesterday as trading on the New York Stock Exchange held to a slow-paced 13.41 million shares.

The metropolitan area, already sodden from a week of sprinkles, showers and torrential downpours, got another dose of heavy rain yesterday as the tropical storm Agnes released its burden.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that all four recent knife slayings of women in Queens might be solved with the arrest of a suspect on Wednesday who had been released by a mental institution in January while under indictment for the attempted murder of a policeman.

DETROIT, June 22 (UPI) -- The former grand dragon of the Michigan Ku Klux Klan and four klansmen were charged today with conspiracy in the tarring and feathering of a high school principal who was trying to improve race relations at his school.

MOSCOW, June 22 (AP) -- Andrei D. Sakharov, father of the Soviet hydrogen bomb and an outspoken critic of the Soviet treatment of dissidents, has proposed a bill of rights for the Soviet Union and urged a major redirection of Soviet economic and foreign policies.

The June 5 column about heroin maintenance by John A. Hamilton of your editorial staff contains a number of misleading and incorrect statements. He refers to the proposal made by Howard Samuels and the Vera Institute of Justice which he misunderstood throughout.

JACKSON, Miss., June 22 (AP) -- Judge Dan Russell Jr. of Federal District Court ruled today that the regular faction was the legal Democratic party in Mississippi, but declined to order the Democratic National Convention to accept his findings.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP)-As thousands of firefighters from throughout the country lined the rain-slicked streets outside, Archbishop Humberto S. Medeiros of Boston celebrated a funeral mass today at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross for nine firemen killed, last Saturday in the Hotel Vendome fire.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Seven South Vietnamese college students studying in the United States on grants from the Agency for International Development have refused to return to South Vietnam, saying they fear prosecution for their antiwar views.

The title is Chairman, New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, but David A. (Sonny) Werblin, never a man to be bothered by details, has to consult his business card to get the title exactly right.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Following is a White House transcript of the news conference held today by President Nixon.
LOS ANGELES, June 22 -- The Government has charged that still-secret portions of the Pentagon papers have been leaked to the press.

SQUAW GAP, N.D. -- There's a strange clicking sound in Squaw Gap these days, coming from within the new, pink cement-block building over by the crumbling community hall. Every so often a workman visits the windowless structure, but the clicking continues. And that's just fine with everyone here.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., June 22 -- Edwin James Grace, who shot 12 men, killing six of them, in an office building here yesterday, apparently had directed his rage at an employment agency that failed to get him a job earlier this year.

KINSHASA, Zaire, June 19 -- The Congo, now known as Zaire, won political independence from Belgium in 1960 but, even more than most black African countries, remained politically unstable and culturally and economically dependent on her former colonial masters.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he was reviewing a number of investigations and allegations of corruption among policemen, prosecutors and judges in New York City to determine "what action, if any, would be appropriate."

Zenon G. Rossides, Cyprus's delegate to the United Nations and chairman of the United Nations committee that deals with the safety of diplomats here, was mugged and robbed as he strolled in Central Park early Wednesday evening, the police reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Treasury disclosed today that the United States had cast its first formal vote against a loan by the World Bank -- a negative vote based on President Nixon's new policy on compensation for American companies whose property has been nationalized or otherwise expropriated by other countries.

GENEVA, June 22 -- Trade union leaders who assert they represent about 90 per cent of the nearly 200,000 workers employed around the world by the giant Dunlop-Pirelli rubber combine said here today they would demand a hearing by the group's top international management.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Supreme Court balanced property rights against freedom of expression today and concluded that owners of large suburban shopping centers might bar political pamphleteers from their premises.

To vote at all in last Tuesday's primaries in this city reflected a triumph of citizen determination over official bungling and pettifoggery. The ballots were unnecessarily confusing. Machines jammed. Polling places were hard to find. Once found, they were often inadequately staffed. Voters at some of the worst precincts had to wait in line until midnight to register their preferences.
ANOKA, Minn., June 22 (AP) -- Dan Gable scored an impressive victory today in the first round of the United States Olympic wrestling trials.

PEKING, Friday, June 23 (Reuters) -- Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, flew from Peking ths morning 10 hours after a final midnight talk with Premier Chou En-lai at the conclusion of a five-day visit.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told Congress today that discussions among governments so far on world monetary reform had tended to "slide past" the fundamental points to concentrate instead on problems of technique and mechanism.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Federal Power Commission was formally requested today to apply a code of fair employment practices to the electric power and natural gas companies subject to its jurisdiction.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota has a new rationale for continuing his Presidential campaign, but it has nothing to do with winning the Democratic nomination.

Strong opposition to the proposed Manhattan Landing development was expressed yesterday as the Board of Estimate heard some speakers denounce, and others praise, the planned $1.2-billion project for more than five hours. The board voted late in the afternoon to delay a decision until its July 20 meeting.

The Pennsylvania Company, the investment holding subsidiary of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, had a net loss last year of $86,512,000 after an extraordinary charge of $98,768,000, it announced yesterday.

Metromedia, Inc., announced yesterday it had completed the previously announced purchase of station WTCN-TV in Minneapolis-St. Paul from Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., for $18-million in cash, plus repayment of the station's indebtedness to Chris-Craft.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- People say to Abigail McCarthy, "If you can write like this, why aren't you writing all the time?" And she answers, "Well, I was writing, but nobody noticed."

LONDON, June 22 (UPI) -- Britain is unlikely to challenge for the 1974 America's Cup, the world's premier yachting event, a statement by the Royal Thames Yacht Club, which is organizing elimination races, said today.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Over State Department opposition, the Senate by a vote of 56 to 27 approved legislation today establishing independent grievance procedures for Foreign Service officers.

The newest White Lion, First Class, is Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, who received the Czechoslovak Government honor in Prague, where he continued his tour of Eastern Europe. The honor was given by Gustav Husak, Communist party leader, instead of President Ludvik Svoboda, who was said to be slightly ill.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 22 -- The Irish Republican Army's Provisional wing, under intense pressure from the Roman Catholic community to end its campaign of terror in Northern Ireland, today announced a conditional cease-fire starting midnight Monday.

HONG KONG, June 22 -- An American source expressed the belief here today that China would like to see some serious negotiations to end the war in Vietnam. The source added that the Chinese might favor an approach more effective than that at the Paris meetings, which have produced little results.

Allard K. Lowenstein, who lost his Congressional primary race with John J. Rooney, the Brooklyn incumbent, by about 1,000 votes, said yesterday that suits challenging the election's validity would be filed in Federal court today and in state court next week.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was reported today to have agreed to a strategy for pushing an immediate 20 per cent increase in Social Security payments through Congress.

Diana Allabach, a young pianist from Toronto, made her New York debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall with a program of sonatas by Scarlatti, Haydn and Liszt, topped off by Chopin's Fantaisie Impromptu, the Nocturne, Op. 55, No. 2 and B flat minor Scherzo.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Illinois Democratic leaders threatened today to file suit to force the seating of their chosen delegates on the national party's three major convention committees.

LONDON, June 22 -- The Bank of England raised its basic lending rate -- the so-called bank rate -- to 6 per cent from 5 today. But the move did not strengthen the pound, which fell again in heavy, erratic trading on continuing fears of an impending devaluation.

OLD WESTBURY, N. Y. -- On this page there recently appeared a piece entitled "Zen, American Style." Its derisive and critical tone and the accompanying caricature of a Zen master with a Frankenstein face over whom there hovered an imaginary zoomorphic creature, seemed to me to call for some more balanced presentation of an ancient and honorable way of life, currently of interest to many intelligent Americans.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 23 -- Christine Platten, a Bennett College freshman, rode Oconee to victory in two classes and took a place ribbon in another today to move into a commanding lead for the Division A amateur-owned working hunter championship at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A number of well informed critics of the Vietnam war, including some men still serving in the Government, said in interviews today that there was no evidence to support repeated assertions by Hanoi that the United States had been deliberately bombing dikes and dams in North Vietnam.
In active trading, prices of all platinum futures contracts, except nearby July, reached new highs yesterday and closed $1.50 an ounce higher to unchanged on 1,380 transactions.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -The Senate Commerce Committee today reported out by voice vote a compromise bill, breaking a long impass on how to correct the serious national freight-car shortage. The bill now goes to floor, where approval is expected by midsummer.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 23 -- The pound crisis became the dollar crisis on the Continent of Europe today, with immediate prospects for more controls of dollar flows.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A Federal District judge refused late tonight to order the seating of Florida delegates on Democratic National Convention committees.
Nobel laureate Prof. Paul Samuelson has expressed the hope that he will live to see the day when a shift in the exchange rate of a major currency does not make Page One of The New York Times.

Summer exhibitions can often turn out to be ho-hum rehashes of past shows, lackluster group endeavors or uninspired afterthoughts that might prove embarrassing during the winter season. But they can also turn out to be an unexpected delight or, occasionally, a most satisfying discovery.
MIAMI BEACH, June 23 -- The Miami Beach City Council voted today against providing campsites in the city to nondelegates expected here for the two national political conventions.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Platform Committee of the Democratic National Convention began today to draft the party's stand on issues, with all signs indicating that its document will reflect the liberal views of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota.

ROME, June 23 -- Nationwide strikes began in Italy today as 1.7 million farmhands and sharecroppers were ordered by their unions to stay away from work for 48 hours in a conflict over contract renewals.
Six of the nation's largest banks yesterday announced that beginning Monday they would charge their best corporate customers more to borrow money.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- After 23 primaries in which Senator George McGovern performed as if he had written the rules -- which he had -- the Democrats here find themselves in almost total agreement on one practical premise.

ANOKA, Minn., June 23 (AP) -- Dan Gable of Waterloo, Iowa, won his fourth straight match tonight, defeating Larry Owings of the University of Washington, 7-1, in the 149 1/2-pound division at the United States Olympic wrestling trials.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Except for some handshakes in the cloakroom, a smattering of applause when Representative William F. Ryan walked onto the House floor and a speech by Representative Bertram L. Podell, it was hard to tell here that the New York primary election on Tuesday had changed things very much.

Slamming Sammy Snead, who some devotees of the divot jokingly maintain has been bird-dogging the small, white ball since the turn of the century, came up with a complaint the other day that was more familiar to duffers than to top tournament golfers.

A dispirited stock market drifted steadily lower yesterday as worry-laden investors pondered the twin developments of higher prime rates at home and the decision by Britain to let the pound float in value.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 19 -- This city, whose recent political alignment with the East rather than the West is apparent in the scarcity of cars of more recent date than the late nineteen-fifties, is jammed with the newest American and West German models these days.

TOKYO, June 23 -- Government and private financial institutions reduced interest rates today in another move in Japan's plan to cope with a domestic recession and reduce the massive payments surplus in economic dealings abroad.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 23 -- Secret talks with local officials, fist fights, angry debate and relentless pressure from Roman Catholic housewives led the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army to grudgingly propose a cease-fire starting at midnight on Monday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Canada -- In the evening, I used to walk through the summer streets of Greenwich Village to the corner of Bleecker and MacDougal, where the Cafe Figaro stood, tables and chairs in the windows occupied by tourists and artists, loafers and lunatics, sitting around, keeping watch through the night.
John M. Lynch, Prime Minister of Ireland, has proposed a union of the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, by agreement with Britain, as the "only solution" for the island's division and strife.

Your June 7 news article concerning the U.S. share of contributions to the U.N. was well justified, as were the actions of the State Department and the U.S. Mission in suggesting a reduction to 25 per cent of the total budget. From personal experience, I support this move.

Mexico's recent decision to launch a major national family planning program represents a policy switch that could have significant repercussions throughout Latin America. It offers a timely boost to the expanding population efforts of the United Nations, to which the Mexicans are expected to turn for supplementary assistance.

Retailers who are prone to gripe about the adverse effect on their business of prolonged rainy spells are happy this week about at least one department. More umbrellas have been sold in New York stores since last Monday's few drops turned into a near torrent than in any comparable week this year.

A city official testified yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court that he saw Michael Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, stomp a member of the Gay Activists Alliance when the homosexual group demonstrated at the New York Hilton Hotel in April.

NORTHBROOK, Ill., June 23 (AP) -- Jimmy Jamieson, suddenly thrust into the role of gallery favorite, responded with a four-under-par 67 today and established a two-stroke lead after the second round of the $150,000 Western open golf tournament.

STOCKHOLM -- At 73, Gunnar Myrdal looks like the film version of a shaggy, rambling professor wise with age. He maintains the interests that made him an international scholarly figure: Economic development of the poor countries, for example, and the race relations problems that he explored in his 1944 classic, "An American Dilemma."

MIAMI BEACH, June 23 -The Italian Blue Team headed confidently for its third straight World Team Olympiad title here this afternoon, aided by over-optimistic bidding by the Aces, its American opponents.
Officials of Beth Israel Medical Center said yesterday that it had been forced to refuse clinic service to poor people not covered by Medicare to avoid being plunged into debt.
From a survey of my neighbors and business associates, I have developed answers to the questions asked or implied in your June 4 news story on Governor Cahill's tax plan.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 23 (AP) -- Australian opponents of French nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific are planning to drop rubber rafts and six parachutists into international waters off the testing grounds at Mururoa atoll.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Interest rates on home loans are going up again, the Government announced today. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed that interest rates on conventionalmortgage loans climbed slightly in May after six months of decline.

HUNSTANTON, England, June 23 (AP) -- Laura Baugh of Long Beach, Calif., was the only American advancing to the semifinals of the British women's amateur golf championship today. Three other Americans were beaten in the quarterfinal round.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 23 -The referee will not do any scoring in either the Muhammad Ali-Jerry Quarry fight or the world light-heavyweight title bout between Bob Foster, the champion, and Mike Quarry at the Convention Center Tuesday night.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 23 -Rampaging flood waters left 31 persons dead in Pennsylvania today and caused property damage estimated at $1-billion.

A Puerto Rican nationalist accused by the police two years ago of having participated in 35 bombings -- and who was subsequently indicted on charges relating only to two attempted bombings -- has been acquitted of one of those attempts.

" News pending" is often the terse reason the American Stock Exchange gives when it halts trading in a company's shares. Yesterday at 1:22 P.M. shares of Binney Smith crossed the tape at 65 7/8, up 1 1/4, and that was the last trade permitted.
Theodore M. Bernstein, second in command of the news operations of The New York Times for 21 years as assistant managing editor from 1948 to 1969, will retire on July 1.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 23 -- Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol and Mrs. Austin Straub of the Huntington Country Club will meet in the 36hole final of the 69th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tomorrow.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 23 -- Quick, how much is two plus two?
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23 -- Israeli warplanes and artillery attacked reported Palestinian guerrilla concentrations inside Lebanon today for the second time in three days.

WALDEN, N. Y. -- One might think that Clement Bartolemy would have had enough of other people's children by this time of year. But no. After winding up the academic years as director of athletics at the Lycee Francais in New York, he and his wife, who have a son and two daughters of their own, are taking in boys and girls from 6 to 12 years of age at their farm.
John B. Santamaria has been named senior vice president and director of administration of Levitt Sons, Inc.

Ellis Larkins, a brilliant but unusually elusive jazz pianist who was last heard in New York 11 years ago, not only has reappeared hero but also has settled down into what is turning into a much longer engagement than he had planned.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP) -- A Federal judge ruled valid today Rick Barry's contract with the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association.

Weather forecasters knew there was a chance of rainstorm problems for the Eastern Seaboard when they noticed a tropical disturbance developing a week ago yesterday off Cozumel Island, between Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and Cuba.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 23 -- The opening session of this year's Association of American University Presses meeting today heard a pointed warning that cost-conscious university administrators may cripple the essential purpose of academic publishing -- producing books of scholarly excellence.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 -- The trotters and pacers were back at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, but harness racing fans, irked by what they termed "management's hastiness in cancelling last night's card," continued today to be critical over the action.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday took the first step in divesting itself of the Canteen Corporation, as required by an antitrust settlement that allowed the conglomerate to keep the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

ROME, June 23 -- Pope Paul VI said in an address to the College of Cardinals today that President Nixon's talks in Peking and Moscow and other East-West contacts had encouraged hope for peace in the Middle East and Vietnam.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 24 -- North Vietnamese forces reportedly struck again yesterday against the Government's northern defense line after having been repulsed the day before, and there was growing apprehension here that they were opening a new southward drive.

The Police Academy graduated two new groups of specialists yesterday -- 14 policewomen who will for the first time be assigned to neighborhood police teams, and 30 policemen who will serve as moderators in a recently instituted workshop program in "ethical awareness."

CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) -Led by city aldermen and ward committeemen, hundreds of screaming supporters of Mayor Richard J. Daley disrupted last night all but one of eight meetings called by challengers to Mr. Daley's delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

Things took a decided upward turn at Aqueduct yesterday, in the matter of attendance. The turnout for the thoroughbred activity was 17,371, a heartening increase of more than 40 per cent over the previous day, when an alltime local low of 12,003 passed through the turnstiles.
LONDON, June 23 (AP) -American tourists in London were able to change their dollar travelers checks freely today but rates varied widely.

The frantic search by American corporations in the late nineteen-sixties for black professionals and executives floundered in the recession and mutual disenchantment set in. WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Stewart R. Mott 3d made a list the other day of the money he had contributed, pledged and lent to politicians or their causes so far in 1972. It "staggered" him.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 24 -- On nearly any other occasion, tonight's spotlight at Roosevelt Raceway would have belonged to Adios Bob, a 5-year-old New York-bred who posted the season's first sub-two-minute mile at the track.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senator George McGovern invited some of his favorite people -- the VIC's, for Very Important Contributors -- to a royal round of entertainment in the capital yesterday, in exchange for a $5,000 per couple donation. Twenty-one stanch supporters took him up on it.

One day several months ago, Edwin James Grace, 33, appeared at the offices of Key Personnel, Inc., in suburban Cherry Hills, N. J. He had previously worked as a guard for the Pinkerton Detective Agency and was looking for "a job in his line of work, security." Key had nothing for him, and last April Grace went back to work for Pinkerton.

YAPHANK, L.I. -- Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic chairman, walked casually into the Board of Elections headquarters early last Wednesday morning and surveyed the damage done to his party organization in the primary.

KeN Buchanan, a master boxer from Scotland, and Roberto Duran, a slugger from Panama, will meet in a 15-round fight for Buchanan's world lightweight championship tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
Warnings of dire consequences have greeted virtually every effort to eliminate the New York Stock Exchange's system of fixed commission charges.

From 1918 until 1955 George S. Kaufman was one of the most important figures in the American theater, as playwright, director, critic, once or twice even a performer, and of course, always as one of Broadway's resident wits. In 37 years he had a hand in writing 45 production.

At the age of 77, S. N. Behrman, author of five books and 20 plays, has extracted a memoir from the 60 volumes of a diary he has kept since 1915. It is, to begin with, a delightful and endearing collection of anecdotes involving such people as George and Ira Gershwin, Ina Claire, Garbo, Ernst Lubitsch, the Lunts and many eminent literary figures.

The first nonprofit professional resident theater east of Manhattan will open Sept. 27 in Flushing Meadows - Corona Park in Queens. For Joseph S. Kutrzeba, its founder and producer, the opening of the Queens Playhouse will be the climax of what he called "a seven-year, long uphill pull."
TUSCON, Ariz. -- Twenty-five years ago at 3 P.M. on June 24, 1947, Kenneth Arnold a Yakima, Wash., businessman, ushered in the era of the flying saucer.

Isaac Bashevis Singer is both an old-fashioned storyteller and a modern psychological writer. His large chronicle novels -- such as "The Family Moskat," "The Manor" and "The Estate" -- are thick with plot and characters and draw us into the rich and complex life of the Eastern European Jewish communities.

MIAMI BEACH, June 24 -- Italy won a convincing victory here today in the World Bridge Olympics. The celebrated Blue Team, which captured 12 world titles in the fifties and sixties, emerged from a two-year retirement to beat the Aces, who won the world title for the United States in 1970 annd 1971, by 65 inenational match points.

Rick Barry, the New York Nets' top scorer and No. 1 gate attraction, is considering his next step after a court ruling that ordered him to return to the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association.
ATLANTA, June 24 -- The subject was basketball, or more specifically, how to get more blacks to attend Atlanta Hawks' games.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Federal Highway Administration has announced that 112,922,354 motor vehicles were registered in the United States during 1971, an increase of more than 4.5 million during the year.

ROBERT Altman, who is now shooting Raymond Chandler's "The Long Goodbye" with Elliott Gould and a nifty newcomer named Nina Van Pallandt, has just said hello to another movie project.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The good news is that President Nixon has signed the Higher Education Bill, with its aid for colleges and universities and its mild restraints on pupil busing. The bad news is that he is still threatening to campaign in the fall for a constitutional amendment prohibiting busing.

BONN, June 24 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel declared in Berlin today that they would seek federal elections in November to end the tie-vote situation that has stymied the Parliament since April.
Alexander Casella's article, "The Politics of Prisoners of War" (May 28), is misleading and inaccurate on a number of points.

The metropolitan area began drying out yesterday after two weeks of sporadic rain that caused flooding in some places and disrupted commuter train and highway traffic.

MINEOLA, L.I. -- Ballet 4, until last October known as the Recreation Ballet Company and operating under the auspices of the Nassau County Department of Parks and Recreation, is now at the crossroads. Having lost the support of the county, which reorganized its entire performing arts program at the end of last summer, the company is now very much in need of funds and rehearsal space.

MATTITUCK, L. I. -- In something vaguely akin to the salmon's upstream swim at spawning time or the return of the Capistrano swallows, 5,000 people converged on this rural hamlet last weekend to pay homage to that most delicate, delectable and succulent of beauties, the Long Island strawberry.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 22 -- "Pragmatism" is a word that recurs frequently in conversations with Jordanian officials as well as diplomats observing King Hussein's policies toward his Israeli enemy, his Arab friends and his Western suppliers of military and development assistance, principally the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The National Cancer Institute named a contractor yesterday to operate its newly acquired facilities at Fort Detrick, Md., and predicted that, by fall, the former biological warfare laboratories would be fully at work toward the conquest of cancer.

TOMS RIVER -- The state and the Federal Government have scheduled a four-day conference here this week at which they will present a joint implementation plan for ending pollution along the Jersey shore by the end of 1976.

SAN FRANSICO, June 24 (UPI) -- An appellate court has ruled against a lawyer who had attempted to claim depletion allowances on his and his wife's bodies.

A PLAYER should be happy in slam bidding if his trump suit is substantial, and sad if his trumps are feeble. At a low level the strength of the trump suit is a minor consideration. The combined point-count and the existence of an eight-card trump fit are the vital matters, for if there are losers in the trump suit there will be compensating winners elsewhere.

THE mounting concern over rising prices for meat and other foods in the United States and the sudden, dramatic action of Britain in floating the pound sterling last week diverted the attention of the business and economic community from the domestic economy and the securities markets.

EAST RUTHERFORD -- One week after Joe Dressel and Chip Taylor opened their Town House Inn in February, 1969, they sent out a desperation call for a banjo player who could lead singalongs, because the leader of the quartet that had played for them the week before could not make it.

MINEOLA, L. I. -- A program to send prisoners off to paying jobs in the outside world by day and return them to jail each night has proved so successful that Nassau County is about to widen its scope sevenfold.
WHEELING, West Va., June 24 -- A flood crest swept southward along the Ohio River Valley today after inundating parts of downtown Pittsburgh, and hundreds of homes were evacuated here.

In our governmental process, the executive has become the predominant branch, and cabinet officials have therefore taken on added importance. However, the only manner in which the people are able to exercise any control over nominations to a cabinet is through the inadequate procedure of advise and consent of the Senate.

LONDON, June 24 -- On a flat asphalt field in East London, Mrs. Charity Eastwood steps out of her battered trailer each morning to heat up a pot of coffee. The open fire flickers. She pauses, then stares at the cars streaming toward the city.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- A Chicago investment banker who has returned from a trip to China says that he made a close relationship with the Communist Chinese by pledging support and a $5,000 reward in a hunt for the prehistoric Peking man, missing since Pearl Harbor was attacked by the Japanese on Dec. 7, 1941.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey warned the Platform Committee of the Democratic National Convention today that if the party "falls into the hands of any narrow, ideological elite" it will lose the November election to "the forces of reaction, racism and privilege."

Jewish young men and women face "relatively greater" job-hunting difficulties in the nineteen-seventies and should give more consideration to nonprofessional jobs than they have in the past, according to a new Federal analysis.

The Dick Abramses of Rochester were in town last weekend with their neighbors, the Alan Calderons. The Abramses had been in Boston the weekend before, and got there the same way they got here. They have their own plane.

The United States national fencing championships, which will largely determine the makeup of this summer's American Olympic fencing team, open Saturday at Bentley College in Waltham, Mass.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., -- Cotton, once dethroned as the king of fibers, is enjoying a renewed favor in the world of textiles.

PARIS -- American Presidential campaigns sometimes cast long shadows overseas and this particularly appears to be the case in 1972. Already one foreign ambassador has been reproached for hints of intervention and, far more important, many capitals appear to be taking exceptional interest in the projected contest.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 -- John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, has told the Federal District Court that is hearing the Pentagon papers case that he routinely leaked classified Government documents to the press when he was Ambassador to India and when he held other official positions.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I. -- On July 24, a huge self-propelled vessel resembling a giant kettledrum, which serves as a waterborne concert stage for the American Waterways Wind Symphony, will drop anchor here for a diversified program of music.

The overwhelming vote in the House of Representatives for a five-year program of revenue sharing marks the first step toward a fundamental advance in the American governmental structure -- one in which the Federal Government acts as centralized tax collector for the states and localities.

The City Commission on Human Rights charged yesterday that the law firm of Royall, Koegel Wells, 200 Park Avenue, had practiced sex discrimination in the recruitment, hiring, promotion and treatment of women lawyers.

Women got the vote in 1920 but they have got little in politics since. FOR the new Economy-Sized Islamic republic of Pakistan, April 21 was supposed to have been a day of national rejoicing, the first day of a new era -- one of those wicked-witch-is-dead days that children cherish but that triumphant politicians cherish even more.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 -- Sultan Qabus Bin-Said of Oman, who arrived in Amman today on a state visit to Jordan, is to marry King Hussein's eldest daughter, Princess Alia, according to informed diplomatic sources here.

ARLINGTON, Tex., June 24 (AP) -- The Texas Rangers scored five runs in the eighth inning tonight and beat the Chicago White Sox, 3-1. The late surge was sparked by Lenny Randle's double that drove in three runs and Dick Billings's two-base hit that scored two more runs.

YONKERS, June 24 -- Richard L. Ottinger, the former Westchester County Representative, announced this week that the issue of crime control would play a major part in his campaign for reelection to the House.

Meat prices rose 4 to 10 cents a pound last week in the New York City and Hartford areas -- the only ones where government price reporters maintain a week-by-week price watch -- and the New York and Connecticut State Agriculture Departments warned consumers that still higher prices were likely.

ENGLEWOOD -- A pleasant, slightly overgrown backyard in a middle-class black neighborhood here will make its annual transformation into an art gallery this afternoon for a one-man show by A. C. Hollingsworth.

The recent financial failure of Lennen Newell, Inc., has renewed the advertising industry's interest in who is responsible for the debts incurred by a defunct agency on behalf of its advertiser clients.
New schedules on the Long Island Rail Road, the product of several years work, go into effect tomorrow on every division of the commuter line.

The Health Department yesterday cited 20 city food establishments where inspectors have found serious violations of the Health Code. The list was released by the Health Services Administrator, Gordon Chase.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 24 (UPI) -- The Amsterdam Court has confirmed a ruling of the lower district court that Dutch and foreign hippies may sleep in a part of the downtown Vondel Park.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I. -- More than seven years ago, a volunteer program was started here to help meet the needs of elderly people. It expanded dramaticaly and now, its organizers say, a major problem has risen out of its popularity.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 24 (UPI) -- Steve Prefontaine ran to an American record in the 3,000 meters today, beating his nearest competitor by 100 yards in a highlight of the Rose Festival track meet on a cold, drizzly afternoon.

CHICAGO -- The Administration's wage-price stabilization program is about to face its greatest challenge: a sharp increase in costs for the table -- meat, specifically -- in the next few months. At a time when the Presidential election campaign will be at its height.

HANOVER, N. H., June 24 -- Harry Parker, the United States Olympic crew coach, announced today that 22 oarsmen and five coxswains had been invited to compete for the berths of 14 oarsmen and two coxswains to represent the United States in the eight-oared and four-with-coxswain competition at the Olympic Games in Munich, Germany.

MILWAUKEE, June 24 (AP) -- John Briggs homered and Bob Heise stroked a two-run double today as the Milwaukee Brewers beat Boston, 5-2. Eddie Kasko, the Red Sox manager, and two of his players were tossed out of the game.

CADILLAC, Mich., June 24 (UPI) -- Homer Rees Davison, a former president of the American Meat Institute, died last night at his home here. He was 73 years old.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 25 -- The language is Portuguese and June 21 marks the start of a cold, windy and damp winter in southern Brazil. But language and weather aside, market analysts here are just as quick with explanations of erratic behavior of stock prices as their New York cousins.

ROCKY HILL, Conn., June 25 (AP) -- Through the use of dental charts the police identified the body of a man found floating in the Connecticut River near the Rocky Hill-Glastonbury ferry dock last Friday as Gary Dube, 25 years old, of Agawam, Mass.

DALTON, Ga., June 25 (AP) -- As eight young persons listened to music at a party early today, one of them suddenly began shooting the others with a 45-caliber pistol, the police said. Three were killed and two wounded.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex. (UPI) -- Richard Petty, overcoming track temperatures of 140 degrees, pulled away from Bobby Allison and Bobby Isaac today and posted an easy victory in the $91,395 Lone Star 500 Nascar race at Texas World Speedway.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- The Soviet Union, still struggling toward the proclaimed goal of a universal high school education for its citizens, announced a program of modernization today designed to make schools more responsive to the needs of society.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -The Democratic party completed today, five months after it began, the complicated process of choosing the delegates who will cast 3,016 votes at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach to nominate the party's candidate for President.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 25 (Canadian Press) -- Nine persons, seven of them Indian high school students, were killed yesterday when a twin-engined plane crashed and burned on a residential street shortly after taking off from Winnipeg airport.

NEW DELHI, June 25 -- A few years ago, the scenes along the storied Grand Trunk Road, the setting of tales by Rudyard Kipling, had Changed little since the Mogul emperors' caravans traveled that strategic highway from the Khyber Pass to Calcutta.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 25 (UPI) -- The Nevada State Athletic Commission refused today to waive an accidental butting rule, despite a strong protest from Angelo Dundee, trainermanager of Muhammad Ali.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday that Reginald H. Jones, born the son of an English steel mill foreman, had been elected president, effective immediately.

BELFAST, June 25 -- Troops and terrorists fought a gun battle in Belfast today as the people of Northern Ireland waited to see the effect of the truce called by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army for midnight tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, June 25 -- Israel's national airline, El Al, weathered a year of crisis in international aviation and finished slightly in the black, the company's annual report showed today. A profit of 113,551 Israeli pounds, approximately $27,000, was recorded for the fiscal year ended March 31.

[Editorial June 19.]

Carlos Monzon, the world middleweight boxing champion, isn't resting on his laurels. The Argentine, who successfully defended his crown against France's JeanClaude Boutier nine days ago, agreed yesterday to meet Tom Bogs of Denmark in a title match at Copenhagen Aug. 19.

LONDON, June 25 -- The Tonkin plain of North Vietnam is hemmed in by mountains to the north and west, the sea to the southeast. In the rainy season every summer vast amounts of water pour out of the mountains and down the rivers that lace the plain. The principal river gives its name to the area: the Red River Delta.

State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger disclosed yesterday that 181 -nearly 19 per cent -- of the 974 cases of relief fraud or abuse that his office has investigated and referred to local welfare commissioners came from upstate areas.

In a politically courageous move, Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey has proposed fundamental reform of his state's totally inadequate and regressive tax structure. Local governments have had to shoulder an inordinate responsibility for delivering services while relying on local property taxes, which, as a result, are higher in New Jersey than anywhere else in the nation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 25 -- James W. Sykes, the skipper of Dixie, won the Long Island Sound district championship of the Shields Class by 1 point at Larchmont Yacht Club today when no one finished the third and final race in the two-day series within the time limit.
With the female prerogative of changing her mind, Mrs. Bernice Gera again is a housewife instead of a minorleague umpire.
With obvious scorn for his young challenger, Ken Buchanan of Scotland will defend the world lightweight boxing title tonight at Madison Square Garden against Roberto Duran of Panama.

JERSEY CITY, June 25 -- The roving ambassadors of Brazil, Pele and his team, Santos, put on a brilliant soccer performance at Roosevelt Stadium today as the Brazilians routed Catanzaro of Italy, 7-1, before 15,343 delighted fans.

NEW CITY, N. Y., June 25 -Five prisoners escaped from the Rockland County Jail here today after joining a volunteer bucket brigade when water pipes burst on the second floor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 -- Remote as the prospects of peace now seem to most South Vietnamese, at least a few high officials here have begun to worry about the staggering social and economic problems that peace and demobilization will bring.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -The Credentials Committee of the 1972 Democratic National Convention met for the first time tonight to decide the fate of 1,281 delegates whose right to go to Miami Beach has been challenged as a violation of new party reform rules.

DETROIT, June 25 -- Proving an invincible man in his flying machine, Bill Muncey won his fifth Gold Cup race today. Muncey averaged 103.547 miles an hour in his Atlas Van Lines unlimited hydroplane, beating his nearest rival by more than a mile in the final heat.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -Moves by the Secret Service to tighten security around the President and Presidential candidates in reaction to assassination fears are creating friction between the Secret Service and the Washington press corps.

ALBANY, June 25 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, overlooking what he termed the "differences" between himself and President Nixon, conducted a two-hour strategy session here today on behalf of the President's re-election effort.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 25 (AP) -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said today he hoped to meet Sheik Mujibar Rahman, Prime Minister of Bangladesh, in the second half of next month and "prepared to go to Dacca," if necessary.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- At 6:30 A.M. on a recent Tuesday, Mrs. Jacob Hess, a pleasant-faced, comfortably proportioned woman, wearing the traditional Mennonite "prayer veiling" cap, was eating some of the profits. WASHINGTON, June 25 -The Nixon Administration believes that the current policy review in Hanoi should provide a firm indication within the next two weeks whether a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war is feasible before the United States Presidential election in November.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 21 -- The new North-South agreement on an agenda for talks about travel and other contacts between family members separated in North and South Korea is only a small beginning but it has raised hopes that North-South antagonism can in time be adjusted peacefully.

William Dunas contrasted the import and impact of words and movement with quiet intensity in his unhurried solo "The Time of Your Life" Saturday afternoon at Westbeth. This short work, one of a series of solo pieces created by Mr. Dunas in the last two years, further elaborates his examination of action and symbol.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -Displaying surprising harmony, a Democratic platform drafting group completed three planks today that reflect the liberal thrust of Senator George McGovern's candidacy but are so general they were termed acceptable by representatives of Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edmund S. Muskie and Henry M. Jackson.

CINCINNATI, June 25 -- A new era began in this city last night when the Cincinnati Summer Opera moved into the newly renovated Music Hall and ended its 52-year tradition of outdoor performances at the Cincinnati Zoo, sometimes in competition with lions and ducks and other vocal creatures in residence there.

For women who can't wait until next fall to start collecting cashmere sweaters, Altman's has a supply on hand right now. They're by Valerie Louthan, a lively, redhaired designer who used to work for Braemar and recently formed her own company in Scotland, where the best cashmeres are made. Hers are "for young people who never knew how nice cashmere feels," said the designer, who firmly believes cashmere is addictive.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Political campaigns are as dirty as ever, although the type of abuse is changing, Samuel J. Archibald, executive director of the Fair Campaign Practices Committee, said today.
William J. Glinsman, president of the Allied Building Inspectors Union, acknowledges the existence of corruption among his members, but stresses that there are also many honest inspectors.
The Stravinsky Festival ended at the State Theater last night the same way it had begun: with emotion, applause and an announcement of things to come.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 25 (AP) -- Hank Iba, the head coach, announced today the 12man United States Olympic basketball squad. Six members of the team are 6 feet 9 inches or taller. It also includes the second-string center of the national championship team of last season, the University of California, Los Angeles.

Ordering by mail from catalogues or from enticing advertisements in magazines seems easy and pleasant. The customer can sit at a desk, fill out a form, write a check, paste a stamp on the envelope and walk to a mailbox -- and then wait.

MIAMI BEACH, June 25 -The victory of the Italian Blue Team in the world championships that ended here yesterday was far from unexpected. The magnificent sextet of Pietro Forquet, Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, Walter Avarelli, Massimo D'Alelio and Camillo Pabis Ticci has been unbeaten on any major occasion in the last decade, and Italy has now won 13 world titles since 1957.

BRUSSELS, June 25 -- Eurobonds dealers are breaking out their monetary crisis survival kits for the umpteenth time, with the market mood turning philosophical under the latest barrage of currency unrest.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -The Price Commission met in special session today to discuss the issue of soaring food prices but concealed its deliberations under an uncharacteristic cloak of Secrecy.

MORICHES, L.I., June 25 -Bill Pagels of the Wet Pants Association, Sayville, who arrived too late to compete in the first event of the six-race round robin series yesterday, captured his third straight Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association men's sailing championship today. His score included four firsts and a fourth.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- At long last this should be an American year at Wimbledon.

DACCA, Bangladesh, June 25 -- Police and paramilitary forces today recovered large quantities of arms and stolen goods in house - to - house searches here. They also evicted persons who they said were illegally occupying houses abandoned by non-Bengalis.
ATOKA, Okla. -- "I been praying that God would send a worm to eat the vines," said the Rev. Billy Joe Howard of the First Baptist Church of Kenefick.

LONDON, June 25 -- The Shah of Iran, before leaving London today, gave a clear declaration of Iran's determination to continue a steady supply for many years of Iranian oil to world markets -- and therefore primarily to Western markets at fair world prices.

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- The New York Yankees' six-game winning streak turned suddenly into a two-game losing string at Municipal Stadium as the Cleveland Indians swept a doubleheader, 4-3 and 5-1, today.

COPENHAGEN -- Thirty-three years ago the enormous release of energy through splitting of the atom was first demonstrated in a small institute here. Consequences for the world were historic.

WELLSVILLE, N.Y. June 25 -- Like well-placed punches, two floods struck this village of 6,000 inhabitants this week, pouring cascades of water, mud and debris onto a third of its homes and stores, destroying three bridges, wrecking part of its hospital, carrying away perhaps 100 automobiles, cutting off its electricity and telephones to the outside world and polluting its water supply.

GROTON, Conn., June 25 -The Connecticut Citizen Action Group -- a Ralph Nader-affiliated organization -- charged today that the United States Navy is violating Federal environmental laws by constructing a 300-family housing project for personnel from its submarine base here.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- Inventories are seen holding the key to future steel demand.
One of the St. Louis players put Scipio Spinks's stuffed gorilla in the clubhouse drier before yesterday's doubleheader, then the Cardinals put the Mets through the wringer.

MONTREAL, June 25 (UPI) -A gunman walked into a Montreal delicatessen early today, ordered four employes into a walk-in freezer, shot them to death and then covered their bodies with produce. He also wounded a security guard.
LONDON, June 25 -- The most talked-about man in Britain these days is a 51year-old judge, Sir John Donaldson, a do-it-yourself enthusiast who is being accused of doing too much himself.
FLEURIMONT, Que., June 21 -- Robert Morgan, an animated 15-year-old, hitchhiked from his home in Toronto two weeks ago, bound for a vacation on the West Coast.
PARIS, June 25 -- Belatedly, those who govern Paris are drawing up new zoning regulations to limit high-rise buildings and preserve what is left of the city's harmonious skyline.

PERU, Ind., June 25 -- A search party of 150 persons, including 100 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, failed today to find an armed skyjacker, his body or the money he took when he leaped out of an airliner near here yesterday.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I. June 25 -More than 4,400 acres of wetlands have disappeared from Long Island in the last eight years, according to a report prepared by scientists of the Marine Sciences Research Center of the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Martha Mitchell, the wife of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, was reported to have said today that she was leaving her husband "until he decides to leave" his job as President Nixon's campaign manager.

LUXEMBOURG, June 25 -- A dozen monetary seizures in 63 months and another just beginning -- this was the record as the Common Market prepared once again to try to deal with the consequences of too many dollars in the world.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Ralph Nader said today that his investigators had begun a thorough study of Congress. He said the findings would be issued before the November elections.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A Federal judge here ruled today that the oath of allegiance required of applicants for a United States passport is unconstitutional. He directed the State Department immediately to cease requiring such oath and denying passports to persons who refuse to take them.
