Message from Henry A. Kissinger, then a Harvard professor, to Mr. Bo, delivered by Mr. Marcovich on Sept. 14, 1967.

VIENNA, June 27 (Reuters) -- The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today cut short its summer conference here and issued a statement rejecting Western oil company proposals for compensation on future oil revenue losses.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 27 -- Foreign-exchange traders here today expected a little smoother sailing for the dollar following the agreement of Common Market countries last night in Luxembourg to buy more dollars if necessary to defend existing fixed currency rates.
RIVERTON, Wyo., June 25 -- Anita Portwood has received so many calls lately that sometimes she picks up the telephone and says, "Mrs. Portwood is out on the range and won't be back until July 5."
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Capitol police arrested 111 antiwar protesters who blocked a hallway outside the Senate chamber this afternoon.

Peter J. Mack of Far Rockaway, Queens, is 67 years old and has chronic high blood pressure. Last November, he told a hearing yesterday, New York Telephone Company billed him for several calls to California he never made. After he refused to pay the bill pending an investigation, his phone service was cut off.

The state warned New York City yesterday that a recent change in the city's rent control program was illegal and could not go into effect without approval of the State Commissioner of Housing and Communiy Renewal.

A man once described the Cincinnati Summer Opera at the Zoo as "The place where you can't hear 'Vissi d'arte' for the ducks." Well, the Cincinnati forces have just moved into the city's grand old Music Hall, leaving the ducks to compete only with the airplanes overhead.
President Nixon asked Congress yesterday to approve an immediate $100-million in Federal emergency relief for five states hit hardest by last week's floods.
Message from United States to Mai Van Bo, North Vietnamese representative in Europe, dated Aug. 25, 1967.

In a letter appearing in your June 14 issue Dr. Philip Kaufmann recommends "a completely different environment" as a needed ingredient for the therapy of drug addicts, He states "an American island in the South Pacific" would provide such a change of environment.
A 27-year-old Bronx man was arrested early this morning after he allegedly broke into a branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 749 East Tremont Avenue.
Short covering and a strong demand sent soybean futures prices higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Beans, oil and meal all shared in the advance.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 27 (Reuters) -- Denmark raised her bank rate from 7 to 8 per cent today. The new rate will go into effect tomorrow, the Central bank said.

BOMBAY, India, June 17 -- Among the million or more homeless people of Bombay, the thousands who live in the wide drainpipes stored on vacant lots are considered the aristocrats of the squalid slums that disfigure one of India's leading cities.

The dollar and the pound rallied yesterday in the New York foreign exchange market. But dealers cautioned that the recovery was largely the result of trading among market professionals, and did not necessarily indicate that the international money crisis had passed.
The Bronx portion of the Triborough Bridge was closed for almost 12 hours yesterday because of a fire beneath the section, and massive traffic jams developed in arteries to and from the Bronx.

I confess I read the first hundred or so pages of Theodore Weesner's first novel, "The Car Thief," with wandering attention and a degree of irritation. Mr. Weesner's story concerns a teen-age punk named Alex Housman who has stolen money from his Central High School classmates and who is addicted to stealing cars and taking them on fantasy-sustaining joy-rides: he is not a character that immediately engages one's sympathies.

WASHINGTON -- Mrs. Hubert H. Humphrey just traveled 25,000 miles by car, campaigning strenuously for her husband. She rode in parades, spoke to students in clubs, visited hospitals, handed out literature on the street. She called it all "a wonderful experience."

The fundamental reform of New Jersey's inadequate and regressive tax structural has been so long overdue, and so slow in the coming, that the chances for success at the current session of the State Legislature must not be frivolously lost. There is an immediate need for Gov. William T. Cahill, who champions reform, and leaders of the Democratic opposition to Work out reasonable compromises.
PIERRE, S. D., June 27 -- The Republicans have chosen their candidate to run for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 27 -- On the tense first day of the truce called by the Irish Republican Army's militant Provisional wing in agreement with the British, William Whitelaw, Northern Ireland's administrator, began a delicate effort today to reconcile the hostile Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, turned over to the Congressional Black Caucus today a list, which he said came from the Secret Service, containing 5,500 names and aliases of black people on whom he said dossiers are maintained.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate voted today to increase appropriations for Federal health and education programs more than $2-billion above what President Nixon requested in his budget for the next fiscal year. The vote was 72 to 11.
The scheduled appearance of Angela Davis on the Dick Cavett television show this week will not take place because of a dispute over whether a "balancing" guest should appear on the same program.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 27 -- In a frankness the people of Pakistan have not heard, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto tonight admitted that Pakistan suffered a crushing defeat in the December war with India and that nearly a million people were homeless because of Indian occupation of West Pakistani territory.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Newly disclosed sections of the Pentagon papers show that the Soviet Union, after first rebuffing American requests in 1965 to serve as a middleman in ending the Vietnam war, be-came progressively more interested in acting as a diplomatic channel between Washington and Hanoi. But, the papers add, Moscow always seemed unwilling to put pressure on North Vietnam to give up its struggle.

JERSEY CITY, June 27 -- A reform coalition headed by Mayor Paul T. Jordan seized control of the regular Hudson County Democratic organization here tonight, electing Mayor Francis G. Fitzpatrick of Bayonne as the new Democratic County chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House of Representatives passed the debt-ceiling bill today and sent it to the Senate, where Democrats are expected to attempt, over the Administration's objections, to add an amendment increasing Social Security benefits. The vote was 211 to 168.

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, June 27 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister John Vorster spoke out last night against students who participate in demonstrations against unequal opportunities for blacks and whites.

The situation is improving but there is still a long difficult road ahead, William T. Seawell, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, told security analysts yesterday.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27 -- Asserting that President Nixon had been "playing to racist emotions," Senator George McGovern traveled across the South today, appealing to Populist sentiments.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order today to stop indefinitely a planned offering of additional stock by the Levitz Furniture Company.

The entire academic community of New England must feel a double sadness at the departure of Naval R.O.T.C. from another campus like that of Brown University. There is cause to deplore the end of an association that has brought multiple benefits to the colleges, to the military services and to most of the students involved.
Message from Secretary of State Dean Rusk to Foy D. Kohler, Ambassador to Moscow, May 11, 1965.
Stock prices turned steadier yesterday, recovering from the effects of the floating of the British pound abroad and from the flooding caused by tropical storm Agnes at home.

T. J. Sellers' June 9 Op-Ed article protested the current trend in our schools to replace the teaching of conventional English with the so-called "black dialect." I am a teacher of English in a junior high school, a ghetto school, and I quite agree that it is a disservice to these children and to the black community to substitute street vernacular for good grammar.

STRATFORD, Conn., Even one of my worst minds would not call me a Shavian, yet I must admit that I had rather a good time at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater's critic's preview of Bernard Shaw's "Major Barbara."

Three weeks of state-city talks on welfare ineligibility wound up yesterday with disagreement on three-fourths of the cases involved, with the State Welfare Inspector General insisting that the city granted relief to 33 ineligible cases and the city contending that the cases were eligible.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson argued today that the Nixon Administration's past arms-control proposals demonstrated that the United States had made numerous last-minute concessions to the Soviet Union to reach the two accords last month on limiting some nuclear weapons.

SIMLA, India, June 28 -- Shades of past glories hang like mountain mist over the rugged, pine-clad site of the peace conference this week between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, June 28--Backers of Senator George McGovern won a skirmish today in the competition for seating delegates to the Democratic National Convention, but their show of strength appeared insufficient to win the major battle that faces them tomorrow over California's 271 delegates.

HUE, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 29 -A force of about 10,000 South Vietnamese marines and paratroopers pushed above the country's northernmost defense line yesterday, starting a drive to retake Quangtri Province, which fell to the North Vietnamese nearly two months ago.

LONDON, June 28 -- The pound and the dollar weakened further as official foreign-exchange trading resumed on the Continent today. But there was no rout, and speculators held back to wait for a clear trend.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 28 -- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization's Council of Ministers ended its annual meeting in Canberra today with a communique stressing the need for the alliance to be flexible and responsive to changing world conditions.

International Master Edward Lasker is 86 years old and, we are happy to report, in excellent physical and mental health. The Public Education Association charged yesterday that "control and power," not higher salaries, were the "gut issues" of the city teachers' current contract demands.
Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, indicated yesterday that Bobby Hull could well be the highest paid nonplaying hockey star when the season starts in October.

Mass, which officially opened the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington last September has arrived in the fullness of time at the Metropolitan Opera House, where it is scheduled to play through July 22.
Many states raise money from lotteries these days, and one result has been a growing number of winners wealthy overnight. Some lotteries pay $50,000 a year for life.

SACO, Me. -- There is probably only one striped bass fishing guide on the East Coast who guarantees his clients that they will take fish every time out, and his name is Bob Boilard.

PERU, Ind., June 28 (AP) -- A farmer who found and turned in $500,000 dropped by a plane hijacker refused a $10,00 gift from American Airlines today. He indicated he thought the reward should be larger.

A telephone subscriber who moves to a new address will receive a $5 credit fee from the New York Telephone Company if he snips off the telephone wire at his former residence and turns the telephone over to a company serviceman at his new address.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it was reviewing its procedures in disciplinary actions involving member firms, their officers and employes with a view toward a basic revision.

The Corning Glass Works reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for its second quarter and half-year periods that ended June 18, only five days before the company's plant in Corning, N. Y., was struck by the effects of tropical storm Agnes.

International Computers, Ltd., the only major non-American based company competing in the world data-processing market, is being courted by the Burroughs Corporation of Detroit, both companies confirmed yesterday.

The Ginkelvan, a 20-passenger mini-bus (or maxi-taxi) that is no longer than a Cadillac limousine and was designed for crowded city centers, was shown here for the first time yesterday.

A contempt-of-court action against Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Union, was postponed for a second time yesterday to allow for continued mediation of a contract dispute between the union and the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes.

ELLICOTT CITY, Md., June 28 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew assessed storm damage in his home state today and termed it "appalling."

PARIS, June 28 (UPI) -- France has resumed nuclear atmospheric testing in the South Pacific despite vigorous protests that the blasts might endanger the environment, Agence France-Presse reported today.

TRENTON, June 28 -- "Let me put it this way. People who want something are reluctant to call the Governor, so they call me. Say a businessman doesn't like a tax program, or a legislator opposes a bill. They'll call me to see if the Governor can do something about it."

NEWARK, June 28 -- Federal and state grand juries today simultaneously indicted Paul J. Sherwin, the New Jersey Secretary of State and the second most powerful official in the Republican administration of Gov. William T. Cahill, on extortion and bribery charges.

A high Treasury official asserted yesterday that the Administration's "tougher" enforcement of the antidumping act was in reality a liberal trade measure designed to assure fair competition for all importers and domestic producers.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 28 -- Janie Blalock was having luncheon on the terrace of the Winged Foot Golf Club today when she received word that her injunction against the L.P.G.A. would be continued. She dropped a fork and ran into the clubhouse.

MIAMI BEACH, June 28 -- Chuck Hall, the silver-haired Mayor, points out an original John Lennon drawing hanging in his office and exchanges the radical movement's special handshake with gay activists, underground journalists and anyone else young and hairy within reach.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator John C. Stennis, confronted with new testimony linking Gen. Creighton W. Abrams to the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam, announced today that the Armed Forces Committee would hold full hearings into the pending retirement of Gen. John D. Lavelle.

In a renewed effort to gain the business community's cooperation in fighting graft, city officials said yesterday that they had scheduled a meeting next week with the Building Construction Advisory Council, whose members include prominent builders, architects, engineers and union officials.

MADISON, N. J., June 28 -- Paul Barry founded the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in 1963, and for seven summer seasons in Cape May it offered plays by Shakespeare and other writers. Last summer, after financial crises and the loss of two successive theaters, the festival was homeless.
WASHINGTON -- Even while, he sits in a hospital bed, Governor Wallace remains a pivotal figure in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced yesterday that his agency expected to propose, a variable-rate mortgage plan for savings and loan associations by the end of the year.

Patrolman William R. Phillips, the star witness at last fall's Knapp Commission hearings on police corruption, went on trial here yesterday on charges of murdering a pimp and a prostitute and trying to murder one of the prostitute's customers.
The stock market, still saddled with worries, drifted lower yesterday in one of the slowest trading sessions of 1972.

An off-duty Transit Authority patrolman died last night, four hours after being shot in a gun battle in a Bronx subway station. The police said the patrolman had stopped a man who had a gun protruding from his belt.
The ban on advertising of sanitary napkin, tampon and douche products on television stations that subscribe to the Television Code will be lifted on Nov. 1.
Noise-control legislation described as "the most comprehensive" in the country was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Organized labor challenged today the right of Congress to deny workers for small companies the standards of health and safety now required of large and small employers alike under the Occupational Safety and Health Act.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, welcomed today "the decision of a number of major industrial countries, including the members of the European Economic Community,'' to defend the pattern of currency exchange rates established last December in the Smithsonian agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Government's composite index of "leading" indicators of the economy rose only slightly in May following more than a year of strong growth, the Commerce Department reported today.
In a ceremony marked by short speeches, energetic music and a rooftop buffet luncheon, city officials and community leaders dedicated the first Police Athletic League center in Harlem yesterday.

" Are you a screwball?" A television interviewer put the question last weekend to Councilman Matthew Joseph Troy Jr., and added that it was a question "some members of the Lindsay administration ask behind your back."

The New York Telephone Company was accused yesterday of "extorting" high deposits from customers it wants to punish and from those who make repeated complaints.
ATLANTA, June 29 (AP) -For Denny McLain and Orlando Cepeda, a wish came true today: they were traded.

Gilbert Highet, who enlivened the intellectual odysseys of thousands of young men over a 30-year period at Columbia University, will retire today as Anthon Professor of Latin Language and Literature.

Fifty disabled youths were registered for summer employment yesterday in a special eight-week work program jointly sponsored by the Youth Services Agency and the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine at the New York University Medical Center.
PARIS, June 24 (UPI) -France said today that she would put into service in 1976 a hydrogen warhead that would be invulnerable to radiation from antimissile weapons.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Supreme Court ruled today, by a 5-to-4 vote, that Congressional immunity did not prevent a grand jury from asking Senator Mike Gravel or his aides certain questions about his version of the Pentagon papers -- including the question where had he obtained the papers.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 29 -- Last March her physician told her that she would never be able to play competitive golf again. But today Shirley Englehorn took the lead in the United States Women's Open championship with a first round of 72.

Interest rates in the United States stiffened across the board this week, at least partly as a result of the turmoil in the international money markets, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

Plans for a summer-long voter registration program directed at working-class communities in the city were announced at Mayor Lindsay's office yesterday by the National Movement for the Student Vote. The Mayor endorsed the program, which will involve up to 100 young people as special registrars each day, according to the announced plan.

In the dark ages of 1956, a propeller-driven plane bound for Australia and the Olympic Games stopped to refuel in Fiji and passengers stepped down near a cluster of grass-roofed huts. So these were the fabled islands of Captain Cook, land of cannibals and head-hunters. It seemed unreal, and unbelievably far from the Eighth Avenue subway.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -The Phillies caught up to the New York Mets tonight in no uncertain terms. For the seventh trading session in a row, prices dwindled yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, and the index closed at 27.17, down 0.03. The NASDAQ index of over-the-counter issues was down to 138.75, off 0.54.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Senate passed a $9.6-billion antipoverty bill today that included a provision to put the Legal Services program for the poor under an independent corporation.

The disappearance of about 10 important documents and letters involving trading in the common stock of the Levitz Furniture Corporation was reported yesterday to be impeding one of several investigations.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -President Nixon gave the country a splendid demonstration tonight of how he hopes to succeed himself in the White House without really running. While the lawyer-dominated New York State Legislature was again rejecting proposals for no-fault automobile insurance -- proposals which the New York State Department of Insurance helped to pioneer -- lawmakers across the Hudson in New Jersey were quietly enacting this fundamental reform calculated to speed recoveries and reduce costs. C. -- I am a doctor, deeply concerned with the dangers inherent in accidental poisoning of children, and for the last 35 years I have been urging manufacturers not to tell small children that medication is "just like candy." The Piping Rock horse show, one of the leading events in the country for more than half a century, has been canceled for this year. The show was scheduled for Sept. 14-17. The announcement was made the other day by Mrs. Sarah Steel of Syosset, vice presi dent of the show.

HUNTINGTON, L. I. -- A small boat cruised near shore in Huntington Harbor recently while a bay constable photographed private piers. Weeks later the piers' owners were asked to sign leases and pay rent on their dock facilities.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 1 -- Consumers in Nassau County are being charged the state sales tax 60 per cent of the time on nontaxable items, thus paying "several million dollars annually" in taxes that they should not be paying, according to a survey of supermarkets, delicatessens and drugstores by the Nassau Office of Consumer Affairs.

Although both sides indicated their belief yesterday that a hospital walkout could still be averted, officers of Local 1199, the Drug and Hospital Union, went ahead with plans to strike more than 60 voluntary and municipal hospitals on Thursday.

KONSTANZ, West Germany, July 2 -- Donald R, Hodgman, economics professor at the University of Illinois, has just analyzed before an international group of financial men here the prospects for a currency union in Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -Senator George McGovern indicated today that he would work to end party factionalism in the week before the Democratic National Convention.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 2 -Bert Freemn captured the national men's senior foil championship today and virtually assured himself a place on the Olympic fencing team.

Big-band buffs had a feast at the Newport Jazz Festival's concerts at Philharmonic Hall Sunday evening. If the menu left something to be desired, the lightness of the diet can be overlooked because of its sheer rarity: how often is there an opportunity to hear three top-notch big jazz ensembles in a single program?
LENOX, Mass., July 2 -- With a red-and-white-striped tent, serving as opera house, the Lenox Arts Center has opened its season with Virgil Thomson's "The Mother of Us All."
EUGENE, Ore., July 2 -- The signs of another major money scandal in track and field have appeared at the United States Olympic trials.
Not only do Wall Street and retailing feel the effects of major national events, but apparently also the mail order business.

Shouting "Ralph," the first name of one of his victims, a gunman wounded six persons -- one seriously -- yesterday morning with a shotgun in front of 1414 Vyse Avenue in the South Bronx. The assailant fled.

For the 39 teams competing in the World Team Olympiad in Miami Beach, the qualifying stage was normally a question of zigging to victory one moment and zagging to defeat the next. Several teams had the misfortune to zag much more often than they zigged.

Not content that the odds are against them in this election year, the Democrats seem bent, as usual, on decreasing their chances still further. The battles in the credentials committee over the California and Illinois delegations are unlikely to lose the nomination for Senator George McGovern, but the bitterness they are generating can only make the re-election of President Nixon more probable.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation submitted to the White House last October an 18-point plan designed to assure that the Government of Chile's Marxist president, Salvador Allende Gossen, "does not get through the crucial next six months."
Some of Count Basie's former sidemen came out of the past yesterday to show their old boss how superbly a big jazz band can swing.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 2 -- The Senator, owned and handled by Frank Andrea of Syosset, L.I., captured the puissance (high jump) today at the Gaudeamus Farms' horse show. The Senator and Judy Korn's Easy Rider, ridden by Terry Rudd, both knocked down the wall at 6 feet 2 inches.
BRUSSELS, July 2 -- The week following the floating of the pound sterling has been one of teapot tempests rather than crisis, as far as the Eurobond market is concerned.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- The steel market was behaving in a predictable manner last week. Advance orders indicated shipments would dip in July and rebound in August. Officials said this swing reflected the normal summer pattern of automobile production and procurement.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 3 (Reuters) -North Vietnamese troops shelled the city of Hue for four hours yesterday, killing or wounding about 50 persons, military sources said.

A South Vietnamese student, apparently an antiwar dissident whose scholarship in the United States was canceled recently, was shot and killed at Tansonnhut Airport in Saigon yesterday after he attempted to divert a Pan American jumbo-jet flight to Hanoi.

CANTON, Ohio, July 2 (AP) -- Willy White won a 13th national title today, but another long-time competitor, Mrs. Olga Connally, tearfully hinted of retirement after finishing second in the Amateur Athletic Union women's discus throw.

Marcel Goldfarb and Ken Ginty, an unseeded team from the New York Athletic Club, scored another upset yesterday in gaining the semifinals of the national one-wall doubles handball championships at Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.

Senator George McGovern's economic policies have aroused great controversy in Wall Street and seriously jeopardized some of the sources of campaign funds that have traditionally been available in the financial community for liberal candidates.
" Fiddler on the Roof," the longest-running show in Broadway history, closed yesterday after its 3,242d performance.

The House of Molade sold brown rice and black-eyed peas and sweet whole-wheat corn bread. Amateur and professional musicians played -- some alone and some with dancers. And children carried red, green and black balloons at the Harlem street fair held yesterday on Seventh Avenue by the House of Kuumba.

In only 1,659 games, much fewer than Gil Hodges or Hank Aaron had needed to accomplish the feat, Willie McCovey yesterday hit his 14th career grand-slam homer as the Giants routed the slumping Dodgers, 9-3, at San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -Only minutes after his televised news conference last Thursday night, President Nixon telephoned his chief of Congressional relations, Clark MacGregor.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The United States has been secretly seeding clouds over North Vietnam, Laos and South Vietnam to increase and control the rainfall for military purposes.

Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm sat down the other day with 20 male inmates awaiting sentencing and told them about a legal advocate program to overcome some of their complaints about court procedures.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 2 -- "I don't care what she pays me," Mrs. Susie Maxwell Berning's caddie said today as he trudged off the 18th green at Winged Foot Golf Club. "She's the most consistent golfer I've ever worked for, male or female. Maybe not the longest hitter, but the most consistent."

CAPE MAY, N. J., -- One year ago this resort city closed off a three-block stretch of roadway and created the Washington Mall, an oleo of well-restored Victorian era shops and ticky-tacky imitations, of old gas lights and new electrified adaptations, of merchants historically located here and of late-coming entrepreneurs.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 2 -- Under a hot sun that turned muddy streets to fine dust today, residents of the Southern Tier continued cleanup operations in the wake of the worst flood in the history of the area.
Now that summer is here, parents with teen-age children about to go off to college have some planning to do involving taxes and other financial aspects of education.
Albatross towered above all other performers in harness racing's weekend as the 4-year-old pacer posted the fastest mile ever on Saturday night at Sportsman's Park in Chicago.

Credit analysts remained optimistic late last week, even as money rates climbed rapidly, that a major increase could be avoided in the cost of longterm money. To be sure, most interest rates climbed sharply throughout June because of the expanding economy, skepticism about the attack on inflation, heavy Treasury financing in the first half of the new fiscal year and international currency turmoil.
" Touch Me." No, it's not a new X-rated film. Not a new sensitivity game, either. But how about soap in a tube -- because that's what it is.
MILAN, Italy -- Subscribers to expensive seats at La Scala recently snubbed Mozart by staying away from the visiting Salzburg production of "The Abduction From the Seraglio."
MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 (AP) -- Northwest Airlines has laid off a "very substantial majority" of its 8,500 nonstriking employes as the result of a walkout by pilots, a Northwest spokesman said today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 2 -- Three bullet-riddled bodies were found in Belfast today amid rising tension between Roman Catholics and Protestants.

Even before he emerges to stride confidently to the mound, the crowd knows he is Albert W. (Sparky) Lyle, relief pitcher extraordinary, and when he showed up on schedule yesterday, noisy anticipation quickly became happy reality.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- The Yemen Arab Republic and the United States officially announced the resumption of diplomatic relations today.

MONTREAL, July 2 -- The New York Mets, who had beaten the Expos six successive times, went down to a 4-3 defeat today in Jarry Park, but it was not robust hitting that ended New York's streak.

SAIGON, July 2 (AP) -- The United States command announced today the loss of three more United States Air Force F-4 Phantom jets over North Vietnam, with all six crewmen missing.

PRINCETON, N. J. -- When Richard Nixon assumed the Presidency in 1969, he diagnosed the malaise of this nation as a "crisis of the spirit," and he promised that his Administration would meet that crisis with "an answer of the spirit." Since the inaugural Mr. Nixon has done his utmost to meet this pledge.

LONDON, July 2 -- TFhe reconnaisance techniques developed by the United States in Vietnam are especially remarkable in their selective capacity. They can count the number of furnaces in a steel mill hit by American planes, but they do not see bombed hospitals or schools or houses.

DARIEN, Conn., July 2 -Jordan Miller of Ossining, N. Y., and Mrs. Lois Stephens's Arcadius formed an unbeatable combination today and won the two leading events in the Ox Ridge Hunt Club all-dressage horse show.

EUGENE, Ore., July 2 -- Reaffirming his status as one of track and field's supreme competitors, Bob Seagren cleared 18 feet 5 3/4 inches on his final attempt tonight and regained sole possession of the world record in the pole vault.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 2 -- President Nixon's removal of quota restrictions on meat imports is warmly welcomed in New Zealand as being in line with a policy frequently urged on the United States to reduce agricultural protectionism.
WUHAN, China, June 23 -"They were our best teachers -- they taught us to do things with our own hands."
CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -Lanny Wadkins shot a four-under-par 67 today and moved into a tie with Larry Hinson for the lead after three rounds of the rain-delayed $150,000 Cleveland open tournament.
A Puerto Rican exodus from Manhattan nearly double the borough's over-all population rate of decline in the nineteen-sixties was reported yesterday in 1970 census reports.

Metropolitan Opera orchestra members chose phrases like molto legato (very smooth) and even con amore (with love yesterday to describe the negotiations that settled their three-year contract a month before the deadline.

Sir Robert is identified as "the British expert on guerrilla warfare who has undertaken secret missions for President Nixon to report on events in Vietnam."
LOS ANGELES, July 2 -- The head of a Jewish community relations group said today that he was "appalled by the depth of ignorance" in Israel about the character of Jewish community life in America.

Doctors at Columbia and Yale, reacting to an unpublicized recent outbreak of Lassa fever in Liberia that claimed the life of an American nurse among others, are planning a new study into the mysterious viral disease.

Five ad agencies are being "actively considered" for the Marine Corps recruiting advertising assignment. The contract the Corps had with J. Walter Thompson, which is one of the five, ran out yesterday and the Pentagon said it should have its decision in around July 20. Thompson has had the assignment for a quarter of a century.
HADDAM, Conn. July 2 -On a quiet morning in Haddam or Higganum so many caterpillars are feasting on leaves that they sound like the light pitter-patter of rain.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- It doesn't seem like the same old Wimbledon. True, the contract pros are temporarily missing, but with a week gone the quarterfinal line-up presents for the first time three players from Eastern Europe, and top-seeded Stan Smith, who is supposed to win it, is drawn to meet them all.
President Nixon continues to lead both Senators George McGovern and Hubert H. Humphrey, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Supporters of Senator George McGovern tried to recapture their vanishing majority on the Democratic convention's Credentials Committee today by replacing three New York members who had registered independent voting records.

Eckerd's, Inc., a privately owned chain of drug stores based in Erie, Pa., is making a tender offer to purchase all the 1,044,186 outstanding common shares of Erie Technological Products, Inc., at $14 a share, it was announced yesterday.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2 -- President Nixon, on a working vacation at his Western White House here, telephoned today to both his just-resigned campaign manager, John N. Mitchell, and Mr. Mitchell's successor, Clark MacGregor.

NEW ORLEANS, July 2 (AP) -- Federal officials have arrested nine men in Texas and Louisiana on charges of conspiring to smuggle munitions to Mexico for the overthrow of a foreign country, presumably Cuba.

Joseph F. Crangle, the state Democratic chairman, said yesterday he would vote to "sustain the primary results" in Illinois and seat Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago and 58 adherents who had been ousted in favor of a slate of challengers.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 2 -Joseph Fielding Smith, president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints -- the Mormon Church -- died tonight here at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Bruce R. McConkie, according to a church official. His death was apparently of natural causes. He would have been 96 years old on July 19.

Ten or 20 years from now will the Manhattan central business district -- the warren of steel and stone south of 60th Street that is the workplace of 2.2 million people -- still be the national center it is today for corporate headquarters.

WARSAW, July 2 -- A Western expert on East-West trade who had been in Warsaw 10 years ago was asked at a conference the other day by a Polish newsman if the visitor noticed any difference in the Polish capital.

When President Nixon named him as the best allround athlete in major league baseball history, Jackie Robinson seemed surprised but very pleased with the "real honor." The former Brooklyn Dodger second baseman and the first black athlete in the major leagues said, "He's an individual making his picks and I'm honored that he thought of me in that way.

Kodaly's gustily expansive Te Deum and Donizetti's very operatic Requiem for Bellini were the contrasting pair of choral works heard at the Caramoor Festival Saturday night. It would be difficult to imagine two more dissimilar approaches to the liturgy, but in practice these pieces played off against each other most effectively in Caramoor's congenial open-air surroundings.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- E. Howard Hunt Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency official now sought by Federal agents in connection with last month's raid on the Democratic National Committee here, was reliably reported today to have fled to Europe and possibly to be in Spain.

BALDWIN, L. I., July 2 -The pitch floats down from an arc as high as 10-feet, coming in as big as a pumpkin. Jim Galloway at home plate is relaxed, muscles apparently limp, watching the ball as if he had all the time in the world.

Susan Kinsey writes (letter June 26) that she deplores an attempt by the B'nai B'rith "to infringe upon the right of any American to criticize Israel's motives or actions." Yet she is "indignant" regarding certain statements in the June 16 ad she refers to and states it is "ludicrous to attempt to defend Israel's policy of full and equal citizenship."

WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 -In the wake of last Saturday night's Roosevelt Raceway debacle, caused by breakdowns in two computer systems which resulted in a five-race card, it developed today that the win payoff of $21 on Jefferson Aiken in the second race should have been only $7.20.
Soybean futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Oil and meal futures prices moved upward in sympathy with those of soybeans.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 -- Federal District Judge William Matt Byrne Jr. denied today a defense motion in the Pentagon papers case, that would have quashed the indictment on the ground that it constituted discriminatory prosecution.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- The Soviet Union announced last week that a rapidly growing nuclear power station in central Russia had become the largest on the Eurasian continent and showed off the atomic complex to Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

SILVER SPRING, Md., July 3 -- To the doctors, nurses and orderlies at Holy Cross Hospital, he is the model patient -a scarred Southern gentleman who jokes and laughs and winks despite his pain and suffering.

Trying to forget about "yesterday," when his troubles seemed so far away, Denny McLain returns to the major leagues tonight when he will start for his new team, the Atlanta Braves, against the Chicago Cubs. Twice voted the American League's top pitcher, he was demoted to the minors this season by the Oakland Athletics, who traded him last week.

EUGENE, Ore., July 3 -- Despite a temperature of 97 degrees, Jeff Bannister zeroed in on an 8,000-point performance after opening day decathlon competition at the United States Olympic track and field trials today.

ATHENS, July 3 -- Leaders of the Greek political opposition expressed "pain and bitterness" today over the scheduled arrival here tomorrow of Secretary of State William P. Rogers for talks with Premier George Papadopoulos.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 (UPI) -- The big American-owned construction combine known as RMK-BRJ ended its operations in Vietnam today after 10 years in which it built $1.9-billion worth of military installations and public works under Government contract.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 3 (AP) -- An official of the Small Business Administration said today that his agency would provide some $500-million for flood-relief programs and added that "the biggest chunk will go to Pennsylvania."

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, July 4 -- High-level representatives of North and South Korea held secret talks in Seoul and Pyongyang recently and agreed on principles to reunify the divided nation by peaceful means, a joint North-South communique announced here today.

The semi-holiday quiet around City Hall was shattered for a few hours yesterday as more than 150 junior and senior high school students from the Williamsburg area of Brooklyn staged an angry demonstration demanding more summer jobs under a federally financed program.

Buccaneer owned by Tom Clark of Auckland, New Zealand was reported yesterday to be the leader in the trans-Atlantic yacht race from Bermuda to Bayona, Spain. The boats had been at sea four days when they radioed their positions at noon.

I.T.T. not only maneuvered to try to block the inauguration of Chile's President Allende after his election in 1970, but sought White House involvement last October in a covert campaign to bring down his Government.

MIAMI BEACH, July 3 -- The Democrats open their convention here a week from today. CAIRO, July 3 -- Yemen's decision to resume diplomatic relations with Washington -- combined with indications that the Sudan may soon follow suit -was condemned here today as another painful example of Arab inability to take a common stand against common enemies.

VIENNA -- The West is no longer able to import cheap energy from developing countries. Interest rates registered only negligible changes in extremely light trading yesterday. The credit markets generally operated with reduced staffs, with many traders and syndicate personnel given the day off.
ROME, July 3 -- Italian bankers, politicians and people with savings accounts are almost fatalistically convinced that there is no longer a question of whether the lira will be devalued, but of when.
The Newport Jazz Festival's Carnegie Hall concert last night was a peculiar mixture of quietly exploratory chamber jazz and aggressively outgoing jazz-rock.

A bed reproduced from an impression of an antiquity found on the Greek island of Santorini has again shown that in furniture, at least, it is almost impossible to improve on the ancients. The line-for-line copy is part of an exhibition of four Greek furniture manufacturers' designs on view through Friday at the Greek Trade Center, 150 East 58th Street.

GENEVA, July 3 -- The Swiss National Bank bought dollars today to anchor the Swiss franc to its official exchange rate against the dollar for the first time since the start of the recent monetary unrest.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Government officials expect a warrant to be issued by Wednesday for the arrest of E. Howard Hunt Jr. as a material witness in connection with last month's raid on the Democratic National Committee.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3 (AP) -- President Nixon will address the nation by radio tomorrow in a July 4 holiday speech expected to call for unity to meet the "great trials" the President sees ahead for the American people.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 4 -- With strong Saigon forces fighting their way into Communist-occupied Quangtri Province, North Vietnamese forces farther south replied yesterday with heavy artillery barrages. For the first time, the city of Hue came under fire from long-range 130-mm. guns.

Leo C. Zeferetti, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association charged yesterday that city prisons have reached "new inhuman levels of overcrowding" and that they could "boil over into a riot situation at any moment."
